Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1A., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed art. I, § 2-1, which pertained to residence requirements of employees, and derived from Ord. No. 95, §§ 2-7.01-2-7.04, adopted February 28, 1972. 

Secs. 2-1-2-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 

Sec. 2-16. - Superintendent. 
    The department of public works shall be headed by the superintendent of public works, who shall be responsible for all matters relating to construction, management, maintenance, and operation of the physical properties of the city, except as provided elsewhere in this Code. The superintendent shall also be responsible for all planning in connection with such changes or improvements to the physical properties as are essential to the future growth and development of the city. 
(Code 1957, § 2-3.01) 
Sec. 2-17. - Divisions. 
    The department of public works may be divided into divisions which shall include, but not be restricted to the following: 
(1)  Division of engineering. The division of engineering shall be supervised by a competent civil engineer experienced in the design and construction of municipal engineering works. This division shall perform all engineering services for the department and for such other departments of the city as may from time to time require such services. The supervision of all constructed work undertaken by the city shall also be furnished by this division except as otherwise ordered by the city manager. 
    Bureau of permits and inspections. The bureau of permits and inspections shall be under the division of engineering, and shall be supervised by a city inspector who shall: 
(a)  Issue all permits for, and inspect the work involved in, the construction of sewer and water services, sidewalks, curb cuts, street cuts; 
(b)  Inspect, or cause to be inspected, all work done under the provisions of the electrical, plumbing, and building codes of the city; and 
(c)  Inspect, or cause to be inspected, all premises, including structures and appurtenances thereon, for safety features. 
(2)  Division of pumping and filtration. The division of pumping and filtration shall be supervised by a qualified person who shall have charge of the pumping, purifying, softening and filtering of water supplied to the water distribution system. 
(3)  Division of water and sewer maintenance. The division of water and sewer maintenance shall be supervised by a qualified person who shall have charge of the construction, operation and maintenance of the city water distribution and sewage systems. 
(4)  Division of parks and cemeteries. The division of parks and cemeteries shall be supervised by a qualified person who shall have charge of the control and regulation of the planting of trees and of the planning, development, maintenance, management and operation of parks, boulevards, cemeteries, municipal parking lots, markets, airports and recreation facilities, except that the recreational use of city recreation areas and facilities shall be under the supervision of the director of recreation. 
(5)  Division of street and bridge maintenance. The division of street and bridge maintenance shall be supervised by a qualified person who shall have charge of the maintenance of all improved and unimproved street surfaces, the cleaning of improved streets, the removal of snow, the maintenance and operation of bridges, the operation of the city sanitary landfill, and such other problems of maintenance and service as may be required of the division by the director of public works. 
(6)  Division of signal service. The division of signal service shall be supervised by a signal service supervisor who shall be responsible for the construction, installation, repair and maintenance of all facilities of the fire and police signal systems, traffic-control signals, and other electrically operated signals but excluding the fire and police radio systems. Such supervisor shall supervise the work of cable splicers and those other employees who assist in the construction, installation, repair and maintenance of such facilities. This division may be called upon to provide services for other departments. Such services shall be provided when ordered by the city manager and, in the performance of such service, the signal service supervisor shall be subject to call by the department head concerned. 
(Code 1957, § 2-3.02) 
Secs. 2-18-2-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-29. - Members serving at time Code is adopted. 
    All members serving on boards and commissions at the time this Code is adopted shall, provided the board or commission on which they are serving is continued by this Code, remain in office for the duration of the term for which they were appointed. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.01) 
Sec. 2-30. - Membership. 
    Unless hereinafter otherwise specifically provided, all boards and commissions of the city shall be composed of seven (7) members. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.05) 
Sec. 2-31. - Members' terms of office. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the terms of members of boards and commissions shall be staggered. No persons shall serve on the same board or commission for a period of more than two (2) consecutive terms exclusive of a partial term to fill a vacancy. A member may however be reappointed after a lapse of at least one year. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.06) 
Sec. 2-32. - Compensation of members. 
    Unless otherwise provided, all members of boards and commissions shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.04) 
Sec. 2-33. - Vacancies. 
    Any vacancy occurring in the membership of any board or commission shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by the city commission. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.02) 
Sec. 2-34. - Removal of members. 
    The appointing authority may remove any member of any board or commission for cause. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.03) 
Sec. 2-35. - Officers. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the officers of all boards and commissions shall consist of a chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary. Such officers shall be elected annually at the first regular meeting of such board or commission following after June thirtieth. In the event a treasurer is required for any board or commission, the city treasurer shall serve ex officio in that capacity. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.07) 
Sec. 2-36. - Bylaws, rules and regulations. 
    Each board or commission shall have the power to make and adopt such bylaws, rules or regulations as may be deemed expedient for the exercise of its powers. Such bylaws, rules or regulations shall become effective upon the filing of a copy with the city clerk and presentation of the same to the city commission at the next regular city commission meeting. Any bylaw, rule or regulation shall become void upon the veto of either the city manager or the city commission. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.08) 
Sec. 2-37. - Expenditures. 
    No board or commission shall incur any expense or obligate the city in any respect without first securing specific authorization from the city commission. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.09) 
Sec. 2-38. - Purchases. 
    All purchases by any board or commission shall be handled through the city purchasing agent in accordance with customary city procedures and in accordance with the Charter. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.10) 
Sec. 2-39. - Deposit of funds with city treasury, bonds, bills. 
(a)  All moneys received for any board or commission shall be deposited in the treasury of the city, to the credit of such board or commission in a special account fund and shall be drawn upon by the officers of such board or commission as the members of such board or commission and the city manager shall designate. 
(b)  All bills shall be allowed at a meeting of the board or commission, and, when certified, shall be paid so long as funds are available. 
(c)  All moneys collected by any board or commission shall be deposited monthly or more often with the city treasurer. Forms for the collection and remittances of all funds shall be prescribed by the city auditor. Such funds shall be remitted intact to the city treasurer. All persons regularly handling funds or any persons handling funds in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be bonded in like manner as other city employees. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.11) 
Sec. 2-40. - City auditor to prepare books, annual budget. 
    The city auditor shall set up such books and forms for the audit and report of all funds received by any board or commission as deemed proper and advisable by the auditor, or as may be required by the charter. There shall be an annual audit of the accounts of all boards and commissions, certified by the city auditor to the city commission as to sources of all funds, the amount of money expended, and for what purposes. In addition thereto, the board of directors of any board or commission shall submit a proposed budget on or before March first of each year showing the anticipated funds and proposed expenditures for the coming year. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.12) 
Sec. 2-41. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1A., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed § 2-41, which pertained to annual reports, and derived from the Code of 1957, § 3-1.13. 
Sec. 2-42. - No member or relative to be employed. 
    No member of any board or commission shall be employed by such board or commission or be directly or indirectly interested in any contract with such board or commission. No relative of any member of a board or commission shall be employed by such board or commission. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1.14) 
Secs. 2-43-2-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1A., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed div. 2, §§ 2-50 and 2-51, which pertained to the safety council, and derived from the Code of 1957, §§ 3-3.01 and 3-3.02. 

Secs. 2-50-2-58. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PLANNING COMMISSION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 528-11, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, amended Div. 3 in its entirety and enacted the provisions set out herein. The former Div. 3, titled Planning and Development Commission, derived from Ord. No. 222-82, § 2, adopted Feb. 1, 1982; and Ord. No. 466-03, § 1, adopted Jan. 6, 2002. 

Sec. 2-59. - Creation and powers. 
    There is hereby created a planning commission for the City of Sault Ste. Marie, hereinafter referred to as the planning commission. The commission is established pursuant to Act 33 of Public Acts of 2008, as amended, being the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3801 et seq. 
    The commission shall have such powers and duties as set forth in PA 33 of 2008, as amended, being the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3801 et seq. and PA 110 of 2006, as amended, being the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3101 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-60. - Composition. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of nine (9) members who shall be appointed by the mayor, such appointments to be subject to the approval of the majority of the city commission. The individuals shall meet the following qualifications: 
(1)  Shall be a qualified elector of the city, except one (1) nonqualified elector may be a member of the commission; 
(2)  Shall be representative of the important segments of the community, such as the economic, government, educational, and social development of the municipality in accordance with the major interests as they exist in the city such as agriculture, natural resources, recreation, education, public health, government, transportation, industry, commerce, and tourism. The members shall also be representative of the entire geography of the city to the extent practicable. 
(b)  All members shall hold a term of three (3) years, except that three (3) members of the first commission to be so appointed shall serve for a term of one (1) year; three (3) for a term of two (2) years; and three (3) for a term of three (3) years. All members shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(1)  The city commission shall fill any vacancy in the membership of the planning commission for the unexpired terms in the same manner as the initial appointment. 
(c)  No member shall hold any office or position with the city except that a member may also be a member of the zoning board of appeals. 
(d)  The city commission may designate one (1) of its members to sit as a nonvoting liaison on the planning commission. The terms of office of city commission liaisons shall coincide with their elected terms of office with the city. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-61. - Officers, meetings, records, organization. 
(a)  The commission shall elect its chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary from the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. An ex-officio member of the commission is not eligible to serve as chairperson. The term of its officers shall be one (1) year, with eligibility for reelection as specified in the bylaws. 
(b)  The commission shall hold not less than four (4) regular meetings each year, and by resolution shall determine the time and place of the meetings. A majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum to conduct the transaction of business. The affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the total number of seats for members of the commission, regardless if vacancies or absences exist or not shall be necessary for the adoption, or recommendation for adoption, of any plan or amendments to a plan. 
(1)  A special meeting may be called by the chairperson or by two (2) other commission members, upon request to the secretary. Notice of a special meeting shall be given not less than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the special meeting. 
(c)  The commission shall adopt bylaws for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be made a public record. 
(d)  In pursuance of its duties and functions, the planning commission may establish one (1) or more advisory committees to review and analyze various matters under its jurisdiction, provided, however, that no such advisory committee may act for the commission. Such advisory committees may include as members persons who are not on the commission, provided that at least two (2) commissioners are appointed to serve on any such advisory committee. The chairperson of the commission shall make all such committee appointments. 
(e)  Regular or special commission meetings shall be conducted at a public meeting open to the public and held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act, 1976 PA 267, MCL 15.261 to 15.275. Public notice of the time, date, and place shall be given in the manner required by the Act. 
(f)  Any written and/or prepared, owned, used, in the possession of, or retained materials/documents by the commission in the performance of an official function shall be made available to the public in compliance with the Freedom of Information Act of 1976, PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246. 
(g)  The planning commission shall make an annual written report to the city commission concerning its operations and the status or planning activities, including recommendations regarding actions by the city commission related to planning and development. 
(h)  The city commission may remove a member of the planning commission for misfeasance, malfeasance, or nonfeasance in office upon written charges and after a public hearing. Failure of a member to disclose a potential conflict of interest as required by this section shall be constitutes malfeasance in office. Before casting a vote on a matter on which a member may reasonably be considered to have a conflict of interest, the member shall disclose the potential conflict of interest to the planning commission. The member shall be disqualified from voting on the matter if so provided by the bylaws or by a majority vote of the remaining planning commission members. The secretary of the planning commission shall report any member who has missed three (3) regular meetings in a row to the city commission. Failure to repeatedly attend planning commission meetings shall be considered nonfeasance in office. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-62. - Duties and functions. 
    The commission shall have the following duties and functions: 
(a)  Master plan. To make and approve a master plan for the physical development of the municipality. Such master plan, or portion thereof, shall be developed and approved in accordance with provisions of Act 33 of Public Acts of 2008, as amended, being the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3801 et seq., and as summarized in section 2-64. 
(b)  Other plans. To make or coordinate the development of subsidiary or complementary development plans. 
(c)  Capital improvements. To prepare a coordinated and comprehensive program of public structure and improvements, such program to be prepared annually for the ensuing six (6) years in accordance with section 2-65. 
(d)  Zoning. To recommend zoning regulations, changes and amendments to the city commission, in accordance with Act 110 of Public Acts of 2006, as amended being the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, and to administer provisions of the city's zoning ordinance to the extent specified in such ordinance, including but not limited to, site plan reviews and conditional use approvals. 
(1)  The planning commission may by first-class mail or personal delivery submit to the county planning commission, or if there is no county planning commission, the county board of commissioners if requested a copy of the zoning ordinance and any amendments. The commission shall submit the requested documents to the county planning commission, or if there is no county planning commission, the county board of commissioners within sixty-three (63) days after the request is received and shall submit any future amendments to the zoning ordinance within sixty-three (63) days after the amendments are adopted. The commission may also submit a zoning ordinance electronically. 
(e)  Subdivision, lot splits, and land divisions. To review and make recommendations on subdivision, lot splits, and land divisions in accordance with PA 288 of 1967, as amended, and to administer the city's subdivision regulations to the extent specified in such regulations. 
(f)  Coordination. To coordinate implementation of the city's master plan with other city agencies and boards in accordance with section 2-66. Consult with representatives of adjacent local units of governments in respect to their planning so that conflicts in master plans and zoning may be avoided. Cooperate with all departments of the state and federal government and other public agencies concerned with programs for economic, social, and physical development within the municipality and seek the maximum coordination of the city with these agencies. 
(g)  Other duties. To provide recommendations to the city commission on other matters relevant to the future development of the city and as may be requested by the city commission or city manager. 
(h)  Generally. In general, the commission shall have such powers as provided in Act 33 of Public Acts of 2008, as amended, being the Michigan Planning Enabling Act, MCL 125.3801 et seq., as may be necessary to carry out the purpose of this division. Upon request, all public officials shall furnish to the commission such available information as it may require for its work. The commission, its members, officers, and employees, in the performance of their functions, may enter upon and land and make examinations and surveys and place maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-63. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-64. - Master plans. 
    The commission shall make, adopt, amend, and implement a master plan for the physical development of the municipality, including areas outside of its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the municipality. The plan may be adopted as a whole or by successive parts corresponding with major geographic areas of the municipality or with functional subject matter areas of the plan. 
(a)  Content. The plan shall address land use issues and infrastructure projects twenty (20) years or more into the future. The plan shall include maps, plats, charts, and descriptive, explanatory, and other related matter and shall show the commission's recommendations for the physical development of the municipality. The plan shall also include those of the following subjects, which reasonably can be considered as pertinent to the future development of the municipality: 
(1)  A land use plan and program, in part consisting of a classification and allocation of land for agriculture, residences, commerce, industry, recreation, ways and grounds, public buildings, schools, soil conservation, forests, woodlots, open space, wildlife refuges, and other uses and purposes. 
(2)  The general location, character, and extent of streets, railroads, airports, bicycle paths, pedestrian ways, bridges, waterways, and waterfront development; flood prevention works, drainage, sanitary sewers and water supply systems, works for preventing pollution, and works for maintaining water levels; and public utilities and structures. 
(3)  Recommendations as to the general character, extent, and layout for the redevelopment or rehabilitation of blighted areas; and the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, or change of use or extension of streets, ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, utilities, or other facilities. 
(4)  A zoning plan for the control of the height, area, bulk, location, and use of buildings and premises. 
(5)  Recommendations for implementing any of its proposals. 
(6)  The planning commission may, by a majority vote, adopt a subplan for a geographic area less than the entire planning jurisdiction, if the unique physical characteristics require more intensive planning efforts. 
(7)  If the plan is or includes a master street plan, the means for implementing the master street plan in cooperation with the county road commission and the Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) shall be specified in the master street plan in a manner consistent with the respective powers and duties of and any written agreements between these entities and the municipality. 
(b)  Surveys. In the preparation of such plan the commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth of the municipality and with due regard to its relation to the neighboring territory. The plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted, and harmonious development of the municipality and its environs which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity, and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development; including, among other things, adequate provision for traffic, the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers, adequate provision for light and air, the promotion of the healthful and convenient distribution of population, the promotion of good civic design and arrangement, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds, the adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements, and the use of resources in accordance with their character and adaptability. 
(c)  Notice of intent to prepare a plan. A plan may be adopted as a whole or by successive parts corresponding with major geographic areas of the municipality. Before preparing a plan, the commission shall send by first-class mail or personal delivery, a notice explaining that the commission intends to prepare a plan and requesting the recipient's cooperation and comment, to all of the following: 
(1)  The planning commission, or if there is no planning commission, the legislative body, of each township, city, or village located within or contiguous to the municipality. 
(2)  The regional planning commission for the region in which the municipality is located. 
(3)  The county planning commission, or if there is no county planning commission, the county board of commissioners, for the county in which the municipality is located. 
(4)  Each public utility company and railroad within the municipality, and any governmental entity that registers its name and mailing address for this purpose with the commission. 
(5)  If the plan will include a master street plan, the county road commission and the MDOT. 
(6)  A submittal under subsection (d) to an entity described in subsection (c) may be made by personal or first-class mail delivery of a hard copy or by electronic mail. However, the commission preparing the plan shall not make such submittals by electronic mail unless, in the notice described in subsection (c), the commission states that it intends to make such submittals by electronic mail and the entity receiving that notice does not respond by objecting to the use of electronic mail. Electronic mail may contain a link to a website on which the submittal is posted it the website is accessible to the public free of charge. 
(d)  City commission approval of plan distribution. After preparing a proposed plan, the planning commission shall submit the proposed plan to the city commission for review and comment. The process of adopting the plan shall not proceed further unless the city commission approves the distribution of the proposed plan. If the city commission approves the distribution of the proposed plan, it shall notify the secretary of the planning commission. 
(e)  Distribution of plan for review and comment. If the city commission approves the distribution of the proposed plan, the secretary of the planning commission shall submit a copy of the proposed plan, for review and comment, to all of the following: 
(1)  The planning commission, or if there is no planning commission, the legislative body, of each city, village, or township located within or contiguous to the municipality. 
(2)  The regional planning commission for the region in which the municipality is located. 
(3)  The county planning commission, or if there is no county planning commission, the county board of commissioners, for the county in which the municipality is located. The secretary of the commission shall concurrently submit to the county planning commission or, if there is no county planning commission, the county board of commissioners, a statement, signed by the secretary, that the requirements of subsections (1) and (2) have been met. The statement shall include the name and address of each planning commission or legislative body to which a copy of the proposed plan was submitted under subsections (a) and (b) and the date of submittal. 
(4)  Each public utility company and railroad company owning or operating a public utility or railroad within the municipality, and any government entity, that registers its name and address for this purpose with the secretary of the commission. An entity that, pursuant to this subdivision, receives a copy of a proposed plan shall reimburse the municipality for any copying and postage costs thereby incurred by the municipality. 
(5)  If the proposed plan is or includes a proposed master street plan, the county road commission and MDOT. 
(f)  Comments on plan. An entity described in subsection (e) may submit comments on the proposed plan to the planning commission within sixty-three (63) days after the proposed plan was submitted to that entity under subsection (e). 
(g)  County board comments. If the county planning commission or the county board of commissioners that receives a copy of the proposed master plan submits comments, the comments shall include, but need not be limited to, both of the following, as applicable. The comments are advisory only. 
(1)  A statement whether the county board of commissioners, after considering any comments received under subsection (f), considers the proposed plan to be inconsistent with the plan of any city, village, township, or region described in subsection (e)(1) or (2). 
(2)  If the county has a county plan, a statement whether the county planning commission considers the proposed plan to be inconsistent with the county plan. 
(h)  Public hearing, notice. Before approving the proposed plan, the commission shall hold not less than one (1) public hearing on the proposed plan. The hearing shall be held after the expiration of the deadline for comment. The commission shall give notice of the time and place of the public hearing not less than fifteen (15) days' before the hearing by one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality. The commission shall also submit notice to each entity described in subsection (c). 
(i)  Plan approval. The approval of the plan shall be by resolution of the commission carried by the affirmative votes of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members of the commission. The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps and descriptive and other matter intended by the commission to form the whole or part of the plan and the action taken shall be recorded by the chairperson or the secretary of the commission. Following approval of the proposed plan by the commission, the secretary of the commission shall submit a copy of the proposed plan to the city commission. 
(j)  City commission action. Approval of the plan by the planning commission is the final step for adoption of the plan, unless the city commission by resolution has asserted the right to approve or reject the plan. In that case, after approval of the plan by the planning commission, the city commission shall approve or reject the plan. If the proposed plan is rejected, the city commission shall submit to the planning commission a statement of its objections to the proposed plan. The planning commission shall consider the city commission's objections and revise the proposed plan so as to address those objections. The procedures provided in subsections (h) and (i) and this subsection shall be repeated until a proposed plan is approved by the city commission. 
(k)  Plan distribution. Upon final adoption of the plan, copies of the adopted plan shall be submitted in the same manner as provided for submitting copies of the proposed plan under subsection (e). 
(l)  Plan amendments or adoption of new plan. An extension, addition, revision, or other amendment to a plan shall be adopted under the same procedure as a plan or a successive part of a plan as set forth herein, subject however to the following: 
(1)  The review period provided for in subsection (f) shall be forty-two (42) days instead of sixty-three (63) days. 
(2)  Amendments to a master plan involving grammatical, typographical, or similar editorial changes, title changes, or a change to conform to an adopted plat may be made without following the procedure set forth in subsections 2-64(c), (d) and (h). 
(m)  Five-year review . At least every five (5) years after adoption of the plan, the commission shall review the plan and determine whether to commence the procedure to amend the plan or adopt a new plan. The review and its findings shall be recorded in the minutes of the relevant meeting or meetings of the commission. 
(n)  Authority of the plan . A street; square, park, playground, public way, ground, or other open space; or public building or other structure shall not be constructed or authorized for construction in an area covered by a municipal master plan unless the location, character, and extent of the street, public way, open space, structure, or utility have been submitted to the planning commission by the legislative body or other body having jurisdiction over the authorization or financing of the project and has been approved by the planning commission. The planning commission shall submit its reasons for approval or disapproval to the body having jurisdiction. If the planning commission disapproves, the body having jurisdiction may overrule the planning commission by a vote of not less than two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of its entire membership for a township that on the enactment date of this act had a planning commission created under former 1931 PA 285, or for a city or village, or by a vote of not less than a majority of its membership for any other township. If the planning commission fails to act within 35 days after submission of the proposal to the planning commission, the project shall be considered to be approved by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-65. - Capital improvements. 
    For the purpose of furthering the desirable future development of the municipality under the master plan, the planning commission, after adoption of a master plan, shall annually prepare coordinated and comprehensive programs of public structures and improvements. The commission shall annually prepare such a program for the ensuing six (6) years, which programs shall show those public structures and improvements, in the general order of their priority, which in the commission's judgment will be needed or desirable and can be undertaken within the six (6) year period. The programs shall be based upon the requirements of the community for all types of public improvements, and to that end, each agency or department of the city concerned with such improvements shall, upon request, furnish the commission with lists, plans, and estimates of time and cost of those public structures and improvements. The commission may recommend to the city commission programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-66. - Coordination. 
(a)  The commission shall have the power to promote public interest in and understanding of the plan [and] to that end may publish and distribute copies of the plan or of any report and may employ such other means of publicity and education as it may determine. The commission shall coordinate the implementation of the city's development policy and master plan with other city agencies and boards. To this end, other agencies and boards may submit to the planning commission their projects, plans, and grant requests for a "finding of consistency" with the approved development policy and master plan. The commission's determinations in the "consistency" matters shall be submitted to the city commission. 
(b)  The commission shall consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, educational, professional and other organizations, and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-67. - Staff support. 
    The city manager shall appoint the city planner or such other officer as he may determine to act as staff support to the commission. Such staff support shall provide the commission the data, options and analysis needed by the commission to make determinations and recommendations. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 2-68. - Approval, ratification, and reconfirmation. 
    All official actions taken by city commission and/or planning commission during and preceding this division are hereby approved, ratified, and reconfirmed. Any project, review, or process taking place at the effective date of this division shall continue with the planning commission as amended by this division, subject to the requirements of this division, and shall be deemed a continuation of any previous City of Sault Ste. Marie planning commission. This division shall be in full force and effect from and after its adoption and publication. 
(Ord. No. 528-11, 9-6-11)

DIVISION 5. - COMMUNITY SERVICES BOARD 

Sec. 2-76. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted under the provisions of Act 156 of the Public Acts of 1917 of the State of Michigan [MCL § 123.51 et seq.], in which it is provided that any city may operate a public recreation and playground system, there is hereby created a community services board for the city. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 3-6.01, 11-19-73) 
Sec. 2-77. - Appointment; terms of members. 
    The city commission shall appoint the members of the community services board. The board shall consist of nine (9) members with a term of office for each of three (3) years. Members of the first board shall be appointed, effective December 3, 1973 as follows: Three (3) members shall each be appointed for three (3) year terms; three (3) members shall each be appointed for two (2) year terms; three (3) members shall each be appointed for one (1) year terms; and annually thereafter on July 1st, three (3) members shall each be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 3-6.02, 11-19-73; Ord. No. 280-87, § 1, 8-17-87) 
Sec. 2-78. - Compensation, removal and filling of vacancies. 
    The members of the community services board shall serve without compensation and may be removed from office by the city commission. Any vacancy in office shall be filled by the city commission for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 3-6.02, 11-19-73) 
Sec. 2-79. - Meetings. 
    The community services board shall hold meetings at least once a month. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 3-6.06, 11-19-73) 
Secs. 2-80, 2-81. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1A., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed §§ 2-80 and 2-81, which pertained to separate fund and leasing of Pullar Community Building, and derived from Ord. No. 132, §§ 3-6.04 and 3-6.05, adopted November 19, 1973. 
Sec. 2-82. - Duties. 
(a)  The community services board shall act as an advisory board to the city manager and advise the city manager concerning all phases of a parks and recreation program for the city, including the control of the Pullar Community Building; and including all activities, receipts, expenditures, supervision and control of the parks and recreation system and the Pullar Community Building of the city. 
(Ord. No. 132, §§ 3-6.01, 3-6.03, 11-19-73; Ord. No. 584-18, § IA., 11-19-18) 
Secs. 2-83-2-88. - Reserved.

DIVISION 7. - HISTORICAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-103. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to Act 213 of the Public Acts of 1957 [MCL § 399.171, MSA § 5.3395], as amended by Act 33 of the Public Acts of 1968 [MCL § 399.172, MSA § 5.3396], and all amendments thereto, a commission is hereby created in and for the city, to be known as the Sault Ste. Marie Historical Development Commission. 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1 (3-11.01), 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77) 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1 (3-11.02), 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77) 
Sec. 2-104. - Composition, appointment, members, and terms. 
    The city commission shall appoint all the members of the historical development commission. the commission shall consist of seven (7) members, each of whose terms shall consist of seven (7) years. Members of the historical development commission appointed before January 1, 2002 are hereby removed from office. Members of the commission appointed after January 1, 2002 to the historical development commission shall be appointed for the terms of one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), five (5), six (6), and seven (7) years respectively, and annually thereafter one (1) member shall be appointed for seven (7) years. Four (4) of the appointed seven (7) historical development commission members shall be appointed from a list of nominations provided by the Chippewa County Historical Society, Inc. The Chippewa County Historical Society, Inc. shall provide a list of nominations under the terms and conditions of a request of the city commission from time to time. Upon the failure of the Chippewa County Historical Society, Inc. to provide a list of nominations to the city commission, the city commission may appoint members to the historical development commission nominated from any other source. 
    If the members of the historical development commission are increased or decreased then the number of Chippewa County Historical Society, Inc. nominees shall increase or decrease in such a manner that the Chippewa County Historical Society, Inc. nominees shall always constitute a simple majority of the members. 
    Three (3) of the appointed seven (7) members shall be nominated and appointed solely by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1, (3-11.02), 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77; Ord. No. 465-02, 12-2-02) 
Sec. 2-105. - Compensation. 
    Members of the historical development commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1 (3-11.02), 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77) 
Sec. 2-106. - Removal of members; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  Members of the historical development commission may be removed from office by the city commission. 
(b)  Any vacancy on the historical development commission shall be filled by the city commission for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1 (3-11.02), 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77) 
Sec. 2-107. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The historical development commission shall have all the powers and duties vested or permitted to be vested in municipal historical commissions by Public Act 213 of 1957 [MCL § 399.171, MSA § 5.3395] and Act 33 of 1968 [MCL § 399.172, MSA § 5.3396] as heretofore or hereafter amended, and any laws heretofore or hereafter enacted which are related or supplemental thereto, it being the intention of this division to vest in the historical commission all powers and duties permitted by law, including advising the city commission and city manager on all phases of historical development and financing for said city, including the acquisition and disposal of historical buildings and sites and financing of such buildings and sites, and leasing of said sites, subject to the approval of the city commission and city manager. 
(b)  It shall be the function and duty of the historical development commission to study, investigate and survey the needs of the city in the development of historical sites, materials, and other related matters. It shall report its findings and recommendations to the city commission and the city manager. The historical development commission shall consider and devise plans for the use and development of lands and facilities now owned or to be acquired by the city for historical purposes, including plans for the financing thereof. In general, it shall be the duty of the historical development commission to make such studies and to submit such recommendations to the city commission and city manager from time to time as it shall deem necessary and desirable to carry out the purposes of this division. 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1 (3-11.03, 3-11.04), 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77) 
Sec. 2-108. - Establishment of regulations; contracting and hiring. 
    The city commission shall, from time to time, establish regulations for the guidance of the historical development commission, and the historical development commission shall not bind the city to any contract, or hire any employees, without the approval of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 66, § 1 (3-11.05, 3-3-69; Ord. No. 176, 1-3-77) 
Sec. 2-109. - Governor Chase S. Osborn Trust Fund spending recommendations. 
    The historical development commission shall annually as part of the city budget development process: (i) recommend to the city commission a list of projects to be funded from the annual proceeds distributed to the city from the Governor Chase S. Osborn Trust Fund. The historical development commission shall prior to such recommendation review and evaluate the projects recommended for funding, and (ii) prepare and submit the report required by subsection 2-107(b). 
(Ord. No. 465-02, 12-2-02) 
Secs. 2-110-2-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - LOCAL OFFICERS COMPENSATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-116. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to Act 8 of 1972 [MCL § 117.5c, MSA § 5.2084(3)], a local officers compensation commission is created, which shall determine the salaries of all local elected officials. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.01, 9-18-72) 
Sec. 2-117. - Composition; appointment. 
    The local officers compensation commission shall consist of five (5) members who are registered electors of the city, appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority of the members elected and serving on the city commission. The terms of office shall be five (5) years, except that of the members first appointed, one each shall be appointed for terms of one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), and five (5) years. All first members shall be appointed within thirty (30) days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section was derived. Thereafter, members shall be appointed before October 1 of the year of appointment. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.01, 9-18-72) 
Sec. 2-118. - Certain persons ineligible. 
    No member or employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of any level of government or members of the immediate family of such member or employee shall be eligible to be a member of the local officers compensation commission. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.01, 9-18-72) 
Sec. 2-119. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the local officers compensation commission shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.01, 9-18-72) 
Sec. 2-120. - Determination of salaries. 
    The local officers compensation commission shall determine the salaries of such local elected officials, which determination shall be the salaries unless the city commission by resolution adopted by two-thirds of the members elected to and serving on the city commission shall reject them. The determinations of the local officers compensation commission shall be effective thirty (30) days following their filing with the city clerk unless rejected by the city commission. In case of rejection, the existing salary shall prevail. Any expense allowance or reimbursement paid to elected officials in addition to salary shall be for expenses incurred in the course of city business and accounted for to the city. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.02, 9-18-72) 
Sec. 2-121. - Meetings; organization; compensation. 
    The local officers compensation commission shall meet for not more than fifteen (15) session days in 1972 and every odd-numbered year thereafter and shall make its determination within forty-five (45) calendar days of its first meeting. A majority of the members of such commission constitute a quorum for conducting its business. The local officers compensation commission shall take no action or make determination without a concurrence of a majority of the members appointed and serving on the commission. Such commission shall elect a chairman from among its members. "Session days" means any calendar day on which the commission meets and a quorum is present. The members of such commission shall receive no compensation, but shall be entitled to their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.03, 9-18-72) 
Sec. 2-122. - Changing of procedure to establish compensation of elected officials. 
    The procedure for establishing the compensation of elected officials may be changed by Charter amendment or revision. 
(Ord. No. 110, § 3-13.04, 9-18-72) 
Secs. 2-123-2-128. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - HOUSING COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-129. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to Public Act Number 18 of the Extra Session of 1933 [MCL § 125.651 et seq.], as amended, a commission is hereby created in and for the city to be known as the Sault Ste. Marie Housing Commission. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 1 (10-6.01), 7-5-61) 
Sec. 2-130. - Appointment; terms. 
    The city manager is hereby directed to appoint the members of the housing commission, with the consent and approval of the members of the city commission. Such housing commission shall consist of five (5) members, each of whose term of office shall be five (5) years. Members of the first housing commission shall be appointed for the terms of one (1) year, two (2) years, three (3) years, four (4) years, and five (5) years, respectively, and annually thereafter one member shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 1 (10-6.02), 7-5-61; Ord. No. 39, § 10-6.02, 5-2-66) 
Sec. 2-131. - Compensation. 
    Members of the housing commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 1 (10-6.02), 7-5-61; Ord. No. 39, § 10-6.02, 5-2-66) 
Sec. 2-132. - Removal of members; filling of vacancies. 
    Members of the housing commission may be removed from office by the city manager. Any vacancy in office shall be filled by the city manager for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 1 (10-6.02), 7-5-61; Ord. No. 39, § 10-6.02, 5-2-66) 
Sec. 2-133. - Powers and duties. 
    The housing commission shall have all the powers and duties vested or permitted to be vested in housing commissions by Public Act No. 18 of the Extra Session of 1933 [MCL § 125.651 et seq.], as heretofore or hereafter amended, and only laws heretofore or hereafter enacted which are supplemental thereto, it being the intention of this division to vest in the housing commission all powers and duties permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 1 (10-6.03), 7-5-61; Ord. No. 65, § 1 (10-6.03), 1-20-69) 
Sec. 2-134. - Hiring of employees. 
    The housing commission shall select and appoint such employees as it shall deem necessary for the proper exercise of its powers, functions and duties and shall pay them such compensation as it shall fix and determine. 
(Ord. No. 15, § 1 (10-6.03), 7-5-61; Ord. No. 484-05, 9-6-05) 
Secs. 2-135-2-140. - Reserved.
