ARTICLE IV. - PURCHASES 

Sec. 2-169. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Purchasing Ordinance of the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan." 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.01, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-170. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City purchasing agent or agent is the purchasing agent of the city. 
    Contractual services shall mean and include all telephone, gas, water, electric light and power service, towel and cleaning service; insurance; leases for all grounds, buildings, office or other space required by the using agencies; and the rental, repair or maintenance of equipment, machinery and other city-owned personal property. The term shall not include professional and other contractual services which by their nature are unique and not subject to competition. 
    Supplies, materials and equipment as used throughout this article shall mean any and all articles or things which shall be furnished to or used by any agency including all printing, binding or publication of stationery, forms, journals and reports. 
    Using agency means any department, agency, commission or other unit in the city government or a unit other than the city government making use of the city purchasing department using supplies or procuring contractual services as provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.02, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-171. - Establishment of office of purchases. 
    There is hereby established, as prescribed by section 4.6 of the Charter, the department of purchases and supplies, to be administered by a director of purchases and supplies, or purchasing agent, under the direction and control of the city manager as provided by the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.03, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-172. - City purchasing agent. 
(a)  Generally. The city purchasing agent shall be the head, and have general supervision of the office of the department of purchases and supplies. The agent shall perform all duties required of a department head by law and shall have the powers and duties prescribed by this article. 
(b)  Scope of purchasing authority. The agent shall have the powers and duties as follows: 
(1)  Purchase or contract. To purchase or contract for all supplies and contractual services required by any using agency in accordance with purchasing procedures as prescribed by this article and such rules and regulations as adopted by the purchasing procedural committee for the internal management and operation of the department of purchases and supplies. 
(2)  Unauthorized purchases. Except as herein provided, it shall be unlawful for any city officer or officers to order the purchase of any supplies or make any contract within the purview of this article other than through the department of purchases and supplies, and any purchase ordered or contract made contrary to the provisions hereof shall not be approved by the city officials, and the city shall not be bound thereby. 
(c)  Other powers and duties. In addition to the purchasing authority conferred above and in addition to any other powers and duties conferred by this article, the agent shall: 
(1)  Minimum expenditure. Act to procure for the city the highest quality in supplies and contractual services at the least expense to the city. 
(2)  Encourage competition. Discourage uniform bidding and endeavor to obtain as full and open competition as possible on all purchases and sales. 
(3)  Rules and regulations. The agent shall be responsible for the establishment and amendment when necessary, of all rules and regulations authorized by this article, the Charter, and any other ordinances pertaining to purchasing which have been or may be enacted. Such rules and regulations shall be established and amended by a purchasing procedural committee which shall be composed of the city manager, purchasing agent and finance officer and shall be in the form of a purchasing manual which shall be revised and updated to conform to changing conditions. 
(4)  Purchasing analysis. Keep informed of current developments in the field of purchasing, prices, market conditions and new products, and secure for the city the benefits of research done in the field of purchasing by other governmental jurisdictions, national technical societies, trade associations having national recognition, and by private businesses and organizations. 
(5)  Forms. Prescribe and maintain such forms as shall be reasonably necessary to the efficient and effective operation of a department of purchases and supplies. 
(6)  Vendors' catalog file. Prepare, adopt and maintain a vendors' catalog file or library. Such catalogs shall be filed, as nearly as may be, according to materials and shall contain if possible description of materials, vendors' commodities, prices and discounts. 
(7)  Bulk purchases. Explore and make use of the possibilities of buying "in bulk" so as to take full advantage of quantity discounts. The cooperative purchasing or purchasing for other governmental agencies or political subdivisions is to be encouraged and explored by the agent. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.04, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-173. - Capacity of agent. 
(a)  Generally. The agent shall enforce the written specifications adopted. 
(b)  Agent's duties. It shall be the duty of the agent: 
(1)  Classification. To classify all supplies used by the using agencies. 
(2)  Standardization. To adopt as standards the minimum number of qualities, sizes and varieties of supplies consistent with the successful operation of the city government. 
(3)  Specification. To prepare and adopt written specifications of all such standard supplies. 
(c)  Consultation with using agencies. The agent shall consult with the heads and other officials of the using agencies to determine their precise requirements and shall endeavor to prescribe those standards which meet the needs of the majority of such agencies. 
(d)  Nature of specifications. All specifications shall be definite and certain as nearly as may be, and shall permit of competition; provided, however, that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to noncompetitive types or kinds of supplies. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.05, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-174. - Requisitions and estimates. 
    All using agencies shall file with the purchasing agent, detailed estimates of their requirements in supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services in such manner, at such time, and for such future periods as the agent shall prescribe. This shall not prevent any using agency from filing with the purchasing agent at any time duly approved requisitions for supplies, equipment or commodities as required. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.06, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-175. - Encumbrance of funds. 
    Except in cases of emergency, the agent shall not issue any purchase order for delivery on a contract or open market purchase until the finance officer has certified that there are unencumbered funds to the credit of the using agency to defray the amount of such order. When the total cost requisitioned exceeds the amount the finance officer has been authorized to approve by the city manager, such requisition shall bear the approval of the city manager prior to the issuance of a purchase order. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.07, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-176. - Competitive bidding required. 
    All purchases of, and contracts for supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services, and all sales of personal property which has become excess or obsolete and unusable shall, except as specifically provided in this article, be based wherever possible and feasible on competitive bids. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.08, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-177. - Formal contract procedure. 
(a)  Generally. All supplies and contractual services, except as otherwise provided in this article and by the Charter, when the estimated cost thereof shall exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be purchased by formal, written contract from the lowest responsible bidder, after due notice inviting proposals. 
(b)  Notice inviting bids. Notice inviting bids shall be published at least once in an official publication of general circulation in the city and surrounding area at least five (5) days preceding the last day set for the receipt of proposals. At the discretion of the agent, notices may be published in publications of greater area circulation than the local paper. 
(1)  Scope of notice. The newspaper notice required in this subsection shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold, shall state where bid blanks and specifications may be secured, and the time and place for opening bids. 
(2)  Bidders list. The agent shall also solicit sealed bids from all responsible prospective suppliers who have requested their names to be added to a "bidders list" which the agent shall maintain, by sending them a copy of the notice which will acquaint them with the proposed purchase or sale. 
(c)  Bid deposits. When deemed necessary by the agent, bid deposits or surety in the form of check, cash or bond shall be made a part of the specifications. Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of surety upon awarding or rejection of bids. A successful bidder shall forfeit any surety required by the agent upon failure on his part to enter a contract within a reasonable length of time after the award. 
(d)  Bid opening procedure. 
(1)  Submittal. Sealed bids shall be submitted sealed to the purchasing agent and shall be identified as bids on the envelope. 
(2)  Opening. Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notice. 
(3)  Tabulation. The tabulation of all bids received shall be open to public inspection. 
(e)  Bid handling. The tabulation of the bids received along with the recommendation of the purchasing agent shall be submitted to the city manager, who shall submit such information with a recommendation to the city commission for commission action. 
(f)  Award of contract. The agent shall have the authority to award contracts under the section 2-177 limit and recommended to the city manager the awarding of contracts involving expenditures in excess of the section 2-177 limit with the purview of this article. 
(g)  Lowest responsible bidder. Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the "lowest responsible bidder," in addition to price, the agent shall consider: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
(2)  The time element; whether or not the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
(3)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(4)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(5)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service; 
(6)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. 
(h)  Award to other than low bidder. When the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the agent and filed with the other papers relating to the transaction. 
(i)  Tie bids. 
(1)  Local vendor. If all bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to the local bidder. 
(2)  Outside vendors. When subsection (i)(1) is not in effect, the agent shall award the contract to one of the bidders by publicly drawing lots. 
(j)  Performance bonds. The agent shall have the authority to require a performance bond, before entering a contract, in such amount as he shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the city. 
(k)  Prohibition against subdivision. No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.09, 5-24-71; Ord. No. 493-07, § 1, 7-2-07) 
Sec. 2-178. - Open market procedure. 
(a)  Generally. All purchases of supplies and contractual services, and all sales of personal property which has become obsolete and unusable, of less than the estimated value of the section 2-177 limit may be made in the open market, without newspaper advertisement and without observing the procedure described by section 2-177 for the award of formal contracts. 
(b)  Minimum number of bids. All open market purchases shall, whenever possible, be based on at least three (3) competitive bids, and shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder in accordance with the standards set forth in section 2-177(g). 
(c)  Bid invitations. The agent shall solicit bids from interviews with representatives, by telephone, direct mail or personal delivery to prospective vendors. 
(d)  Recording. The agent shall keep a record of all open market orders and the bids submitted thereon for a period of six (6) months, which records shall be open to public inspection. 
(e)  Rejection of bids. The agent shall have the authority to reject all bids, parts of all bids, or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract, when the best interest of the public will be served thereby. 
(f)  Source establishment by bid. The purchasing agent may establish sources of supply for various commodities, supplies or material by means of the procedures as set forth in this section even though the aggregate amount which may be purchased over a period of time may exceed the section 2-177 limit limitation for a single purchase. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.10, 5-24-71; Ord. No. 493-07, § 1, 7-2-07) 
Sec. 2-179. - Emergency purchases. 
    In case of actual emergency, and with the approval of the agent, a department head or duly authorized agent thereof may purchase directly any supplies whose immediate procurement is essential to prevent delays in the work of the using agency which may vitally affect the life and health or convenience of citizens. Such purchases shall be made in compliance with prescribed rules and regulations as set forth in the purchasing manual. Provided further that the amount does not exceed the section 2-177 for a single-limit purchase. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.11, 5-24-71; Ord. No. 493-07, § 1, 7-2-07) 
Sec. 2-180. - Inspection; tests. 
(a)  The agent shall have the authority to inspect, or cause to be inspected, all deliveries of purchases to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the order or contract. 
(b)  The agent shall have the authority to require chemical or physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformity with the specifications. In the performance of such tests, the agent shall have the authority to make use of laboratory facilities of any outside laboratory. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.12, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-181. - Surplus and obsolete stock. 
(a)  Generally. All using agencies shall submit to the agent, at such times and in such form as he shall prescribe, reports of stocks, supplies or equipment which are no longer used or which have become obsolete, worn out or scrapped. 
(b)  Sale. The agent shall have the authority to sell all supplies which have become unsuitable for public use, or to exchange the same for, or trade in the same on, new supplies. 
(1)  Competitive bidding. Sales of personal property, the value of which exceeds the section 2-177 limit, and all sales of real estate property shall be made to the highest responsible bidder in conformance with section 2-177. 
(2)  Open market procedure. Sales of personal property, the value of which does not exceed the section 2-177 limit may be made to the highest responsible bidder in conformance with section 2-178. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.13, 5-24-71; Ord. No. 493-07, § 1, 7-2-07) 
Sec. 2-182. - Cooperative purchasing. 
    The agent shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interest of the city would be served thereby. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.14, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-183. - Exceptions to competitive bidding. 
    Competitive bidding shall not be required for the following activities: 
(1)  Where the product or material contracted for is not competitive in nature and no advantage to the city would result from requiring competitive bidding or the city commission authorizes execution of a contract without competitive bidding as provided by section 12.1 of the Charter; 
(2)  The employment of professional services; 
(3)  When the department of purchases and supplies shall determine that the public interest will be best served by purchase from or joint purchase with another government unit; 
(4)  When the city elects to undertake the work itself, as provided by the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2-7.15, 5-24-71) 
Sec. 2-184. - Contract change orders. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to approve and sign change orders for all construction projects previously approved by the city commission if all of the following terms and conditions are met: 
(1)  The dollar amount of said change order shall not exceed ten (10) per cent of the original bid award on the entire construction project; provided, however, that in no event shall the change order amount exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); and 
(2)  Such change orders authorized by the city manager shall not exceed the funds budgeted for the particular construction project in question; and 
(3)  No contract or change order shall be subdivided for the purpose of circumventing the ten (10) per cent bid award limitation contained in this section. 
(Ord. No. 211-81, § 1, 1-19-81) 
Sec. 2-185. - Local bid adjustment and award. 
(a)  This section applies to purchases only. 
(b)  A city or county local bidder is defined as either a bidder who owns land in the city or the county; and upon such land its business is located; and who owned the land continuously for the twelve (12) months prior to the bid; and who is current on all obligations and property taxes owed to the city or the county as the case may be; and has paid in full any real property taxes which were due to the city or county in the twelve (12) months prior to making the bid. 
(c)  A city or county local bidder is defined as either a bidder who is a tenant under a fully signed written lease on land located in the city or the county; and upon such land its business is located; and which lease was in existence continuously for the twelve (12) months prior to the bid; and who is current on all obligations owed to the city or the county as the case may be. 
(d)  Any bid made by a local bidder as defined above shall be provided a competitive adjustment to their bid at the time of tabulation: 
If a city local bidder then equal to five (5) percent of the low bid amount not to exceed $10,000.00. 
If a county local bidder then equal to three (3) percent of the low bid not to exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(e)  The competitive adjustment for purposes of determining the award of the bid shall reduce the local bidder's bid artificially as means of determining if the award to the local bidder is in the best interest of the city. 
(f)  Lowest responsible bidder defined under subsection 2-177(g), and award to other than low bidder under subsection 2-177(h) shall include the competitive adjustment of this section in their application to the bid award decision. 
(g)  To receive the benefit of this section the local bidder shall agree to lower its bid at the time of bid award to match the actual bid submitted by the non-local bidder. 
(Ord. No. 502-08, § 1, 5-14-08; Ord. No. 511-09, § 1, 10-5-09; Ord. No. 517-10, § 1, 5-17-10; Ord. No. 563-15, § 1, 10-19-15) 
Secs. 2-186-2-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CODE OF ETHICS AND CONDUCT 

Sec. 2-300. - Preamble. 
    In keeping with the policies declared by the state legislature in enacting codes of ethics for state officials, it is recognized that high moral and ethical standards among city officials are equally essential to the conduct of local and state government; that a code of ethics for the guidance of city officials is necessary in order to prevent conflicts of interest in public office, improve standards of public service, and promote and strengthen the faith and confidence of the people of the city in their governing body. The ethics and conduct board will initially receive and process complaints or allegations of violations of the city code of ethics and conduct. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 1, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-301-2-309. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-310. - Code of ethics and conduct. 
    Definitions. No city officer shall violate the standards of conduct or procedural parameters as used in this article: 
(a)  City officer means an elected commissioner, mayor, employee of the city, or the members of the several boards and commissions created by or under the authority of the Sault Ste. Marie City Charter, Code, or applicable state law. 
(b)  Unethical conduct means a violation of the standards of conduct contained in this article. 
(c)  Incompatible offices means the standards of conduct prescribed by 1978 PA 566. 
(d)  Conflict of interest-Kinship means the contracting with an entity that is either wholly owned or that is controlled by and through a controlling interest by a person who is a member of the city officer's family as defined in City Charter subsection 5.14(a). 
(e)  Person means any business, individual, club, other organization, or group of individuals. 
(f)  Procurement means the buying, purchasing, renting, leasing, or otherwise acquiring of any supplies, services, or construction. It also includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any supply, service, or construction, including description of requirement, selection, and solicitation of sources, preparation and award of contract, and all phases of contract administration. 
(g)  Gratuity means an item of value in excess of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) such as: a payment, loan, subscription, advance, deposit of money, service, alcoholic beverages, or anything else of more than a twenty-five-dollar ($25.00) value, present or promised, unless consideration of substantially equal or greater value is received. 
(h)  Confidential information means any information which is available to a city officer only because of the city officer's status with the City of Sault Ste. Marie and is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request. 
(i)  Contract means all types of agreements, regardless of what they may be called, for the sale of city real or personal property, procurement of supplies, services, or construction. 
(j)  Contractor means any person having a contract with the city or an agency thereof. 
(k)  Services means the furnishing of labor, time, or effort by a contractor, not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than reports. This term shall not include employment agreements or collective-bargaining agreements. 
(l)  Direct participation means substantial involvement through decision, approval, disapproval, or preparation of any part of a purchase request, for the purposes of influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard. 
(m)  Non-employee means any person, not an officer or employee of the city, who is involved directly or indirectly, including through a third party, in the procurement process with the city. 
(n)  Conflict of interest-Employment/financial means a personal interest of such substance as to induce action on his or her part to promote the governmental decision or contract for his or her own personal benefit. 
(o)  Governmental decision means a determination, action, vote or disposition upon a motion, proposal, recommendation, resolution, ordinance, or measure on which a vote by a defined city officer of the public body is required, and by which the public body formulates or effectuates public policy. 
(p)  Minor violation means a violation of this article where the acts or omissions of the violator only: 
(1)  Meet the prohibitions of conduct contained in this article in a limited fashion; and 
(2)  Where there is only indirect benefit to the violator. 
(q)  Major violation means a violation of this article where the acts or omissions of the violator: 
(1)  Meet the expressed prohibitions of conduct contained in this article in a direct fashion; and 
(2)  Where there is direct benefit to the violator. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-311-2-314. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-315. - Standards of conduct. 
(a)  Disclosure of confidential information and city officer status activities within one year. It shall be unethical for a city officer to use or divulge to any person confidential information acquired in the course of city service in advance of the time prescribed for its authorized release to the public. No city officer shall, except as required in the performance of his duties, or in the course of any conduct reasonably believed to be in the performance of his duties, disclose confidential information gained by reason of his or her official position, nor shall he otherwise use the information for his personal interest. Confidential information shall include: 
(1)  Personnel information, applications, or any files maintained for city officers; 
(2)  Information required of any taxpayer or city license holder in connection with the assessment or collection of any tax or license fee if the disclosure of the information to other persons would violate the taxpayer or licensee's right to privacy; 
(3)  Specific intelligence information and specific investigative files compiled by investigative law enforcement and penology agencies and those state agencies vested with the responsibility to discipline members of any profession, the nondisclosure of which is essential to effective law enforcement or for the protection of any person's right to privacy. 
(4)  Information revealing the identity of persons who file complaints with investigative law enforcement or other government agencies except as the public disclosure laws may authorize; 
(5)  Test questions, scoring keys and other examination data used to administer license, employment or examination [license or employment examinations]; 
(6)  Preliminary drafts, notes, recommendations and intra-agency memorandums in which opinions are expressed or policies formulated or recommended, except that a specific record shall not be exempt when publicly cited by an agency in connection with any agency action; 
(7)  Records which are relevant to a controversy to which the city or any of its officers, employees or agents is a party and would not be available to another party under the rules of pretrial discovery for causes pending in the courts; 
(8)  Any other information as is declared confidential by other specific statutes; 
(9)  The confidential areas herein above listed shall be inapplicable to the extent that information, the disclosure of which would violate personal privacy or vital governmental interest, can be deleted from the specific records sought. 
To further the goal of maintaining confidences and preventing confidences from being used for personal gain, a person who was a city officer shall not, within one (1) year of his or her leaving the city office, be an employee of any entity who seeks a contract with the city without obtaining approval of the city commission. 
(b)  Use of city property. It shall be unethical for a city officer to use personnel resources, equipment, property, and funds under the officer's official care and control for personal gain or benefit unless used judiciously and solely in accordance with prescribed constitutional, statutory, and regulatory procedures. 
(c)  Gifts or loans. It shall be unethical for a city officer to solicit or accept a gift or loan of money, goods, services, or other thing of value for the benefit of a person or organization other than the city which tends to influence the manner in which the city officer or another city officer performs official duties. 
(d)  Personal profit. It shall be unethical for a city officer to engage in a business transaction in which the city officer may profit from his or her official position or authority or benefit financially from confidential information which the city officer has obtained or may obtain by reason of that position or authority. 
(e)  Gratuities. It shall be unethical for a city officer to accept a gratuity or an offer of employment in connection with a decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, or preparation of any part of a program requirement or a purchase request, influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard, rendering of advice, investigation, auditing, or in any other advisory capacity in any proceeding or application, request for ruling, determination, claim or controversy, or other particular matter, pertaining to any program requirement or a contract or subcontract, or to any solicitation or proposal therefore. 
(f)  Kickbacks. It shall be unethical for a city officer to be directly or indirectly involved in any payment, gratuity, or offer of employment to be made by or on behalf of a subcontractor under a contract to the prime contractor or higher tier subcontractor or any person associated therewith, as an inducement for the award of a subcontract or order. 
(g)  Incompatible employment. It shall be unethical for any city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in 1978 PA 566. 
(h)  Incompatible offices. It shall be unethical for any city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in 1978 PA 566. 
(i)  Incompatible kinship. It shall be unethical for any city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in subsection 2-310(d) described herein. 
(j)  Contract fixing. It shall be unethical for a city officer to participate in the negotiation or execution of contracts, making of loans, granting of subsidies, fixing of rates, issuance of permits or certificates, or other regulation or supervision relating to a business entity in which the city officer has a financial or unethical interest. 
(k)  Unethical hiring. It shall be unethical for a city officer to be hired, or to hire a person, to solicit or secure a city contract upon an agreement or understanding for a commission, per centage, brokerage, or contingent fee. 
(l)  Financial conflict of interest. It shall be unethical for a city officer to violate the standards of conduct prescribed in subsection 2-310(n) described herein. 
(m)  [Participation in decision making.] Before debate or a motion, proposal, recommendation, or resolution is made, a city officer shall not directly participate in a vote or debate regarding a governmental decision or a contract between the city and any of the following: 
(1)  Himself or herself or any family member as defined in City Charter section 5.14. 
(2)  A partnership, or limited liability company in which he or she (or any family member as defined in City Charter section 5.14.) is a partner, or member. 
(3)  Any corporation in which he or she (or any family member as defined in City Charter section 5.14.) is a stockholder owning more than ten (10) per cent of the total outstanding stock of any class if the stock is not listed on a stock exchange, or of which he or she is a director or officer. 
(4)  Any trust of which he or she (or any family member as defined in City Charter section 5.14.) is a beneficiary or trustee. 
(5)  An entity where the city officer has a financial interest as defined in City Charter section 5.14. 
(n)  Conduct of conduct of board, commission, and committee members (collectively called commission members). Commission members will hereafter conduct themselves according to the following rules of conduct as they pertain to work for and on behalf of the city: 
(1)  A commission member shall maintain decorum and set an example for conduct when the commission member represents the city, constituents, principals, or themselves personally. Commission members shall conduct themselves so as not to bring disgrace or embarrassment upon the city. Conduct such as name calling, yelling, screaming, use of fighting words, threatening retribution, or similar activity shall be prohibited. 
(2)  A commission member shall always represent that opinions stated are the member's own and do not necessarily represent those of the commission unless the commission has voted and passed an ordinance, resolution or motion that so states the expressed policy. 
(3)  If a commission member writes to a citizen, the member may use city stationery. However, the form and language must clearly state that opinions are those of the writer unless the commission has taken some official action. The commission member shall sign his/her name as "mayor," "mayor pro tem" or "commission member" as applicable. 
(4)  A commission member must obtain approval of the commission by motion to represent the city to any organization. 
(5)  A commission member must obtain approval of the commission by motion to attend any activity for which the city will pay for travel and other expenses. 
(6)  A commission member shall not divulge the discussions held in closed session until or unless the commission itself has made the discussions public. 
(7)  A commission member shall not make false statements on which the commission, city staff or other agencies rely to establish policy or make important decisions. A commission member violates this rule if he or she knows it is untrue, or if he or she has knowledge that would lead a reasonable person of ordinary prudence to conclude that the statement is untrue. 
(8)  A commission member shall not interfere with the city managers control of and relationship to city employees as protected by City Charter section 4.9. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Sec. 2-316. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-317. - Employee standards of citizen responses. 
(a)  Employees shall promptly respond to citizen request for assistance or inquiry. 
(b)  Employees are expected to respond as required by law to all requests of citizens for information under the State Freedom of Information Act. 
Secs. 2-318, 2-319. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-320. - Waiver by necessity. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b), a city officer shall be permitted to vote on, make, or participate in making a governmental decision if all of the following occur: 
(1)  The requisite quorum necessary for official action on the governmental decision by the entity of the city to which the city officer has been appointed is not available because the participation of the public officer in the official action violates this article. 
(2)  Without breaching legal requirements for nondisclosure, the city officer promptly discloses any personal, contractual, financial, business or employment interest he or she may have in the governmental decision and disclosure is made part of the public record of the official action on the governmental decision. 
(b)  If a governmental decision involves the awarding of a contract, a city officer shall be permitted to vote on, make, or participate in making the governmental decision on issues defined in this article herein if all of the following occur: 
(1)  All of the conditions of subsection (a) are fulfilled. 
(2)  The city officer will directly receive from the contract an amount less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-321-2-324. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-325. - Intent, public contracts. 
    This article is intended as a code of ethics and conduct for city officers and not as a rule of law for public contracts. 
    In the event of a conflict between this article and the city's purchasing ordinance, the provisions of the purchasing ordinance shall prevail. 
    This article does not prevent the issuance of a contract awarded to the lowest qualified bidder, upon receipt of bids pursuant to a notice for bids, and shall not preclude any person, firm, corporation, or trust from bidding. 
    A contract in respect to which a city officer acts in violation of this article shall not be considered to be void or voidable. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-326-2-324. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-335. - Notices of employee protections and obligations. 
    The city shall post notices and use other appropriate means to keep its employees informed of their obligation under this article. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-336-2-339. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-340. - Violation and penalties. 
    The following procedure will be implemented by an appointed ethics and conduct board consisting of three (3) people who are not city officers and who are appointed by the city commission under this section. The city clerk shall act as secretary for the board. Each member's term shall be for three (3) years. Members of the board shall be initially appointed for the terms of one (1), two (2), and three (3) years respectively. Annually thereafter one (1) member shall be appointed for a full three-year term. The rules of procedure for violations and penalties are as follows: 
(a)  Any officer who believes that another officer has violated this article shall submit a written statement of the purported violation to the secretary of the ethics and conduct board. 
(b)  The board shall review the violation to determine whether adequate reasons exist to bring formal charges. 
(c)  The board shall come to one of the following conclusions: 
1.  There is insufficient evidence to conclude that any particular violation has occurred. In this case, the board shall keep any records confidential. 
2.  The board concludes it is more likely than not that there has been a violation, in which case the board may call for full review by the city commission or the city manager if the complaint involves a city employee under the managers control under the charter. 
(d)  If the board concludes there may have been a violation, the city commission (or manager) shall classify the possible violation as major or minor. If the city commission (or manager) determines that a minor violation has occurred, it shall administer a censure. The violator may demand a public hearing for minor violations. A major violation shall result in a public hearing by the city commission (or manager). If before the city commission it shall select one of its members to present its findings at the hearing. The accused violator shall neither conduct the meeting during the hearing nor shall the member present the findings of the city commission. The city commission (or manager) shall give the accused violator adequate time to prepare a case and to present the case at the public hearing. Both the city commission (or manager) and accused member shall present their own cases but they may be accompanied by counsel during the proceedings. The city commission presenter (or manager) and the accused may present witnesses who shall present their evidence under oath. After hearing the evidence, the city commission (or manager) shall determine whether the purported violation was major, minor or whether there is insufficient evidence to determine that a violation occurred. if the city commission (or manager) determines that a violation occurred, they shall also establish a penalty commensurate with the violation as follows: 
1.  Oral or written warnings or reprimands; 
2.  Suspension of duties for specified periods of time; or 
3.  Termination of duties. 
The city commission may remove the violator from the positions of commissioner, mayor or mayor pro tem, if applicable, as part of the penalty if they deem it appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-341-2-344. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-345. - Recovery of value transferred or received in breach of ethical standards. 
(a)  General provisions. The value of anything transferred or received in breach of the ethical standards of this article by persons affected by this article may be recovered by and on behalf of the city for the sole benefit of the city. 
(b)  Recovery of kickbacks by the city. Upon a showing that a subcontractor made a kickback to a person affected by this article, to a prime contractor or a higher tier subcontractor in connection with the award of a subcontract or order thereunder, it shall be conclusively presumed that the amount thereof was included in the price of the subcontract or order and ultimately borne by the city and will be recoverable hereunder from the recipient. In addition, that amount may also be recovered from the subcontractor making such kickbacks. Recovery from one offending party shall not preclude recovery from other offending parties. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-346-2-349. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-350. - Severability, savings, repealer, sanctions. 
(a)  If any section, subsection, clause, phrase or portion of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion of this article, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(b)  All proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing, acquired or incurred at the time this article takes effect are saved and may be consummated according to the law in force when they are commenced. 
(c)  To the extent that violations of the ethical standards of conduct set forth in this article constitute violations of the Michigan Criminal Code or the City Charter they shall be punishable as provided therein. Such penalties shall be in addition to the civil sanctions set forth in this article. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  No provision contained herein shall be intended to restrict, preclude, hinder or otherwise impair the city officer from exercising any and all rights, duties, obligations or discretion bestowed upon them in the exercise and fulfillment of their official functions. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Secs. 2-351-2-354. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-355. - False charge-Violation. 
    Any person who files a false charge of misconduct on the part of any city officer when the person knows it is false shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 496-07, § 2, 9-4-07) 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Unlawful business advertising in connection with electrical work, § 8-45; businesses and business regulations, Ch. 9; signs, Ch. 20; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Posting of signs, advertisements and other matter. 
(a)  No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp, paste or otherwise affix any sign, advertisement or other matter upon any lamppost, electric light, railway, public utility pole, tree, fire hydrant or boxing covering it, or on any bridge, pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk, public building or any property or thing belonging to the city or located in the public streets, alleys, parks or other public places; provided that this shall not be construed to prevent any duly authorized public official from so doing for a public purpose. 
(b)  No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp, paste or otherwise affix any sign, advertisement or other matter upon any private house, wall, fence, gate, post or tree without first having obtained the written permission of the owner, agent or occupant of the premises. 
(c)  No person shall erect any sign in violation of this Code or any ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.06) 
State Law reference- Highway advertising act, MCL § 252.301 et seq., MSA § 9.391(101) et seq. 
Secs. 3-2-3-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISTRIBUTION OF HANDBILLS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Litter, Ch. 13, Art. III; nuisances, Ch. 18. 

Sec. 3-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Commercial handbill shall mean any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature: 
(1)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing; 
(2)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; 
(3)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided, nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place at any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this state, or under any ordinance of this city; or 
(4)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purpose, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Newspaper shall mean any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Noncommercial handbill shall mean any printed or written matter, or sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Private premises shall mean any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designated or used wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place shall mean any street, sidewalk, boulevard, alley or other public way and any public park, square, space, grounds or building. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
Sec. 3-17. - Throwing or distributing in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city; nor shall any person hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in any public place. 
Sec. 3-18. - Throwing on vacant private premises. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
Secs. 3-19, 3-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1B., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed §§ 3-19 and 3-20, which pertained to distributing at inhabited private premises and political, and derived from the 1978 codification of ordinances.

Chapter 5 - AIRPORT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate airports, § 2.3(s). 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; operation of snowmobiles at airports restricted, § 24-155. 

Sec. 5-1. - Obedience to laws, rules and regulations required. 
    No person shall violate any law of the United States or of the State of Michigan nor any applicable rule or regulation adopted by any duly authorized agency of the United States or the State of Michigan, pertaining to airport landing fields, airport managers and air traffic. 
(Code 1957, § 7-6.01) 
Sec. 5-2. - Trespassing prohibited. 
    No persons shall, without special permission in writing from the city manager or authorized representative, enter upon or drive or travel upon or cross any part of the Sault Ste. Marie Airport, or shall permit their horses, cattle or other animals to enter upon such airport, or shall occupy or use any portion of such airport. 
(Code 1957, § 7-6.02) 
Sec. 5-3. - Rules and regulations promulgated by city manager. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby empowered to make and promulgate rules and regulations governing the administration and management of the municipal airport. Any rule or regulation so made shall be in writing. 
(b)  A copy of each such rule or regulation shall be filed with the city clerk before the same is put into effect. The clerk shall present such rule or regulation to the city commission for its consideration not later than the next regular meeting of the commission after the filing of the same. No such rule or regulation shall remain in effect if disapproved by the city commission. 
(c)  No person shall violate any such rule or regulation promulgated in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1957, § 7-6.03)

Chapter 7 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animal noise constituting a nuisance, § 18-7(5); keeping of animal carcasses on public sidewalks prohibited, § 22-44. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Keeping when annoyance to neighborhood prohibited. 
    No person shall harbor or keep any animals, birds or insects which cause annoyance in the neighborhood, either by: 
(1)  Barking, howling, braying, crowing or making other sounds common to its species; or 
(2)  Failure of the owner, caretaker or custodian to maintain in a clean and sanitary condition, devoid of rodents and vermin, and free from objectionable odors, all structures, pens, coops, or yards wherein any animals, fowl or insects are kept; or 
(3)  Failure of the owner, caretaker or custodian to keep such animals confined on such owner's, caretaker's or custodian's premises; or 
(4)  In the case of insects, stinging or molesting any person. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.11) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 7-2. - Slaughter; licensing. 
(a)  No person shall kill or slaughter any animal to be used as food for human consumption except as otherwise permitted herein. 
(b)  No person shall maintain or operate any slaughterhouse, premises, place, room or shop where animals are killed or slaughtered except as otherwise permitted herein. 
(c)  Killing of fowls and rabbits for human consumption may be conducted after obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk in the manner provided in chapter 14. 
(d)  No such license will be issued except upon certification of the health officer to the effect that the premises are kept in a clean and sanitary manner consistent with health regulations and pure food laws in force in the city and in the state. 
(e)  No person shall burn any feathers, hides or other animal matter within the corporate limits of this city. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.12) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14; nuisances, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 7-3. - Disposition when sick or dead. 
(a)  No person shall place dead animals in rubbish or garbage containers. The owner of any dead horse, cow, dog, cat or other such large animal shall, within six (6) hours of the death of such animal, notify the department of public works of such death and secure the removal of the carcass. 
(b)  No person shall deposit, place or throw any dead or fatally sick or injured animal, or part thereof, on any public or private place, or into any reservoir or into, or on the banks of any stream, lake, pond, sewer, well or other body of water. 
(c)  No person shall carry or convey any dead animal through or upon any street, alley or public place unless the same is so covered that no part of it is exposed to view and no odors can emanate therefrom. 
(Code 1957, §§ 6-1.13, 7-4.05) 
Cross reference- Garbage and rubbish, Ch. 13, Art. II; nuisances, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 7-4. - Livestock prohibited in certain areas; permit required for other areas. 
(a)  No person shall keep or confine horses, cows, sheep, goats, pigs, hogs or chickens in any stable, barn, building or on any lot or premises, or otherwise, within that portion of the city bounded as follows: 
    Beginning at a point in the south shoreline of St. Mary's River which would be intersected by the west line of the SE1/4 of the NE1/4 of Sec. 17, T. 47 N., R. 1 W., thence south along said west line of SE1/4 of NE1/4 of Sec. 17, T. 47 N., R. 1 W., to the intersection of the center line of Bermuda Ave., thence easterly along the center line of Bermuda Ave. to the intersection of the center line of 20th Ave. W., thence easterly along the center line of 20th Ave. W. to the intersection of the center line of Sec. 16, T. 47 N., R. 1 W., thence northerly along said center line of Sec. 16 to the intersection of the center line of 16th Ave. W. extended, thence easterly along the center line of 16th Ave. W. extended and the established avenue to the intersection of the center line of 24th St. W., thence northerly along the center line of 24th St. W., to the intersection of the center line of 8th Ave. W. extended, thence easterly along said line to the intersection of a line parallel to and 150 feet east of 24th St. W., thence northerly along said line to the intersection of the center line of 5th Ave. W. extended, thence easterly along said line to the intersection of the center line of 22nd St. W., thence southerly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 6th Ave. W. extended, thence easterly along said line to the intersection of the center line of 20th St. W., thence southerly along said line to the intersection of the center line of 8th Ave. W. extended, thence easterly along said line to the intersection of the center line of 18th St. W., thence southerly along said line to the intersection of the center line of 10th Ave. W., thence easterly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 16th St. W., thence northerly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 8th Ave. W. extended, thence easterly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 8th St. W. extended, thence southerly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 24th Ave. as platted, thence easterly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of Young St., thence northerly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 12th Ave. E., thence easterly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 12th St. E., thence northerly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of Spruce St. E., thence easterly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of Mission Rd., thence northerly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of Riverside Dr., thence southeasterly along said center line to the intersection of the center line of 32nd Ave. E., thence easterly along said said boundary line to a point which would be the point of intersection of a line drawn from the point of beginning perpendicular to the international boundary line, thence southerly along said line perpendicular to the international boundary line to the point of beginning. 
(b)  No person shall keep or confine horses, cows, sheep, goats, pigs, hogs or chickens in any stable, barn, building or on any lot within the portion of the city lying outside of the area described in subsection (a) without first obtaining a permit therefor from the health department. Such permit shall extend for a period of time not exceeding one year as the health department shall determine and may be renewed annually or for such shorter periods as the health department shall determine. Upon application for such permit or renewal thereof being made, the health department shall cause an investigation to be made of the premises to be used for such purposes and the health department may issue such permit if it shall be determined by the health department that the premises are kept in a clean and sanitary manner consistent with health regulations and pure food laws in force in the city and state and that the keeping and confining of such animals shall not create a nuisance in the surrounding neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 280, § 1, 8-30-54) 
Secs. 7-5-7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL WELFARE AND CONTROL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, adopted Oct. 2, 1995, repealed §§ 7-16-7-21, 7-28-7-33, being the substantive sections of Art. II, Dogs, derived from the 1957 Code, § 6-1.14, and added §§ 7-26-7-31, 7-33-7-38, 7-51, 7-52, 7-76, 7-77, 7-80-7-82, to read as herein set out. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-26. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the "Animal Welfare and Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-27. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is declared to be as follows: 
(1)  To require the licensing of dogs. 
(2)  To provide regulations for the protection, control and maintenance of dogs and animals on public and private property within the city. 
(3)  To define and control dangerous animals. 
(4)  To establish a procedure for the removal or destruction of certain dangerous animals. 
Cross reference- Dangerous and exotic animals, § 7-76 et seq. 
(5)  To establish powers and duties of enforcement and implementation in certain city officers and employees. 
(6)  To provide for penalties and sanctions for violations hereof. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-28. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adequate shelter means a structure which, other than an opening for egress and ingress, is completely enclosed, creating a space within which is equal to the length of the animal in inches, as measured from the tip of the nose to the base of the tail, plus six (6) inches expressed in square feet, and creating ample height space. 
    Animal means any one (1) or more of a kingdom of living beings (except humans) differing from plants in capacity for spontaneous movement and rapid motor response to stimulation. 
    Animal control officer means any person designated by the city, county, or state to enforce the provisions of this article. 
    Dangerous animal means any animal determined dangerous by a court of competent jurisdiction under M.C.L.A. 287.321 et seq., or an animal defined in section 7-81 of this chapter. 
    Dog means a highly variable domestic mammal (Canis familiaris) closely related to the common wolf (Canis lupus). 
    Domestic animal means any of the various animals (as the horse or sheep) domesticated by humans so as to live and breed in a tame condition. 
    Exotic animals means, generally, the species of animals which are not native to the state or the United States and/or are introduced from another country. 
    Hybrid(s) means any animal which is the offspring of two (2) different varieties or species. 
    Owner or possessor means any person who has right of property in any animal, who has an animal in his care or custody, or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him. 
    Poisonous means a substance which, through its chemical action, usually kills, injures or substantially impairs an organism. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-29. - Dogs or cats running at large in a public place. 
    No dog or cat shall be permitted at any time to be on any road or street, in a public park, public building or any other public place, except that when held securely by a leash of suitable strength and length, by the owner thereof or any other responsible person. It is unlawful to allow any dog or cat to be removed from such a leash in such public places. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-30. - Owners permitting dogs or cats to run at large; collar and license token or tag required. 
(a)  No person owning, possessing or harboring a dog or cat shall permit same to run at large in the city. 
(b)  Dogs and cats at all times shall wear a substantial collar of leather, or other durable material, to which shall be securely attached a license issued by the County of Chippewa if the animal is a dog, or a tag identifying the owner of the animal if a cat. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-31. - Enforcement generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to promptly seize, take up and place in the pound all dogs and other animals, when necessary, that may be found running at large, or unlicensed, or if a cat not tagged as required under sections 7-30 and 7-51 of this chapter, or being kept or harbored any place within the city contrary to the provisions of this Code, city ordinances, state or federal laws. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-32. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-33. - Procedures for animal control officer. 
    The animal control officer is authorized, in his/her discretion, to issue a notice of violation to any person violating the terms of this article, or to file a sworn complaint at the district court. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-34. - Sanitation. 
(a)  Yards and exercise runs shall be kept free of dog and cat feces, uneaten food, and shall be maintained in a sanitary condition so as not to be a nuisance because of odor or attraction for flies or vermin. 
(b)  No owner or possessor of a dog or cat shall cause, suffer, or allow it to defecate upon any public or private property without the permission of the owner of such property unless the person owner or possessor shall immediately remove all feces by a sanitary method. The owner or possessor shall possess a container of sufficient size to collect and remove such feces, and shall exhibit such container if requested by any animal control officer. The collected feces shall be disposed of only upon the property of the owner or possessor of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-35. - Keeping when disturbing others. 
    No person owning or possessing a dog or cat shall permit it to bark, meow, yelp, or howl often enough or loud enough to constitute a disturbance to any occupiers of any land or building. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-36. - Location of pens, cages. 
    No person owning, possessing, or harboring a dog or other domesticated animal shall permit such dog or other domesticated animal to be harbored, housed, penned, caged or kept within fifteen (15) feet of any occupied building or structure located upon premises not owned or under control of such owner, possessor or harborer of any dog or domesticated animal, nor within five (5) feet of any lot line (as defined in the city zoning ordinances, as amended) of property owned or under the control of such owner, possessor or harborer of any dog or domesticated animal. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-37. - Quarantine of biting animals. 
    Whenever any animal bites a person, the owner or possessor of such animal shall immediately notify the animal control officer within the first twenty-four (24) hours of the bite and make themselves readily available to the animal control officer. The officer shall order the animal held on the owner's premises or shall have it impounded, at the discretion of the animal control officer, for a period of ten (10) days. The animal shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of such ten-day period. If a veterinarian is convinced that the animal is free of rabies, the animal shall be released from quarantine or from the pound as the case may be. If the dog dies in the meanwhile, its head shall be sent to the state department of health for examination and determination of rabies. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-38. - Kennel prohibited. 
    No person shall keep, maintain or possess more than: (i) a total of four (4) dogs, or (ii) a total of four (4) cats, or (iii) a combination of four (4) dogs and cats, four (4) months or more in age in any area of the city that is classified or zoned as R-1, R-1A, R-2, RM-1, RM-2, or RM-3. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-39. - Waterfowl. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Waterfowl as used in this section shall include all species of ducks and geese. 
    Feed as used in this section shall include every method whereby any person shall place food, garbage, food scraps, fruits, nuts, honey, vegetables, any food or animal byproducts, wheat, corn, meal, grain, sorghum, alfalfa, lard, grease or any animal rendering, or any other substance of any type out of doors, or inside any structure, whether in a container or otherwise, where such substance is accessible to or used by any animal as a source of food or nourishment. 
(b)  Prohibited conduct. It shall be unlawful for any person to feed any waterfowl in any area in the City of Sault Ste. Marie. This prohibition shall not apply to the feeding of songbirds or squirrels, so long as the food placed for these creatures is not accessible to or consumed by any waterfowl. 
(Ord. No. 443-00, 4-17-00) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 443-00, adopted Apr. 17, 2000, enacted provisions which pertained to waterfowl. Such provisions, designated as §§ 7-39 and 7-40 were redesignated by the editor as § 7-39 (a) and (b) for purposes of classification. 
Secs. 7-40-7-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DOG LICENSE AND CAT IDENTIFICATION TAG 

Sec. 7-51. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess or harbor a dog or cat four (4) months of age or over in the city without first having obtained, if a dog a license therefor, or if a cat a tag identifying the owner of the cat as herein provided. In either case the license or tag shall be affixed to a collar which collar shall be placed around the animals neck at all times when the animal is outside the dwelling of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95; Ord. No. 444-00, § 1, 4-17-00) 
Sec. 7-52. - Application. 
    Licenses to own or harbor a dog shall be issued by the County of Chippewa upon application made therefor, together with payment of the license fee provided. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Secs. 7-53-7-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DANGEROUS AND EXOTIC ANIMALS 

Sec. 7-76. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are declared to be as follows: 
(1)  To identify and enumerate certain animals, which, by their nature, are sufficiently dangerous, undesirable or unsuitable for incorporation into the residential, agricultural or commercial life of this community. 
(2)  To impose prohibitory measures to discourage and ban the possession and maintenance of animals considered as exotic and not easily domesticated. 
(3)  To establish guidelines and procedures to be utilized by animal control personnel in implementing this article. 
(4)  To provide for penalties and sanctions for violations hereof. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-77. - Legislative classification and findings. 
(a)  With the increasing urbanization and population density of the city, the residents of the city must be protected from the attack and threat of injury or disease from certain exotic animals possessed or maintained as domestic animals. 
(b)  This article is enacted following the passage of Act 381 of the Public Acts of 1988 (MCL 750.49, MSA 28.244) by the state legislature which provides for substantial penalties to be imposed against persons who promote the possession or use of dogs bred for fighting or baiting. 
(c)  This article is enacted following the passage of Act 426 of the Public Acts of 1988 (MCL 287.321 et seq., MSA 12.545(21) et seq.) by the Michigan Legislature which provides for additional penalties and procedures for the protection against dangerous animals. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Secs. 7-78, 7-79. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-80. - Minimum requirements for keeping dangerous animal. 
(a)  At all time when such animal is outside of any enclosed structure, fenced yard or fenced running area, the animal shall: 
(1)  Be under the control of a person over the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(2)  Be held securely by a leash of adequate strength to restrain the animal. 
(3)  Have a muzzle over its jaws sufficient to prevent the animal from inflicting any bite upon another person or animal. 
(c)  All properties where the animal is kept, harbored or possessed shall at all times be insured with public liability insurance for bodily injury and property damage by such animal in an amount no less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) coverage. Proof of such insurance shall be submitted to the city clerk upon demand. 
(d)  Pens or structures utilized for harboring or keeping such animal, if a dog, outside of a habitable structure shall be a minimum of five (5) feet wide, ten (10) feet long, five (5) feet in height above grade. The pen must not share common fencing with the area or perimeter fence of the property. The pen must have secure sides, and a secure top attached to all sides. All to be constructed with at least 12-gauge (heavier if necessary to contain animal) chain link fencing with necessary steel supporting posts. The sides must be either buried two (2) feet into the ground, wired or otherwise securely attached to a continuous floor of chain link fencing material, or adequately secured to a concrete pad. The pen must be securely locked with a key or combination lock when the dog is within the pen. All pens erected to satisfy this section must also comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city. All pens must be kept clean and in a sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-81. - Prohibited exotic, rare or dangerous animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person to possess or maintain within the city the following animals: 
(1)  All animals, including snakes, whose bite or venom is poisonous or deadly to humans. 
(2)  Apes: Chimpanzees (Pan); gibbons (Hylobates); gorillas (Gorilla); orangutans (pongo); and siamangs (Symphalangus). 
(3)  Baboons (Papoi, Mandrillus). 
(4)  Bears (Ursidae). 
(5)  Cheetahs (Acinonyx jubatus). 
(6)  Crocodilians (Crocodilus), and alligators. 
(7)  Constrictor snakes if longer than eight (8) feet or if weighing more than forty (40) pounds, or other poisonous reptiles. 
(8)  Coyotes (Canis latrans). 
(9)  Elephants (Elephas and Loxondonta). 
(10)  Gamecocks and other fighting birds. 
(11)  Hyenas (Hyaenidae). 
(12)  Jaguars (Panthera onca). 
(13)  Leopards (Panthera pardus). 
(14)  Lions (Panthera leo). 
(15)  Lynex (Lynx). 
(16)  Ostriches (Sruthio). 
(17)  Pumas (Felis concolor); also known as cougars, mountain lions and panthers. 
(18)  Wolves (Canis lupus). 
(19)  Wolf hybrids. 
(20)  Raccoons (Procyon lotor). 
(21)  Skunks (Genus Mephitis). 
(22)  Tigers (Felis tigris). 
(b)  The prohibitions above shall not apply to pet shops licensed by the state department of agriculture, zoological gardens licensed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and accredited by the American Association for the Accreditation of Zoological Parks and Gardens, and circuses licensed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture or schools keeping such animal for educational purposes if: 
(1)  Their location conforms to the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(2)  All animals and animal quarters are kept in a clean and sanitary condition and so maintained as to eliminate objectionable odors. 
(3)  Animals are maintained in quarters so constructed as to prevent their escape, and so as to humanely provide for their biological and social needs. 
(4)  No person lives or resides within one hundred (100) feet of the quarters in which the animals are kept. 
(c)  The prohibitions above shall not apply to any person who is in possession of an injured animal listed in this section under a valid care giver's permit issued by the state department of natural resources. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95) 
Sec. 7-82. - Destruction or removal of prohibited animals. 
(a)  Upon a sworn complaint that an animal is a dangerous animal or one of the species of exotic or other animal prohibited by this article, and is currently being illegally possessed or maintained, a district court or district court magistrate shall issue a summons to the owner ordering him to appear to show cause why the animal should not be destroyed or removed from the city. 
(b)  Upon the filing of a sworn complaint as provided herein, the court or magistrate may order the owner or possessor to immediately turn the animal over to the animal control officer, an incorporated humane society, a licensed veterinarian, or a boarding kennel, at the owner's option, to be retained by them until a hearing is held and a decision is made for the disposition of the animal. The expense of the boarding and retention of the prohibited animal is to be borne by the owner. After a hearing, the magistrate or court shall issue its findings and opinion as to whether the animal is subject to destruction or removal under this article. If so, the court shall order the destruction of the animal at the expense of the owner, or, in the alternative, at the court's discretion, order the animal removed from the city under terms and conditions which ensure such removal. 
(c)  Illegally possessed and/or maintained animals who reasonably appear to have become a dangerous animal, are subject to immediate seizure or pickup under this article. The impounded animal shall be held at a facility designated by the animal control officer, at the owner's expense. The complaining witness shall promptly comply with the complaint requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 397-95, § 1, 10-2-95)
