ARTICLE VIII. - REGISTRY OF OWNERS AND PREMISES 

Sec. 8-190. - Definitions. 
    Certain words in this article are defined for the purposes thereof as follows: Words used in the present tense include the future; words in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter; the singular number includes the plural and the plural the singular. 
(1)  Dwelling. A "dwelling" is any house, building, structure, shelter, or portion thereof, (except railroad cars, on tracks or rights-of-way) which is occupied in whole or in part as the home, residence, living or sleeping place of one (1) or more human beings, either permanently or transiently. A house trailer or other vehicle, when occupied or used as a dwelling, shall be subject to all the provisions of this act, except that house trailers or other vehicles, duly licensed as vehicles, may be occupied or used as a dwelling, without being otherwise subject to the provisions of this act for dwellings, when located in a park or place designated or licensed for the purpose by the city; provided, that such parking sites are equipped with adequate sanitary facilities. 
(2)  Classes of multiple dwellings. All "multiple dwellings" are dwellings and for the purpose of this act are divided into 3 classes, being: class a, class b, and class c. 
Class a. Multiple dwellings of "class a" are dwellings which are occupied more or less permanently for residence purposes and in which the rooms are occupied singularly, in apartments, suites, or groups; in which each room or combination of rooms is so arranged and designed as to provide for cooking accommodations, toilet, and kitchen sink accommodations within the separate units. This class includes tenement houses, flats, apartment houses, bachelor apartments, studio apartments, duplex apartments, kitchenette apartments, and all other dwellings similarly occupied whether specifically enumerated herein or not. 
Class b. Multiple dwellings of "class b" are dwellings which are occupied, as a rule transiently, as the temporary abiding place of individuals who are lodged, with or without meals, and in which as a rule the rooms are occupied singularly and without any attempt to provide therein or therewith cooking or kitchen accommodations for the individual occupants. This class includes hotels, motels, clubhouses, hospitals, jails and all other dwellings similarly occupied, whether specifically enumerated herein or not. 
Class c. Multiple dwellings of "class c" are dwellings which are occupied more or less permanently for residence purposes and in which the rooms are occupied singularly, in apartments, suites, or groups, and where the dwelling is designed to provide for cooking accommodations, toilet, and kitchen sink accommodations outside of the separate rooms or units. This class includes fraternities, sororities, apartment hotels, nursing facilities, and other communal residence houses, and all other dwellings similarly occupied whether specifically enumerated herein or not. 
(3)  Rooming house. A "rooming house" is any owner-occupied single-family dwelling occupied as the owner's home, and occupied in such a manner that certain rooms, in excess of those used by the members of the owner's immediate family, are leased or rented to persons outside of the family, with or without any attempt to provide therein or therewith, cooking or kitchen accommodations for individuals leasing or renting rooms. 
(4)  Bed and breakfast houses. A "bed and breakfast" is a single-family residential structure that meets all of the following criteria: 
a.  Has ten (10) or fewer sleeping rooms, including sleeping rooms occupied by the innkeeper, one (1) or more of which are available for rent to transient tenants. 
b.  Serves meals at no extra cost to its transient tenants. 
(5)  Agent. "Agent" means a person who has charge, care, control, or management of a dwelling. 
(6)  Owner. "Owner" means a person who has a legal or equitable interest in a dwelling, regardless of whether the person has possession of the dwelling. Owner includes an executor, administrator, trustee, or guardian of the estate of an owner of a dwelling. 
(7)  Residential rental property. "Residential rental property" means any dwelling, or multiple dwelling of class a or class c, the right to possession of which has been transferred for residence, living, or sleeping purposes by one (1) of the following methods: (i) leased, let, or rented, (ii) sold under the terms of a land contract which has not been recorded with the Chippewa County Register of Deeds. 
Residential rental property does not include: 
a.  Rooming houses; 
b.  Multiple dwellings of class b; 
c.  Bed and breakfast houses; 
d.  Reserved. 
e.  A multiple dwelling of class a or class c used for students attending a state licensed or state chartered college or university when the property is owned by the college or university. 
f.  A dwelling operated or licensed by the state or the federal government. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98; Ord. No. 591-19, § 1, 4-15-19) 
Sec. 8-191. - Required. 
    Owners shall separately register each residential rental property. 
    A registry of owners, agents and residential rental property shall be maintained by the building inspection department. Such registry will be kept as a public record and shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 8-192. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person failing to register on or before February 15 of each year, as required by this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punishable as defined in section 1-6 of the Code. Each day that a person fails to register shall be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 8-193. - Data generally, change of status. 
    The owner of each residential rental property shall register the owner's name, business addresses, the location of the dwelling and the number of dwelling units or rooming units located in such dwelling to be offered to let. Such additional information as the city manager shall request shall be provided at the time of registration. The manager shall publish the form of such request. 
    Persons becoming owners of residential rental property after February 15 each year shall register within forty-five (45) days of such event. 
    Property which becomes residential rental property after February 15 each year shall be registered within forty-five (45) days of such event. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 8-194. - Agent authority and information. 
    For all residential rental property registered, an agent shall be named. The agent shall be a natural person. The agent's name and address shall be placed with the name of the owner in the registry. The agent shall be a resident of Chippewa County. The agent shall endorse the registration for the purposes of accepting the responsibility imposed upon the agent by this article. The agent shall be authorized to act for the owner in all matters relating to the City Code and the residential rental property. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 8-195. - Agent for service of process. 
    The agent shall be eligible and authorized to receive all notices and services of process under the laws of the State of Michigan, City Code and Charter and shall be competent to receive the same on behalf of the owner. Service upon the agent may be made by first class mail sent to the agent's address as listed upon the registration. Service upon the agent shall constitute service upon the owner. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 8-196. - Corporate and other legal entity ownership. 
    If the owner is any form of limited partnership, corporation, association, partnership, limited liability company or other legal entity then the names and addresses of its officers or members shall be listed upon the registry. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Sec. 8-197. - Change of address. 
    Any change of address of owner or agent shall be noted in the registry. Agents and owners shall notify the city in writing within ten (10) days of any such change in address. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98) 
Secs. 8-198, 8-199. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-200. - Fees and deadlines for registration. 
    The registration shall be made annually before February 15th of each year. The fee charged for timely registration shall be set by resolution of the city commission. A fee as set by resolution shall be assessed for registrations received up to forty-five (45) days late. A fee as set by resolution shall be assessed for registrations received more than forty-five (45) days late. 
(Ord. No. 438-98, § 1, 12-21-98; Ord. No. 534-12, § 1, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 8-201. - Educational checklist to be certified by owner annually. 
(a)  The city shall send annually to each registered owner a checklist of minimum property maintenance code requirements. The checklist must be signed by the owner or agent and returned to the city within the time prescribed by the inspection department for its return. The owner's execution of the checklist and its return to the city shall be a certification by the owner to the city that all the individual rental units covered by the rental registration meet the requirements of the minimum property maintenance code requirements at the time of the certification. If an inspection by the city subsequent to the owner's certification of compliance with the checklist reveals the property is not in compliance with the checklist then the property shall be subject to an inspection fee as determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(b)  Timely return of the checklist certification does not preclude city inspection nor citing of violations under the entire Chapter 8 Property Maintenance Code or other provisions of the City Code. 
(c)  The city commission by resolution shall set the fee for an owner's failure to return the checklist certified by the owner within the time prescribed for its return to the city. 
(d)  If the owner fails to return the checklist certified within the time prescribed for its return to the city then the city may request an inspection of the individual rental units and common areas. If the owner refuses the city's request for an inspection then the city may apply for a search warrant and such refusal shall be a presumption that the individual units do not comply with the City Code requirements. The city commission shall set a fee for the application for the search warrant. 
(e)  All fees set by this section are enforceable as a lien against the property under section 10.9 of the City Charter and section 21.76 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 534-12, § 1, 12-3-12)

ARTICLE II. - JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Junk, Ch. 13, Art. IV. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Automobile graveyard means any establishment or place of business which is maintained, used or operated for storing, keeping, buying or selling wrecked, scrapped, ruined or dismantled motor vehicles or motor vehicle parts. 
    Junk means old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash, rubber debris, waste, or junked, dismantled or wrecked automobiles, or parts of automobiles, iron, steel and other old or scrap ferrous or nonferrous material. 
    Junkyard means an establishment or place of business which is maintained, operated or used for storing, keeping, buying or selling junk, or for the maintenance or operation of an automobile graveyard, including garbage dumps and sanitary fills. 
    Public street or alley means a street or alley as designated or platted, or used as such, or as may hereafter be so designated, platted or used. 
(Code 1957, § 9-11.01; Ord. No. 44, § 9-11.09, 9-12-66) 
Secs. 9-17-9-22. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - JUNK DEALERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing and regulation of junk dealers, MCL §§ 445.401 et seq., 445.471 et seq. 

Sec. 9-23. - Adoption of state law. 
    All statutes of the state and specifically Sections I to VII of Act No. 350 of the Public Acts of 1917 [MCL § 445.401 et seq.] and Sections I and II of Act No. 231 of the Public Acts of 1945 [MCL § 445.471 et seq.], relating to secondhand dealers and junk dealers are hereby expressly incorporated into and made a part of this division, and no person shall violate any such law, rule or regulation. 
(Code 1957, § 9-11.03) 
Sec. 9-24. - License required. 
    No person shall carry on the business of a secondhand dealer or junk dealer without having first obtained a license from the city clerk in the manner provided in chapter 14 and in the statutes of the state pertaining to secondhand dealers and junk dealers, and paying the fee therefor as provided in section 14-6. 
(Code 1957, § 9-11.02) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 9-25. - Pawning and security transactions prohibited. 
    No licensee under this division shall receive in the course of such business any article by way of pledge or pawn nor shall such licensee loan or advance any sum of money on the security of any article or thing. 
(Code 1957, § 9-11.04) 
Sec. 9-26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 578-18, adopted Apr. 2, 2018, repealed § 9-26, which pertained to loitering by minors, and derived from the 1957 Code. 
Sec. 9-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 578-18, adopted Apr. 2, 2018, repealed § 9-27, which pertained to hours of operation, and derived from the 1957 Code. 
Sec. 9-28. - Records. 
    A licensee under this division shall keep in a separate book, open for inspection to any public officer, a written record showing the time of purchase of each article purchased by such licensee, a brief description of such article, and the name, description and residence of the person from whom such article was purchased or received. 
(Code 1957, § 9-11.07) 
Sec. 9-29. - Retention of articles. 
    Articles purchased by a junk dealer shall, except in time of war, be retained by the junk dealer purchasing the same in an accessible place for at least fifteen (15) days where such articles can be examined and inspected before such articles are disposed of. 
(Code 1957, § 9-11.08) 
Secs. 9-30-9-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - JUNKYARDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Junkyards near highways, MCL § 252.201 et seq. 

Sec. 9-36. - Public policy. 
    In order to promote the public safety, health, welfare, convenience and enjoyment of public travel, to protect the public investment in public streets and alleys, to preserve and enhance the scenic beauty of lands bordering public streets and alleys, to attract tourists and promote prosperity, economic well-being and general welfare of the city, and to provide an ordinance for controlling junkyards consistent with the public policy declared by Congress in Title 23 of the United States Code (and Michigan Public Act 219 of 1966 [MCL § 252.201 et seq.]), it is declared to be in the public interest to regulate and restrict the establishment, operation and maintenance of junkyards in areas adjacent to public streets or alleys within this city. All junkyards which do not conform to the requirements of this division are public nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 9-11.10, 9-2-66) 
Sec. 9-37. - Prohibited near public rights-of-way; exception. 
    Except as provided by section 9-38, no person shall establish, expand or maintain a junkyard, any portion of which is within five hundred (500) feet of the nearest edge of the right-of-way of any public street or alley, except the following: 
(1)  Those which are screened by natural objects, plantings, fences or other appropriate means so as not to be visible from the main-traveled way of the streets or alleys, or otherwise removed from sight, in accordance with rules and regulations of the city; 
(2)  Those located within areas which are zoned for industrial use under authority of law, provided proper screening is maintained; 
(3)  Those which are not visible from the main-traveled way of public streets or alleys. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 9-11.11, 9-12-66) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 9-38. - Removal by city; cost to property owner. 
    Any junkyard which does not conform to the requirements for exception in section 9-37 shall be screened or removed by the city as a cost to the property of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 9-11.12, 9-12-66) 
Cross reference- Single lot procedure for special assessments, Ch. 21, Art. V. 
Sec. 9-39. - Violation; penalty. 
    If a junkyard is established, expanded or maintained not in conformity with the provisions of section 9-37, the city may apply to a court of proper jurisdiction to compel conformity with this division. In addition, any person who establishes, expands or maintains a junkyard in violation of this division shall be punished according to section 1-6. Each day that a violation of this division occurs shall be considered to be a separate violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 44, § 9-11.15, 9-12-66) 
Secs. 9-40-9-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- noise in hawking goods constituting a nuisance, § 18-7(4). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-46. - Definitions. 
    The word "peddler" as used in this article shall include any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers; or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance; or who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers. The word "peddler" shall include the word "hawker" or "huckster." 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.01) 
Sec. 9-47. - Duty of police to enforce. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce a peddler's license and to enforce the provisions of this section against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.10) 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 19. 
Sec. 9-48. - Use of streets. 
    Peddlers shall not have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall they be permitted a stationary location, nor shall they be permitted to operate in any congested area where their operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this article, the judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.08) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 9-49. - Records of violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the city clerk all convictions for a violation of this article. The city clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of violation thereon. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.11) 
Secs. 9-50-9-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 9-56. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.02) 
Sec. 9-57. - Application. 
    Applicants for a license under this division must file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Address, legal and local; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold and in the case of products of farm or orchard, whether produced or grown by the applicant; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of same, together with license number or other means of identification; 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of the county, who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of the names of references, any other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(10)  Applicant shall file with the application a statement by a reputable physician of the city, dated not more than ten (10) days prior to submission of the application, certifying the applicant to be free of infectious, contagious or communicable disease; 
(11)  At the time of filing the application, a fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.03) 
Sec. 9-58. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as the chief deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  If as a result of such investigation the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application such disapproval and the reasons for the same, and return such application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that the application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. 
(c)  If as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application such approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return such permit, along with the application, to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, deliver to the applicant the permit and issue a license. Such license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of such licensee, the class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such peddling. The clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.04) 
Sec. 9-59. - Fees. 
(a)  Licensees under this division shall pay the fees as prescribed in section 14-6. No fee shall be required of one selling meat, poultry, fish, domestic fruits, dairy, farm or garden produce raised or produced by the seller. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section any period of seven (7) calendar days or less shall be considered one week; any period of more than seven (7) calendar days and not more than thirty (30) calendar days shall be considered one month; any period of more than thirty (30) calendar days and not more than one calendar year shall be treated as a year. The annual fees herein provided for shall be assessed on a calendar year basis and on and after November first the amount of the fee for such annual licenses shall be one-half the amount stipulated for the remainder of the year. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.05) 
Sec. 9-60. - Plates and badges. 
    The city clerk shall issue to each licensee under this division at the time of delivery of the license two (2) license plates for each vehicle to be used, plus a metal badge for each individual licensed under this division. The license plates or badges shall bear the words "Licensed Peddler," the period for which the license is issued and the number of the license in letters and figures plainly discernable. License plates shall be attached to the vehicle used by the licensee, either on both sides or on the front and rear of the vehicle so used. Such badge shall be worn constantly by the licensee on the front of such licensee's hat or outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous during such time as such licensee is engaged in peddling. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.06) 
Sec. 9-61. - Transfer. 
    No license or badge issued under the provisions of this division shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.07) 
Sec. 9-62. - Exhibition. 
    Peddlers shall exhibit their licenses at the request of any citizen. 
(Code 1957, § 9-3.09) 
Secs. 9-63-9-73. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-74. - Defined. 
    A canvasser or solicitor is defined for the purposes of this article as any individual, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not, provided that such definition shall include any person who, for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop, or any other place within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.01) 
Sec. 9-75. - Duty of police to enforce article. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen soliciting or canvassing, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce a solicitor's or canvasser's license and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.09) 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 19. 
Sec. 9-76. - Records of article violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the city clerk all convictions for violation of this article. The city clerk shall maintain a record for each license issued and record the reports of violation thereon. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.10) 
Secs. 9-77-9-82. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 9-83. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or canvasser to engage in such business within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.02) 
Sec. 9-84. - Application. 
    Applicants for a license under this division must file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery; 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of the county, who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of the names of references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(10)  A statement by a reputable physician of the city dated not more than ten (10) days prior to submission of the application, certifying the applicant to be free of contagious, infectious or communicable disease; 
(11)  At the time of filing the application, a fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated therein. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.03) 
Sec. 9-85. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as the chief deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  If as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application such disapproval and the reasons for the same, and return such application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that such application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. 
(c)  If as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application such approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return such permit, along with the application, to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, deliver to the applicant such permit and issue a license. Such license shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address, and photograph of such licensee, the class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance, and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such soliciting or canvassing. The clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.04) 
Sec. 9-86. - Fees. 
(a)  The license fee which shall be charged by the city clerk for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 14-6. 
(b)  The annual fees herein provided shall be assessed on a calendar year basis and on or after November first the amount of such fee for annual license shall be one-half the amount stipulated above for the remainder of the year. 
(c)  None of the license fees provided for by this section shall be so applied as to occasion an undue burden upon interstate commerce. In any case where a license fee is believed by a licensee or applicant for license to place an undue burden upon such commerce, such applicant may apply to the city manager for an adjustment of the fee so that it shall not be discriminatory, unreasonable or unfair as to such commerce. Such application may be made before, at or within six (6) months after payment of the prescribed license fee. The applicant shall, by affidavit and supporting testimony, show such applicant's method of business and the gross volume or estimated gross volume of business and such other information as the city manager may deem necessary in order to determine the extent, if any, of such undue burden on such commerce. The city manager shall then conduct an investigation, comparing applicant's business with other businesses of like nature and shall make findings of fact from which the city manager shall determine whether the fee fixed by this section is unfair, unreasonable or discriminatory as to the applicant's business and shall fix as the license fee for the applicant, an amount that is fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory, or, if the fee has already been paid, shall order a refund of the amount over and above the fee so fixed. In fixing the fee to be charged, the city manager shall have the power to base the fee upon a percentage of gross sales, or any other method which will assure that the fee assessed shall be uniform with that assessed on businesses of like nature, so long as the amount assessed does not exceed the fees as prescribed by subsection (a). Should the city manager determine the gross sales measure of the fee to be the fair basis, the applicant may be required to submit, either at the time of termination of applicant's business in the city or at the end of each three (3) month period, a sworn statement of the gross sales and pay the amount of fee therefor, provided that no additional fee during any one calendar year shall be required after the licensee shall have paid an amount equal to the annual license as prescribed in subsection (a). 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.05) 
Sec. 9-87. - Bond; service of process after breach. 
(a)  Every applicant for a license under this division, not a resident of the city, or who being a resident of the city, represents a firm whose principal place of business is located outside the state, shall file with the city clerk a surety bond, running to the city in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with surety acceptable to and approved by the city attorney, conditioned that such applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of this Code and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the business of solicitor and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the solicitor and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with such solicitor, that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of such solicitor. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. 
(b)  Before any license shall be issued for engaging in business as a solicitor or canvasser in the city, such applicant shall file with the city clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the city clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, his true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of such applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under such license and the bond given as required by subsection (a), or for the performance of the conditions of such bond or for any breach thereof, which such instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that such applicant for such license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon such agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person or persons applying for such license under this division, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the city clerk, as herein provided, the city clerk shall send to the licensee at such licensee's last-known address, by registered mail, a copy of such process. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.06) 
Sec. 9-88. - Badges. 
    The city clerk shall issue to each licensee under this division at the time of delivery of the license a badge which shall contain the words "Licensed Solicitor," the period for which the license is issued and the number of the license, in letters and figures easily discernible from a distance of ten (10) feet. Such badge shall, during the time such licensee is engaged in soliciting, be worn constantly by the licensee on the front of such licensee's outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.07) 
Sec. 9-89. - Exhibition. 
    Solicitors and canvassers shall exhibit their licenses at the request of any citizen. 
(Code 1957, § 9-4.08) 
Secs. 9-90-9-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TRANSIENT AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Licensing and regulation of transient merchants, MCL § 445.371 et seq., MSA § 19.691 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-101. - Defined. 
    For the purpose of this article a transient merchant, itinerant merchant, or itinerant vendor is defined as any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the city or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar, or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the city, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction; provided, that such definition shall not be construed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.01) 
Sec. 9-102. - Duty of police to enforce article. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this article, to determine if this article has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.09) 
Sec. 9-103. - Records kept by city clerk. 
    The city clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of licensees under this article, together with a license number, with the chief of police; the chief of police shall report to the city clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this article and any conviction for violation of this article; the city clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints and violations. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.10) 
Secs. 9-104-9-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 9-111. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor to engage in such business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.02) 
Sec. 9-112. - Application. 
    Applicants for a license under this division, whether an individual, firm, or corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the city clerk, showing: 
(1)  The name of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the city; the local address of such person while engaged in such business; the permanent address of such person; the capacity in which such person will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
(2)  The fingerprints of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business or in lieu thereof, at least three (3) letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the city manager the good character and business responsibility of such person; 
(3)  The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that such business shall be conducted; 
(4)  The places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where applicant within the six (6) months next preceding the date of such application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post-office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
(5)  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city, the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares and merchandise, whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample at auction, by direct sale or by direct sale and by taking orders for future delivery; where the goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed; 
(6)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the city clerk, copies of all such advertising whether by handbills, circular, newspaper advertising or otherwise, shall be attached to such application as exhibits thereto; 
(7)  Whether or not the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business has been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(8)  Credentials from the person for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative; and 
(9)  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.03) 
Sec. 9-113. - Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license under this division, the chief of police shall cause such investigation of such person's business responsibility or moral character to be made as such chief deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall so certify in writing, and a license shall be issued by the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a full record in the clerk's office of all licenses issued. Such license shall contain the number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of such license, the place where such business may be carried on under such license, and the name of the person authorized to carry on the same. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.04) 
Sec. 9-114. - Fees. 
(a)  The license fee which shall be charged by the city clerk for a license under this division shall be as prescribed in section 14-6. 
(b)  The annual fees herein provided shall be assessed on a calendar year basis and on or after November first the amount of such fee for annual license shall be one-half the amount stipulated above for the remainder of the year. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.07) 
Sec. 9-115. - Bond; service of process. 
(a)  Before any license shall be issued under this division for engaging in a transient or itinerant business in the city, such applicant shall file with the city clerk a surety bond running to the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the applicant, as principal, with surety acceptable to and approved by the city attorney, conditioned that such applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of this Code of the city and the statutes of the state, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against such applicant for any violation of this Code or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against such applicant by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed, or circulated with reference to the goods, wares, and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city attorney, both as to form and as to the surety thereon. 
(b)  Before any license shall be issued under this division for engaging in business as an itinerant merchant in the city, such applicant shall file with the city clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the city clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, such applicant's true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of such applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under such license and the bond given as required by subsection (a), or for the performance of the conditions of such bond or for any breach thereof, which such instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that such applicant for such license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon such agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for such license, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgement of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the city clerk, as herein provided, the city clerk shall send to the licensee at the last-known address thereof, by registered mail, a copy of such process. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.05) 
Sec. 9-116. - Exhibition. 
    The license issued under this division shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person applying for such license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the city, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.06) 
Sec. 9-117. - Transfer. 
    No license issued under this division shall be transferred without written consent from the city manager as evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the city clerk showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Code 1957, § 9-5.08) 
Secs. 9-118-9-128. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 588-18, § 1, 11-19-18)

(Code 1957, § 9-14.03)

Chapter 10 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; operation of snowmobiles in cemeteries restricted, § 24-156; operation of off-road vehicles in cemeteries prohibited, § 24-160. 

Sec. 10-1. - Promulgation of rules and regulations by city manager. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby empowered to make and promulgate such rules, regulations and price schedules pertaining to the conduct and use of cemeteries as are necessary to administer the same or to protect public property or the safety, health, morals, or welfare of the public. No person shall fail to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(b)  Any rule, regulation or price schedule, so made, shall be in writing. A copy of each such rule, regulation or price schedule shall be filed with the city clerk before the same is put into effect. The clerk shall present such rule, regulation or price schedule to the city commission for its consideration not later than the next regular meeting of the commission after the filing of the same. No such rule, regulation or price schedule shall remain in effect if disapproved by the city commission. 
(Code 1957, § 7-7.04) 
Sec. 10-2. - Perpetual care of lots. 
(a)  The city manager and the city clerk are hereby authorized and empowered to enter into a contract with the owner of any lot, or part of a lot, in Riverside Cemetery for the perpetual care of such lot on the terms and conditions, as provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  The owner of a cemetery lot, upon payment of the required fee, shall receive from the city manager and the city clerk a written contract by which the city will agree to care perpetually for such lot, or parts of a lot. Such care is defined as keeping the grass cut and the graves level on such lot at all future times. 
(c)  All moneys received for such perpetual care shall be placed in a special fund to be designated "The Riverside Cemetery Perpetual Care Trust Fund." 
(d)  Such fund shall be deposited in banks at interest, or invested by the city in safe and conservative bonds or other securities. Earnings from "The Riverside Cemetery Perpetual Care Trust Fund" shall be used in the discretion of the city manager at Riverside Cemetery solely for the care of lots or improvements to the cemetery. Earnings from "The Riverside Cemetery Perpetual Care Trust Fund" not so used shall be retained in such fund. The principal of such fund shall be kept intact. 
(e)  The city shall furnish perpetual care, as defined herein, of all lots contracted for under the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1957, § 7-7.02) 
Sec. 10-3. - Price schedules. 
(a)  The prices to be charged for lots and graves and the fees and charges to be made for the perpetual care of lots, for the opening and closing of graves, removals, fees to be charged for the use of the receiving vault, and all other charges and fees incident to the operation of Riverside Cemetery shall be established by order of the city manager. No amendments to the price schedules shall be made except by statement of the entire schedule in the amending order. 
(b)  Prices established for the care of lots on an annual basis shall be due on or before May thirty-first in each year. No lots will be given care after May thirty-first if the established price has not been fully paid. 
(Code 1957, § 7-7.03) 
Sec. 10-4. - Use of cemeteries. 
(a)  No person shall bury, remove or disinter the body of any deceased person within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk. 
(b)  No curb, decoration, design, embellishment or improvement of any sort shall be placed upon any burial lot, nor shall any alteration of the surface of the ground be made, nor shall any labor be done unless the same shall be approved by the cemetery sexton. If any person feels himself aggrieved by the decision of the cemetery sexton, such person may appeal to the city manager. 
(c)  The city shall have the right to enter upon the premises and remove any tree or shrub in or upon any lot which shall, in the judgment of the cemetery sexton, because of their roots, branches or otherwise become detrimental, unsightly or inconvenient to the public or to the adjacent grounds. 
(d)  No person shall deface, mark, write upon or otherwise injure any property in any cemetery, or deface, mar, write upon or otherwise injure any monument, design, decoration or other thing within such grounds. No person shall pick any flowers, or break any trees, shrubs or plants. This section shall not be construed to prohibit an owner from trimming shrubs, trees or removing or replacing plants on his own lot in those sections of a cemetery where the landscaping features are the responsibility of the owner. 
(e)  No person shall carry any alcoholic liquor into any cemetery or consume any such liquor therein. No person shall carry any firearms in any cemetery. No person shall allow any animal to run at large in any cemetery. 
(f)  No person shall trespass upon any cemetery lot. 
(g)  No person shall drive or operate within any cemetery a motor vehicle used solely for commercial purposes unless upon cemetery business. 
(h)  No person shall use any cemetery for the purpose of demonstrating any vehicle, or of instructing another, or of learning to drive any vehicle. 
(i)  No person shall tow another vehicle within any cemetery except in the case of a breakdown therein. 
(j)  All burial vaults or boxes over four (4) feet in length used in the cemetery shall be of nonperishable material except if used for burial in the county burial or single burial sections. 
(k)  Orders for opening graves shall not be honored unless signed by the owner, his agent or a legal heir. 
(l)  No burial shall be permitted in the city cemetery on Sunday, New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Armistice Day, Thanksgiving Day or Christmas Day; provided, however, that the health officer, or the person performing the functions of such office during the health officer's absence, may grant special permission for burial on any day if it is the determination of such officer that burial on such day is necessary to protect the public health and safety. The health officer shall so certify in writing, stating the cause for which such burial was made necessary. When a Sunday and a legal holiday fall upon consecutive days the prohibition of burial on a legal holiday may, in the discretion of the health officer, be suspended. 
(Code 1957, § 7-7.01) 
Chapter 11 - ELECTIONS[1]

Sec. 11-1. - Precincts.

Commencing on the west at the International Boundary Line to the center line of the Edison Sault Election Company Power Canal and running to the east to Meridian St., then South on Meridian St. to Sheridan Dr., east on Sheridan Dr. to Ryan Avenue, south on Ryan Ave. to Emmett St., east on Emmett St to Park St., south on Park St. to 5th Avenue, east on 5th Avenue to Ashmun St., North on Ashmun St. to Newton St. East along Newton St. to Seymour St., North on Seymour St. to Easterday Avenue, east on Easterday Avenue to Spruce St., east on Spruce St. to Greenough St. and then north on Greenough St. to the International Boundary Line along the International Boundary Line to the point of beginning.

Beginning at the International Boundary Line on the east at the City Limits on Three Mile Road and going west on Three Mile Road to the intersection of M-129, north along M-129 to the intersection of I-75 Business Spur and Ashmun St., North on Ashmun to the intersection of Newton St., east along Newton St. to Seymour St., north on Seymour St. to Easterday Avenue, east on Easterday Ave. to Spruce St., east on Spruce St. to Greenough St., north on Greenough St. to the International Boundary Line to the point of beginning. 
(3)  Precinct Three. Commencing on the west at the International Boundary Line east to the center line of the Edison Sault Electric Power Canal and running to the east to Meridian St., south on Meridian St. to Sheridan Dr., east on Sheridan Dr. to Ryan Ave., south on Ryan Ave. to Emmett St., east on Emmett St to Park St., south on Park St. to 5th Avenue, east on 5th Avenue to Ashmun St., south on Ashmun St. to the intersection of I-75 Business Spur and M-129 (Ashmun) to Three Mile Road, west on Three Mile Road to the International Boundary Line north along the International Boundary Line to point of beginning. 
(Ord. No. 150, § 1, 1-20-75; Ord. No. 224-82, § 1, 4-5-82; Ord. No. 402-95, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. 454-02, § 1, 4-1-02)
