Chapter 12 - FIRE PREVENTION AND CONTROL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Presence of firemen at public dance halls and dances, § 6-36; payment for extraordinary fire protection at carnivals, circuses and other similar exhibitions, § 6-62; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; fire limits established, § 8-21; burning of garbage, § 13-23; performance standards concerning fire and explosive hazards, App. A, § 10-1.17(1708)(4). 
State Law reference- State fire prevention act, MCL § 29.1 et seq., MSA § 4.559(1) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Mission statement. 
    The city fire department has been established to protect the citizens and property of the city and the county from fire and other threatening circumstances. Our commitment is to provide a professional service of the highest quality to all in need. 
    To meet this commitment, the city fire department will provide its citizens with a timely response to any emergency situation with highest trained personnel available. 
    Our goal is not only to help those in need, but to remove the threat to the community all together through aggressive fire prevention programs, progressive training and years of experience. Our primary responsibility is to provide a safe and peaceful community where our citizens can work and raise a family. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Secs. 12-2-12-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire chief's approval required for transitory shows and exhibitions, § 6-106. 

Sec. 12-16. - Fire chief. 
(a)  The fire department shall be headed by the fire chief, who shall be charged with the prevention and extinguishment of fires, the protection of life and property against fire, and the removal of fire hazards. 
(b)  The fire chief shall be responsible for the maintenance and care of all property used by the fire department. 
(Code 1957, § 2-1.01) 
Sec. 12-17. - Divisions. 
    The fire department may be divided into one or more divisions which may include, but shall not be restricted to the following: 
(1)  Extinguishment division, which shall be responsible for the extinguishment of fires, the saving of life, and miscellaneous public services of an emergency nature; 
(2)  Fire prevention division, supervised by a fire hazard inspector who shall be responsible for the inspecting of potential fire hazards, the abatement of existing fire hazards, and the conducting of an educational fire prevention program. 
(Code 1957, § 2-2.02) 
Sec. 12-18. - Auxiliary fire corps. 
(a)  An auxiliary fire corps, hereinafter called corps, is hereby established as a voluntary organization composed of persons appointed by the fire chief, hereinafter called the chief. 
(b)  The chief shall have complete authority and control over the corps. The chief may appoint as members thereof any person whom such chief deems to be qualified, and may reject any application for membership. The chief may provide for the training of candidates for membership and for further training of members. Membership in this organization shall be limited to men over the age of eighteen (18). 
(c)  No person shall become a member of the corps until such person has taken the training and is able to meet all other requirements prescribed by the chief. When so qualified and selected, such person shall then be sworn in by the chief or the chief's representative as a member of the corps. 
(d)  The duties of the corps, subject at all times to the direction, supervision and control of the chief, shall be to assist the regular members of the fire department of this city in the prevention and extinguishment of fires, the protection of life and property against fire, and the removal of fire hazards, whenever and whenever its services are required. The chief may, by order, establish rules and regulations to govern the corps, including the fixing of specific duties of its members and providing for the maintenance of discipline. The chief may change such orders from time to time. 
(e)  Identification card, badge and cap, and such other insignia or evidence of identification as the chief may prescribe, shall be issued to each member, who shall carry the card at all times. Each member shall surrender all city property issued to such member upon the termination of membership. 
(f)  The membership of any person in the corps may be terminated for cause by the chief at any time, and such member may resign from the corps at any time upon notifying the chief in writing of such person's resignation; provided, however, that the personnel regulations of the city manager applicable to full-time, regular city employees shall not be applicable to the corps and the civil service laws of the state applicable to firemen shall not be applicable to any member of the corps. 
(g)  The chief may, by order, diminish or expand the membership of the corps as existing conditions may require, subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(h)  It shall be a misdemeanor for any person not a member of the corps: 
(1)  To wear, carry or display a corps identification card, badge, cap or insignia; or 
(2)  In any manner to represent themselves to be connected with the corps. 
(i)  Each member of the corps, while acting under the direction of the chief, shall be deemed an employee of the city and shall be entitled to receive workmen's compensation from the city in accordance with the provisions of the workmen's compensation law of the state. If any member sustains an illness or injury covered by the workmen's compensation law, not caused by intoxication or willful misconduct and not intentionally self-inflicted, which, with or without negligence, is approximately caused by and arises out of and in the course of the performance of such member's duties while acting under the direction of the chief, then irrespective of such member's remuneration from other employment, such member's average weekly earnings shall be conclusively presumed to be the amount necessary to receive the maximum disability and death benefits provided at that time by the workmen's compensation law of the state. 
(Code 1957, § 2-1.03) 
Secs. 12-19-12-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-30. - Adoption of National Fire Codes. 
    The International Fire Code, as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the Fire Prevention Code of the City Sault Ste. Marie, Chippewa County, Michigan, for the control of building, structures and premises as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions, and terms of the International Fire Code including appendices B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, and J are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this Code, including the additions, insertions, deletions, and changes, set forth in section 12-35 as amended. Appendix A of the International Fire Code will not be adopted, and instead replaced with the language set forth in sections 12-34.1 and 10-1.20. Copies of the International Fire Code are on file in the office of the city fire department and city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 32, § 5-2.18, 6-21-65; Ord. No. 97, § 5-2.18, 2-28-72; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Charter reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, § 7.8. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL § 117.3, MSA § 5.2073. 
Sec. 12-31. - Copies on file. 
    Printed copies of the National Fire Codes, adopted by section 12-30, with amendments thereto, shall be kept in the office of the city clerk, available for inspection by and distribution to the public at all reasonable times. 
(Ord. No. 32, § 5-2.19, 6-21-65) 
Sec. 12-32. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall violate any of the provisions of the National Fire Codes or of the amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 32, § 5-2.20, 6-21-65) 
Sec. 12-33. - Enforcement. 
    The fire code official of the fire department shall be charged with the enforcement of the provisions of the International Fire Code. 
(Ord. No. 32, § 5-2.21, 6-21-65; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-34. - Appeals. 
(a)  Board of appeals. There shall be established and appointed by the city commission, as amended, a fire code board of appeals. The board shall consist of three (3) members and two (2) alternate members. The appointments shall be as follows: one (1) member appointed for a period of one (1) year; one (1) member appointed for a period of two (2) years; and one (1) members appointed for a period of three (3) years. One (1) of the regular members of the fire code board of appeals may be a member of the planning commission. After the initial appointments, except for a member serving because of his or her membership on the planning commission, whose term shall be limited to the time he or she is a member of that body each member shall be appointed to hold office for the full three (3) year term. The appointments of the two (2) alternate members shall be as follows: one (1) alternate member appointed for a one (1) year term; one (1) alternate member appointed for a two (2) year term; thereafter, each alternate member shall be appointed to hold office for a full three (3) year term. Term of the preceding member has expired for the remainder of the unexpired term the board shall annually elect its own chairman, vice chairman, and secretary. The alternate members shall attend each board of appeals meeting. The alternate members shall sit as a regular member in the absence of a regular member or when a regular member has abstained from acting on a matter coming before the board of appeals. The alternate members shall be called to sit on a rotating basis as needed. All members shall serve until their successor has been appointed and qualified. 
(b)  Appeal. Meetings of the board shall be heard at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine by rule. Such chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. Notwithstanding, whenever the fire code official of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the International Fire Code do not apply, or that the true intent and meaning of the codes have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the fire code official of the fire department, in writing to the city fire code board of appeals within ten (10) days from the date of infraction. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. The board shall adopt his [its] own rules or procedures and shall maintain a record of its proceedings, which shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be a public record provided. The fees to be charged for appeals shall be set by resolution of the city commission. 
(c)  Appeals, how taken. The board of appeals shall hear and decide appeals from a person aggrieved, or by an officer, department, board, or bureau of this state or the city, and review any order, requirements, decisions, or determinations, made by an administrative official or body charged with the enforcement of an ordinance adopted under Act 207, Public Acts of 1921 (MCL § 125.581 et seq.). 
    Appeals shall be taken within ten (10) days after the occurrence of the event which forms the basis for the appeal, by filing in writing a request for an appeal with the official from whom an appeal is taken who shall forthwith transmit to the board all papers constituting the record upon which the appeal is taken. 
    An appeal stays all the proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the official from whom the appeal was taken [certifies to the board, after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him, that by reason of facts stated in the certificate] a stay would in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property, in which case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the board, circuit court or other court of jurisdiction of notice on the application to the official from whom the appeal was taken and on due cause shown. All requests for board of appeals actions shall be made in writing upon forms adopted for such purposes. 
(d)  Powers and duties. The board of appeals shall not have the power to alter to make any change in the terms of this section, but does have power to act on those matters where this section provides for an administrative review, interpretation, exception or special approval permit and to authorize a variance as defined in this section and laws of the state. Said powers include: 
(1)  Administrative review. To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by the appellant that there is error in any order, requirement, permit, decision or refusal made by the administrative official in carrying out or enforcing any provisions of this section. 
(2)  Interpretation. To hear and decide, in accordance with the provisions of this section, requests for interpretation on which the section specifically authorizes the board to act. 
(e)  Hearings. 
(1)  Following receipt of a written request concerning a request for an appeal, the fire code board of appeals shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the request and give notice as provided. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a written request seeking an interpretation of the International Fire Code or an appeal of an administrative decision, a notice stating the time, date, and place of the public hearing shall be sent to the person requesting the interpretation not less than fifteen (15) days before the public hearing. 
(f)  Standards. Each case before the fire code board of appeals shall be considered as individual case and shall conform to the detailed application of the fire code standards in a manner appropriate to the particular circumstances of such case. 
(g)  Miscellaneous. No order of the fire code board of appeals permitting a use of a building or premises shall be valid for a period longer than one (1) year unless such use is established within such period; provided, however, that the use of such permit is dependent upon the erection or alteration of a building, such order shall continue in full force and effect if a building permit for such use, erection or alteration is obtained within such period and such erection or alterations are commenced and proceed to completion in accordance with the terms of such permit. No person shall fail to comply with any special condition for a use as established and required by the board of appeals. 
(h)  Decisions, appeals to circuit court. All decisions of the fire code board of appeals shall be recited in the official minutes of the board of appeals. A copy of the minutes shall be mailed by first class mail to the party who caused the matter to come before the board of appeals. The mailing date shall be stamped upon the minutes. The board of appeals shall keep a record of and proof of such mailing. The decision of the board of appeals shall be final, unless within thirty (30) days after the date of mailing stamped upon the minutes, a person having an interest affected by the decision files an appeal in the county circuit court in accordance with the court rules for taking such appeals. 
(Ord. No. 32, § 5-2.22, 6-21-65; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-35. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-35.3. - Permit fee. 
    A minimum fee established by resolution from the city commission may be applied to each type of permit required by this Code. Permits may be issued to a single vendor, an individual, or an entire event. A permit shall not be required for one- and two-family dwelling residential properties; unless a fire protection system is being installed. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12.35.4. - Required operational permits. 
    The city fire department shall be authorized to issue operational permits for hazardous conditions or processes. A list of required operational permits and their associated fee shall be set by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-36. - Injunctions. 
    If any person maintains violations of this article, or repeatedly violates this article in a manner which becomes a public nuisance, that person may be, upon application by the city commission to a court of competent jurisdiction, enjoined from such dangerous or noxious activity and shall be compelled to pay the costs of the city fire department in procuring such injunction along with the actual attorney fees incurred in such proceedings, with costs and damages, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Secs. 12-37-12-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE 

Sec. 12-41. - Obedience to state law, rules and regulations required. 
    No person shall violate any law of the state, nor any rule or regulation adopted by any duly authorized agency of the state punishable as a misdemeanor, pertaining to fire, fire hazards, fire prevention, fire waste, explosives, flammable liquids, pyrotechnics or hazardous chemicals. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.01) 
Sec. 12-42. - Inspection. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department is hereby empowered to enter at any and all reasonable times upon and into any premises, building or structure for the purpose of examining and inspecting the same to ascertain fire hazards, and the condition, size, arrangements and efficiency of any and all appliances for fire fighting. 
(b)  If such inspection shall disclose any fire hazard or any deficiency in fire-fighting appliances, the chief of the fire department shall order the conditions remedied within a stated time, not less than twenty-four (24) hours nor longer than thirty (30) days; provided, however, that the chief of the fire department may, at the chief's discretion, grant further time for compliance with such order if such extension of time is deemed necessary. 
(c)  The service of such order may be made upon the owner or occupant of the premises, either by delivering the order to the owner or occupant personally or by delivering and leaving it with any person in charge of the premises, or in case no such person is found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door or entrance to the premises. 
(d)  Any person aggrieved by such order may, within twenty-four (24) hours after its receipt, appeal to the city manager or city commission, who shall have the power to veto such order. 
(e)  No person shall fail to comply with any such order of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.02) 
Sec. 12-43. - Storage of combustible materials in waste receptacles required. 
(a)  No person owning or being responsible for any premises shall permit any waste paper, ashes, oil, rags, waste rags, excelsior or any inflammable or combustible material to accumulate thereon, unless contained in fireproof receptacles. 
(b)  No person owning or being responsible for any private garage shall permit any waste paper, oil, rags, excelsior or any inflammable or combustible material to accumulate therein. 
(c)  No person shall place any waste paper, oil, rags, waste rags, excelsior or any inflammable or combustible material in any street, alley or public place, unless the same be contained in a covered receptacle. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.03) 
Sec. 12-44. - Kindling fires in public places. 
    No person shall kindle a fire in or upon any street, alley, or any public place unless they have first been issued a permit for such fire from the Fire Chief. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.04; Ord. No. 414-96, § 1, 10-21-96) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 12-45. - Kindling fires on private property. 
    No person shall kindle a fire, nor suffer or permit a fire, on any private property except: 
(1)  The person has first been issued a permit for such fire by the fire chief, or 
(2)  The fire is contained in a container not in excess of three (3) feet by three (3) feet square, and the container is constructed of metal or masonry material, and the fire is being used for the purposes of cooking food. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.05; Ord. No. 414-96, § 1, 10-21-96) 
Cross reference- Burning, § 13-23. 
Sec. 12-46. - False alarms; interference with equipment. 
    No person shall turn in, sound, or cause to be communicated to the fire department a false alarm of fire; or molest any fire-fighting apparatus or equipment, or anything pertaining to the fire alarm system; or make, or have in such person's possession an impression or duplicate of any key belonging to the fire department, without the express permission of the fire chief. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.06) 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, MCL § 750.240, MSA § 28.437. 
Sec. 12-47. - Obstruction of fire plugs prohibited. 
    No person shall place or permit to remain any obstruction whatsoever within fifteen (15) feet of any fire hydrant or fireplug. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.07) 
Sec. 12-48. - Obstruction of fire exits prohibited. 
(a)  No obstruction shall be placed in the way of, or upon, any fire escape, balcony or ladder intended as a means of escape from fire. 
(b)  No inflammable material shall be placed under or at the bottom of any stairway, elevator or other exit of any building; nor shall any such material be placed where burning would obstruct or render egress from a building hazardous. 
(c)  No obstruction shall be placed in hallways of tenements or apartment houses. 
(d)  No person shall obstruct with furniture, crates, cartons or in any manner any door, aisle or passageway of any theatre, church or other place of public assemblage. 
(e)  No person shall sit or stand in the aisle of any place of public assemblage or in any exit or passage required for the exit from such place of assemblage. 
(f)  Clear passage from all exits and on all sidewalks shall be maintained outside of all places of public assemblage. 
(g)  No aisle, passageway or stairway in any store shall be obstructed with tables, showcases or other obstructions during the hours such store is open to the public. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.08) 
Sec. 12-49. - Garages and repair shops regulated. 
(a)  All gasoline, exclusive of that in tanks of vehicles, shall be stored in tanks approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., and the reservoirs of motor vehicles shall be filled directly through hose from pumps attached to such tanks. No transfer of gasoline in any garage shall be made in any open or breakable container. 
(b)  Smoking shall be prohibited in any public garage, except in office areas separated from the repair or storage areas by sufficient protective walls. "No Smoking" signs shall be maintained in conspicuous places in the repair and storage areas of such garages. 
(c)  No gasoline, oil, grease or inflammable liquid shall be allowed to run on the floor or flow into or be placed in the drainage system of public garages and repair shops. 
(d)  All combustible waste and rubbish, including crankcase drainage, shall be kept in metal receptacles fitted with a tight cover until removed from the premises of public garages and repair shops. 
(e)  Public garages shall be equipped with approved type fire extinguishers and pails of sand as required by the chief of the fire department. 
(f)  All public garages and repair shops shall be kept clean and orderly. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.09) 
Sec. 12-50. - Obstruction of view into certain places prohibited. 
    No person operating any store, shop, warehouse, hall or mercantile establishment shall construct or maintain any curtain, shade, obstruction or device in the front window of any such store, shop, warehouse, hall or mercantile establishment which has for its purpose the closing of such place from public view. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.10) 
Sec. 12-51. - Light to be burning in certain places after dark. 
    Every person operating or conducting any store, shop, warehouse, hall or mercantile establishment shall maintain and cause to be kept burning, during the hours of darkness, one light of at least sixteen (16) candlepower in such shop, store, warehouse, hall or mercantile establishment. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.11) 
Sec. 12-52. - Causing fires in hotels, rooming houses and other places of public abode. 
    No person shall carelessly, recklessly or negligently set fire to any hotel, rooming house, lodging house or any place of public abode, or to any bedding, furniture, curtains, drapes or other furnishings therein. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.12) 
Sec. 12-53. - Smoking in bed prohibited in places of public abode. 
    No person shall smoke or have lighted any cigarette, pipe or cigar, while such person is in or upon any bed in any motel, hotel or rooming house. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.13) 
Sec. 12-54. - Notice required in places of public abode. 
    In each sleeping room of all hotels, motels, rooming houses, lodging houses and other places of public abode, a plainly written notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place as notice of the provisions of sections 12-52 and 12-53. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.14) 
Sec. 12-55. - Smoking in theaters and similar places prohibited. 
    No person shall smoke in any opera house, theater, auditorium or motion picture theater or upon the stage or in the dressing rooms of any opera house, theater, auditorium or motion picture theater except in specially constructed fireproof rooms approved by the fire chief. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.15) 
Sec. 12-56. - Incinerators required in new commercial or public buildings. 
    No person shall construct any new building for commercial or public purposes except the same be equipped with an incinerator of such size as the city inspector shall deem adequate. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.16) 
Sec. 12-57. - Installation of incinerator in existing buildings; when required; appeal. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department may order the installation of an incinerator of a size the chief finds to be adequate in any building which is used for commercial, industrial or public purposes in the event that the burning of combustible refuse upon the premises whereon such building is located or in any alley adjacent thereto constitutes a hazard to the safety of persons and property. Within sixty (60) days, the owner or person responsible for a building used for commercial, industrial or public purposes shall equip such building with an incinerator of the size determined by the chief of the fire department upon order to do so by the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  In the event any such owner or person responsible for property shall feel aggrieved because of any such order of the chief of the fire department, such owner or person may appeal to the city commission by written protest filed with the city clerk. The commission shall set a time and place for such hearing to be held within thirty (30) days of the date of the filing of such protest. The determination of the commission at such hearing shall be final. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2.17) 
Sec. 12-58. - Address numbers. 
    New and existing building shall have approved numbers, building numbers, or approved building identification placed in a position to be plainly legible and visible from the street or road fronting this property. These numbers shall contrast with their background. Address numbers shall be Arabic numbers or alphabet letters. Numbers shall be a minimum of six (6) inches high with a minimum stroke of one-half (0.5) inches for commercial/multifamily occupancies, and a minimum of three (3) inches high with a minimum stroke of one-half (0.5) inches for one- and two-family dwellings. Where required by the fire code official, address numbers shall be provided in additional approved locations to facilitate emergency response. Where access is by means of a private road and the building cannot be viewed from the public way, a monument, pole or other sign or means shall be used to identify the structure. Address identification shall be maintained. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Secs. 12-59, 12-60. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-61. - Required pressure margin. 
    In order to account for seasonal and daily water pressure demands and future growth demands within the water supply, the fire code official is authorized to require a pressure margin of up to ten (10) percent over the minimum design criteria for installed automatic fire sprinkler systems. Where this margin cannot be achieved, approved means shall be taken to provide this margin. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-62. - System records reporting. 
    All required inspection, testing, and maintenance records of fire protection systems shall be submitted to the fire authority in an approved electronic format. 
(Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-63. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXPLOSIVES AND PYROTECHNICS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Permit required for setting off fireworks, § 16-60. 

Sec. 12-64. - Obedience to state law, rules and regulations required. 
    No person shall violate any law of the state, nor any rule or regulation adopted by any duly authorized agency of the state, pertaining to explosives or pyrotechnics. 
(Code 1957, § 5-3.01) 
Sec. 12-65. - Blasting, when prohibited. 
    No person shall blast or carry on any blasting operations without first having obtained a written permit from the city clerk. Before any such permit is issued, the applicant therefor shall furnish a bond deemed adequate by the city manager to pay for any damage to public or private property and any personal injuries resulting from the blasting. The bond so furnished shall be available for the payment of such claims. In addition to the above requirements, a policeman shall be in attendance at the scene while blasting is being done and the applicant shall reimburse the city for the cost of providing such police protection. 
(Code 1957, § 5-3.02) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 12-66. - Storage of explosives. 
(a)  No person shall construct, erect, alter or use any magazine for the storage of explosives as permitted by state law except in industrial districts as established by the zoning ordinance or without first obtaining a license therefor as provided for in chapter 14. 
(b)  No person shall store more than twenty thousand (20,000) pounds of explosives or more than five thousand (5,000) blasting caps in any magazine within the corporate limits. 
(c)  No blasting caps, or other detonating or fulminating caps or detonators, shall be kept or stored in any magazine in which other explosives are kept or stored. 
(Code 1957, § 5-3.03) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14; zoning ordinance, App. A. 
Sec. 12-67. - Explosive or inflammable dust. 
    No person shall operate any plant wherein inflammable dust is created unless: 
(1)  Any and all sources of ignition within the area of explosive or inflammable dust exposure are eliminated; 
(2)  Elevator legs, spouts, hoppers and other conveyances are dusttight; 
(3)  Accumulations of dust are not permitted in the interior of the building and a suitable dust removal system is maintained; 
(4)  Open flame or spark-producing equipment is not permitted in rooms containing dusty atmospheres; 
(5)  Magnetic separators are maintained ahead of all grinding or pulverizing machines; 
(6)  Operation is under competent supervision; and 
(7)  Machinery and parts of the crushing, drying, pulverizing, and conveying systems are adequately grounded. 
(Code 1957, § 5-3.04; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 576-18, adopted January 15, 2018, amended § 12-67 to read as set out herein. Previously § 12-67 was titled "Inflammable dust." 
Secs. 12-68-12-73. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS 

Sec. 12-74. - Obedience to state laws, rules and regulations required. 
    No person shall violate any law of the state nor any rule or regulation adopted by any duly authorized agency of the state pertaining to gasoline service stations (Michigan Storage and Handling of Flammable and Combustible Liquids Rules, and Michigan Underground Storage Tank Rules). 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.01; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-75. - Definitions. 
(a)  The term "gasoline service station," when used in this division, shall mean any premises, including all buildings and structures thereon, devoted to selling or dispensing at retail or wholesale gasoline or volatile liquids as fuel for any motor-propelled vehicle, watercraft, aircraft or internal-combustion engine; or where oil, oil changes or other lubricating service is offered to the public at wholesale or retail. 
(b)  The term "gasoline or volatile liquids," when used in this division, shall mean any inflammable liquid that will flash or emit an inflammable vapor below the temperature of one hundred twenty (120) degrees Fahrenheit. The fire code official of the fire department shall determine the flash point by standard, approved methods. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.02; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-76. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, operate or manage a gasoline service station without first obtaining a license therefor from the city clerk in the manner provided for in chapter 14. 
(b)  No license required by this division shall be issued by the city clerk except upon certification by the fire code official of the fire department that such gasoline service station complies with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.03; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 12-77. - Prohibited locations of service stations. 
    No gasoline service station shall hereafter be constructed or opened for business within a radius of forty (40) feet of any school building, public park or playground, church, community building, theater, or any other place where the public frequently gather in large numbers; provided that this section shall not extend to any gasoline station operating or in the process of being constructed at the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section was derived. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.04; Ord. No. 7, § 1 (5-5.04), 7-7-58; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-78. - Equipment permit, when required. 
    The storing or keeping of gasoline, or the installation, erection, alteration or replacement of any gasoline pump, gasoline tank, pipe, appliance or device used in connection with the storage or handling of gasoline at a gasoline service station shall not be undertaken until a written permit has been issued therefor by the fire code official of the fire department. This section shall not apply to general maintenance activities of wholesale stations, nor to emergency repairs, except that such work must be done in accordance with the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.05; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-79. - Installation of underground storage tanks. 
(a)  All underground gasoline tanks hereafter installed shall be placed outside of buildings in a location approved by the fire code official of the fire department. The top of such tanks shall be at least twenty-four (24) inches below the surface of the ground with the space between the top of tanks and ground properly filled, or shall be covered with one (1) foot of earth and six (6) inches of concrete. 
(b)  All pipes used in connection with underground storage tanks other than vent and filling pipes shall be at least twelve (12) inches underground, shall have a fall toward the tank, shall be free of sags or pockets, and shall be standard, full weight, galvanized steel or iron, or copper. 
(c)  Tanks and pipes shall not be covered until inspected and tested by the fire code official of the fire department and permission to do so has been granted by the fire code official. The fire code official of the fire department shall be notified when the installation is complete and ready for inspection. The fire code official of the fire department shall not approve any installation until the same has been inspected by such fire code official and has been tested with air at a pressure of five (5) pounds per square inch above atmospheric pressure and has demonstrated its ability to hold air at such pressure without loss of pressure due to leakage for a period of one (1) hour. 
(d)  All underground tanks, and piping shall be in accordance with the Michigan Underground Storage Tank Rules. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.06; Ord. No. 576-18, 1-15-18) 
Sec. 12-80. - Safety provisions. 
(a)  Smoking is hereby prohibited on the premises of a gasoline service station. The motor of an automobile shall not be in operation while the fuel tank is being filled with gasoline. Notice to that effect shall be conspicuously posted as required by the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  No fuel tank shall be filled at a retail gasoline service station except through a hose connected to a pump of a type approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Incorporated. 
(c)  No gasoline or inflammable liquid shall be kept or conveyed in open receptacles or in glass bottles or other breakable containers on the premises of a gasoline service station, except in glass bottles of not more than eight (8) ounces capacity used for sample purposes. No gasoline shall be used for cleaning purposes on such premises. No glass container gasoline pump shall be installed in any building. 
(d)  All combustible waste and rubbish, including crankcase drainings, shall be kept in metal receptacles fitted with a tight cover until removed from the gasoline service stations. 
(e)  No gasoline, oil, grease or inflammable liquid shall be allowed to flow into or be placed in the drainage system of gasoline service stations. Oil and grease shall not be allowed to accumulate on the floor of gasoline service stations. Sawdust shall not be kept in any gasoline service station or place of storage, and sawdust or other combustible material shall not be used to absorb oil, grease or gasoline. 
(f)  All gasoline service station proprietors and attendants, upon being notified by the chief of the fire department of the presence of gasoline or volatile liquids in sewers, shall cooperate in ascertaining the reason therefor. Any expense to the city in tracing gasoline leaks shall be paid by the owner of the station responsible for such gasoline leak. 
(g)  The chief of the fire department is hereby empowered, subject to approval by the commission, to make reasonable and necessary rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this division, respecting the use, operation, maintenance and construction of any appliance, device, apparatus, equipment or oil burner used in connection with gasoline or volatile liquids, including fuel oil. 
(h)  There shall be constantly maintained in good working order at least one two and one-half (21/2) gallon fully charged, approved, portable type fire extinguisher at each gasoline service station. 
(i)  When a gasoline service station is discontinued or dismantled, the owner thereof shall forthwith remove all underground tanks that were used in connection therewith or completely fill the same with sand. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.07) 
Sec. 12-81. - Location of gasoline pumps. 
(a)  No gasoline service station shall be permitted to operate within the boundaries of any street, alley or public place. 
(b)  All apparatus for the servicing of motor vehicles shall be so placed that any and all motor vehicles shall be serviced while standing upon the property of the service station with no part of the vehicle projecting over the sidewalk area, street or alley. 
(Code 1957, § 5-5.08) 
Secs. 12-82-12-87. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS 

Sec. 12-88. - Scope. 
    This division shall apply to materials not otherwise covered in this Code which are highly flammable, or which may react to cause fires or explosions, or which by their presence create or augment a fire or explosion hazard, or which because of their toxicity, flammability or explosive character render fire fighting abnormally dangerous or difficult; also to flammable liquids which are chemically unstable and which may spontaneously form explosive compounds, or undergo spontaneous reactions of explosive violence or evolve sufficient heat to be a fire hazard. Hazardous chemicals shall include but shall not be restricted to such materials as compressed gases, flammable solids, corrosive liquids, radioactive materials, oxidizing materials, and poisonous gases. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.01) 
Sec. 12-89. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Compressed gas shall mean and include any mixture or material having in its container either an absolute pressure exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch at seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit or an absolute pressure exceeding one hundred and five (105) pounds per square inch at one hundred thirty (130) degrees Fahrenheit, or both; or any liquid flammable material having a Reid vapor pressure exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch at one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit. 
    Corrosive liquids shall mean and include those acids, alkaline caustic liquids and other corrosive liquids which, when in contact with living tissue, will cause severe damage to such tissue by chemical action; or which are liable to cause fire when in contact with organic matter or with certain chemicals. 
    Flammable solid shall mean and include a solid substance, other than one classified as an explosive, which is liable to cause fires through friction, through absorption of moisture, through spontaneous chemical changes, or as a result of retained heat during manufacturing or processing. 
    Oxidizing materials shall mean and include substances such as chlorates, permanganates, peroxides or nitrates, that yield oxygen readily to stimulate combustion. 
    Poisonous gas shall mean and include any noxious gas of such nature that a small amount of the gas when mixed with air is dangerous to life. Examples are chlorpicrin, cyanogen, hydrogen cyanide, nitrogen peroxide and phosgene. 
    Radioactive material shall mean and include any material or combination of material that spontaneously emits ionizing radiation. 
    Vapor pressure shall mean the pressure, measured in pounds per square inch (absolute) exerted by a volatile liquid as determined by the "Standard Method of Test for Vapor Pressure of Petroleum Products (Reid Method)," American Society for Testing Materials designation (A.S.T.M.D. 323). 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.02) 
Sec. 12-90. - Permit required. 
    A permit from the city clerk shall be required for the storage, use or handling of more than fifty-five (55) gallons of corrosive liquid; or more than five hundred (500) pounds of oxidizing materials; or more than five hundred (500) millicuries of radioactive material; or more than two thousand (2,000) cubic feet of flammable compressed gas; or any amount of poisonous gas. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.03) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 12-91. - General requirements. 
(a)  The storage, handling and use of hazardous chemicals shall be safeguarded with such protective facilities as public safety requires. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department may require the separation or isolation of any chemical that in combination with other substances may bring about a fire or explosion or may liberate a flammable or poisonous gas. The chief of the fire department may require separation from other storage, occupancies or buildings when in the chief's opinion the quantity stored constitutes a material hazard. 
(c)  Defective containers which permit leakage or spillage shall be disposed of or repaired, in accordance with recognized safe practices; no spilled materials shall be allowed to accumulate. 
(d)  Where specific requirements are not otherwise established compliance with the recommendations contained in the Table of Common Hazardous Chemicals of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA No. 49), the Safety Data Sheets of the Manufacturing Chemists' Association, or the Pamphlets G-1, G-2, G-3, G-4, P-1, and P-2 of the Compressed Gas Association, Inc., with respect to the particular chemicals shall be considered as prima facie evidence of compliance with this section. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.04) 
Sec. 12-92. - Compressed gases. 
(a)  Storage rooms for compressed gases shall be cool, dry and well ventilated. 
(b)  Cylinders shall be stored away from radiators and other sources of heat. No part of any cylinder containing compressed gas shall be subjected to temperatures above one hundred twenty-five (125) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(c)  Where caps are provided for valve protection they shall be kept on all cylinders not connected to gas utilization equipment. 
(d)  Cylinders shall not be used as rollers, supports or for any purpose other than to store the gas for which they are designed. Cylinders shall not be handled with lifting magnets, rope slings or chain slings; a crane may be used when a safe cradle or platform is provided to hold the cylinders. 
(e)  Refilling of cylinders shall be done only in compliance with interstate commerce commission regulations. 
(f)  Each cylinder shall carry a legible label or stencil identifying its contents. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.05) 
Sec. 12-93. - Oxidizing materials. 
    Oxidizing materials shall be stored in dry locations and separated from organic materials including wooden surfaces. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.06) 
Sec. 12-94. - Radioactive materials. 
(a)  Adequate signs warning of radiation dangers shall be placed at entrances to locations where radioactive materials are used or stored. Signs will not be required for storage of manufactured articles, other than liquids, such as instruments or clock dials of which radioactive materials are a component part and luminous compounds, when securely packed in strong containers provided the gamma radiation at any surface of the package is less than ten (10) milliroentgens in twenty-four (24) hours. 
(b)  When not in use, radioactive materials shall be kept in adequately shielded fire-resistant containers of such design that the gamma radiation will not exceed two hundred (200) milliroentgens per hour or equivalent at any point of readily accessible surface. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.07) 
Sec. 12-95. - Poisonous gases. 
(a)  Storage of poisonous gases shall be in rooms of at least one-hour fire-resistant construction and having natural or mechanical ventilation adequate to remove leaking gas. Such ventilation shall not discharge to a point where the gases may endanger any person. 
(b)  Adequate warning signs stating the nature of the hazard shall be placed at all entrances to locations where poisonous gases are stored or used. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.08) 
Sec. 12-96. - Corrosive liquids. 
    Satisfactory provisions shall be made for containing and neutralizing or safely flushing away leakage of corrosive liquids which may occur during storage, handling or use. 
(Code 1957, § 5-6.09) 
Secs. 12-97-12-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENT COST RECOVERY 

Sec. 12-201. - Purpose. 
    The city finds that a significant potential exists for fire department responses to incidents involving the release or threatened release of hazardous materials. Such incidents create a great likelihood of personal injury and/or property damage. The control and abatement of such incidents places a significant financial and operational burden upon the city's firefighting and rescue services. 
(Ord. No. 488-06, § 1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 12-202. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this article shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application. 
    Building means any structure. 
    Emergency response means the providing, sending and/or utilizing firefighting, emergency medical and rescue services by the city, or by a private entity or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city or state, for an incident resulting in a hazardous material release or threatened release. 
    Expenses of an emergency response means the direct and reasonable costs incurred by the city, or a private person, corporation, or other assisting government agency, which is operating at the request or direction of the city, when making an emergency response to the hazardous materials incident, including the costs of providing police, firefighting, rescue services, emergency medical services, containment, and abatement of all hazardous conditions at the scene of the incident. The costs further include all of the salaries and wages of city personnel responding to the incident, salaries and wages of city personnel engaged in the investigation, supervision and report preparation regarding said incident, all salaries and wages of personnel assisting government agencies operating at the request or direction of the city, and all costs connected with the administration of the incident relating to any prosecution of the person(s) responsible, including those relating to the production and appearance of witnesses at any court proceedings in relation thereto. Costs shall also include such items as disposable materials and supplies used during the response to said incident, the rental or leasing of equipment used for the specific response, replacement of equipment which is contaminated beyond reuse or repair during the response to said incident, special technical services and laboratory cost, and services and supplies purchased for any specific evacuation relating to said incident. 
    Hazardous material means explosives, pyrotechnics, flammable compressed gas, flammable liquid, combustible liquid, oxidizing material, poisonous gas, poisonous liquid, irritating material, etiological material, radioactive material, corrosive materials, or liquefied petroleum gas. 
    Owner means any person having a vested or contingent interest in the building, personal property, premises, container or vehicle involved in the hazardous materials incident. 
    Premises means any lot or parcel of land and includes a parking lot, tourist camp, trailer camp, airport, stockyard, junkyard, wharf, pier, public roadway, and any other place however owned, used or occupied. 
    Vehicle means any device which is used as an instrument of conveyance, including, but not limited to, motor vehicles, railroads, boats or aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 488-06, § 1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 12-203. - Liability for expense of an emergency response. 
    Person(s) responsible. The owner, lessee, operator, or occupant or [of] any building, premises, personal property or vehicle regarding which an incident arises which involves the release or threatened release or hazardous materials on or about said building, premises, personal property or vehicle shall be required to reimburse the city for all expenses of any emergency response to said hazardous materials incident. This personal liability shall be joint and several among the various parties. 
    Charge against person. The expense of an emergency response shall be a charge against the person(s) responsible under this article. The charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the city in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under contract, express or implied. 
    Cost recovery schedule. The city shall, by resolution adopt a schedule of the costs included within the expense of an emergency response. 
    Billing. The city may, within ten (10) days of receiving itemized costs or any part thereof incurred for an emergency response, submit a bill for these costs by first class mail or personal service to the person(s) responsible for the expenses as enumerated under this article. The bill(s) shall require full payment within thirty (30) days from the date of mailing or service of said bill upon the person(s) responsible. 
    Failure to pay and procedure to recover costs. Any failure to pay said bill within the thirty (30) days of mailing or service of this bill shall constitute a default on said bill. In case of default, the city shall have the right and power to add all emergency response costs to the tax roll as to any such property involved in the hazardous materials incident. The city shall follow section 10.9 of the Charter and chapter 21 of the Code in the making of such assessment. The city shall also have the concurrent right to bring action in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect said costs against the person(s) responsible if the city deems such action to be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 488-06, § 1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 12-204. - Conflicting ordinances repealed. 
    Any and all other ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of the article and any changes adopted thereto are, to the extent of such inconsistency, hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 488-06, § 1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 12-205. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, clause, paragraph or provision of this article shall be adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such adjudication shall only apply to the said portion thereof adjudicated invalid, and the full remaining portions of parts of this article shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 488-06, § 1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 12-206. - Savings clause. 
    All proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing, acquired, or incurred at the time this article takes effect are hereby saved, and such proceedings may be consummated under and according to the ordinance in force at the time such proceedings are or were commenced. This article shall not be construed to alter, affect, or abate any pending prosecution or proceeding or prevent prosecution or proceeding hereafter instituted under any ordinance specifically or impliedly repealed by this article and any changes thereto for any liabilities incurred or offenses committed before the effective date of this article and all proceedings pending at the effective date of this article and all proceedings or prosecutions instituted after the effective date of this article for any liabilities incurred or offenses committed before the effective date of this article may be continued or instituted under and in accordance with the provisions of any ordinance in force at the time of the liability incurred or commission of such offense. 
(Ord. No. 488-06, § 1, 3-6-06)
