ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 13-1-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE AND RUBBISH[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Placing dead animals in rubbish or garbage containers prohibited, § 7-3. 

Sec. 13-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Ashes means the residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings. 
    Frequency of collection means the time elapsing between two (2) successive collections as established herein. 
    Garbage means animal or vegetable wastes which arise from the use, preparation or storage of food for human consumption not including wastes from industrial processes and manufacturing operations. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible material from residential commercial and institutional property, such as ashes, paper cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, bedding, furniture, metal, tin cans, dirt, clay, gravel, grass, crockery and miscellaneous mineral refuse not including gravel, sand or building materials. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.01) 
Sec. 13-17. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city may provide for the supervision, collection and disposal of rubbish and garbage accumulated in this city. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby empowered to promulgate rules, regulations and collection fees necessary for the effective administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. Such rules, regulations or collection fees shall be in writing. 
(c)  A copy of each such rule, regulation or collection fee shall be filed with the city clerk before the same is put into effect. The clerk shall present such rule, regulation or collection fee to the city commission for its consideration not later than the next regular meeting of the commission after the filing of same. No such rule, regulation or collection fee shall remain in effect if disapproved by the city commission. 
(d)  No person shall disobey any such rule or regulations promulgated in accordance with this section. Any violation of such rule or regulation shall be considered a violation of this ordinance and shall be prohibited. Punishment for such rule or regulation violation shall be the same punishment as is accorded for ordinance violations. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.07; Ord. No. 338-90, § 1, 7-23-90) 
Sec. 13-18. - Disposition in general. 
    No person shall deposit, or cause to be deposited, scatter or abandon rubbish or garbage on any public or private place in this city, except as provided in this Code. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.02) 
Sec. 13-19. - Placement in containers for collection. 
(a)  Every tenant, lessee, or occupant of any premises where garbage is created shall provide such premises with a sufficient number of receptacles to contain garbage and rubbish until such time as garbage shall be collected for disposal at a central dump. "Receptacle" shall be defined to mean either: 
(1)  A galvanized metal garbage receptacle with tight-fitting galvanized metal covers; or 
(2)  A mold [molded] plastic garbage receptacle with tight-fitting mold plastic lid. 
Should the use of any particular type of container by a resident result in recurring instances of scattered garbage, debris and resultant unsanitary and unhealthful conditions, the city manager may require the tenant, lessee or occupant to replace the receptacle being used with a more suitable type. 
The city manager, pursuant to § 13-17, may mandate use of uniform containers, such as "totes" to be used for all residential customers within the city. 
(b)  All such containers for garbage or rubbish shall be equipped for easy handling and shall not be filled above the top edge thereof, or so as likely to spill their contents either from bottom, sides or top, when being picked up and dumped into the collecting conveyance. Receptacles that are badly broken or otherwise fail to meet the requirements of this article may be deemed to be rubbish by the city or waste collector, and, after due notice to the users, be collected as rubbish by the waste collector. 
(c)  Receptacles for garbage or rubbish shall be kept clean and sanitary by the owner or occupants of the premises on which they are located. 
(d)  Rubbish and garbage receptacles shall be placed in a location convenient for collection, no earlier than twelve (12) hours before the regularly established collection time, which location shall be one that is acceptable to the city manager, and shall be placed in such location in a manner that will not cause a nuisance or create a public eyesore, and such empty receptacles shall be removed and returned to the private property of the owner or occupants of the premises from which they were placed for collection, within twelve (12) hours after collection and no later. 
(e)  Garbage and rubbish shall be enclosed and sealed in one (1) or more plastic bags prior to placement in the hard-sided container for pickup. Such bags shall be of sufficient size and weight to prevent loss during transfer from garbage container to the waste haulers truck. No person shall place garbage in receptacles provided for the accumulation of garbage without first draining, provided this shall not apply to restaurants, hotels and other places where food is handled commercially. Garbage containers placed out for pickup shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight and thirty-two (32) gallons in volume. 
(f)  No person shall place or cause to be placed in regular rubbish or garbage receptacles any explosive or highly inflammable materials. All such materials shall be disposed of under the supervision and direction of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.05; Ord. No. 108, § 7-4.05, 8-21-72; Ord. No. 199, 11-16-79; Ord. No. 472-03, § 1, 10-6-03) 
Sec. 13-20. - Disposition of materials connected with infectious diseases. 
    Removal of wearing apparel, bedding, rubbish or other materials from homes or other places where highly infectious diseases have prevailed shall be performed under the supervision of the health officer of the city. Such rubbish shall not be placed in containers for regular collections of rubbish or garbage. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.05) 
Sec. 13-21. - Reserved. 
Sec. 13-22. - Collection; licensing of collectors. 
(a)  Collection of domestic garbage and rubbish shall be made at least once each week between May 1 and October 15 and at least every two (2) weeks between October 15 and May 1 of each year. Collections from hotels, apartment houses, stores, office buildings, restaurants, institutions and commercial establishments shall be made not less than once each week or more often in accordance with the need as determined by the city manager. The number of receptacles for these institutions shall be adequate to contain the waste materials. Multiple dwellings in which each unit has its own garbage and rubbish receptacles, for the purpose of this section, shall not be deemed an apartment house. 
(b)  Except as provided herein no person shall engage in the business of the collection and disposal of garbage and rubbish in this city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(c)  Every person required to secure a license by the terms of this chapter shall first make written application therefor in the manner and form provided by chapter 14. The application shall contain an agreement on the part of the applicant that he will comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter and rules promulgated hereunder, and that the license may be revoked at any time for cause by the city manager. The granting or revocation of such license shall be discretionary with the city manager, providing that any person feeling aggrieved by the city manager's decision may appeal to the city commission, whose decision shall be final. 
(d)  The city may undertake the general collection of garbage and rubbish throughout the city, or it may let a contract to one or more persons for making such collections in whole or in part. The city may pay therefor such reasonable amount as the city commission shall determine. All such contractors shall enter into a bond in such amounts as may be set from time to time by resolution of the city commission to be approved by the city attorney conditioned for the faithful performance of their contracts and they will collect all garbage and rubbish in accordance with this chapter. 
(e)  All vehicles for the transportation of garbage or rubbish shall have metal lined bodies, shall be watertight, and be so constructed that no leakage can escape from such vehicle while transporting garbage and rubbish. The body of such vehicle shall be kept covered at all times except when being loaded or unloaded. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.06; Ord. No. 338-90, § 1, 7-23-90) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 13-23. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 414-96, § 2, adopted Oct. 21, 1996, deleted § 13-23, burning of garbage, trash, rubbish, etc., derived from the 1957 Code, § 7-4.04; and Ord. No. 361-91, § 1, adopted Dec. 2, 1991. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and control, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 13-24. - Hauling. 
(a)  No person shall use or cause to be used any truck, wagon, cart, trailer or vehicle for hauling garbage, rubbish, or ashes, unless the box of such vehicle shall be so constructed as to prevent the scattering, dropping, or spilling of the contents thereof on the streets, alleys or other public places of the city. 
(b)  No person shall load or cause to be loaded any truck, wagon, cart, trailer or other vehicle above the side or end board thereof, or in any other manner so that the contents shall be scattered, dropped or spilled on the streets or alleys of the city. 
(c)  No person shall haul shavings, sawdust, dirt, ashes, mortar, lime or other substances likely to be blown about by the wind unless the same shall be securely covered by canvas or other suitable material. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.02) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 13-25. - Unlawful accumulation; abatement. 
(a)  No person owning or occupying any lot or building or premises in this city shall allow any garbage or rubbish to accumulate and remain upon such lot or premises for a period of time in excess of that herein stated as the "frequency of collection"; provided, however, this section shall not apply to lands designated as garbage or rubbish dumps or sanitary landfills. 
(b)  Whenever any person owning or occupying any lot, building or premises in this city permits or allows garbage or rubbish to accumulate and remain upon such lot or premises for a period longer than that permitted in subsection (a), the city manager may order the garbage or rubbish removed. 
(1)  The city manager shall give the owner or agent thereof a notice in writing, in accordance with section 1-8, ordering that the garbage or rubbish be removed within fifteen (15) days from the date of such notice; provided, however, that where the city manager finds an emergency to exist, the city manager may order that the garbage or rubbish be removed immediately. 
(2)  If, after the expiration of the designated time, the garbage or rubbish has not been removed, the city manager may direct that the garbage or rubbish be removed. 
(3)  At the next regular meeting of the city commission, the city manager shall present to the commission a certified copy of the notice served upon the owner or agent thereof, together with a statement in writing and signed by the city manager, showing the record title, the legal description of such premises, that garbage or rubbish had been allowed to accumulate contrary to this section, that such garbage or rubbish was not removed in accordance with the notice, that its removal was made as directed by the city manager, and the cost expended to effect the removal. 
(4)  The commission shall thereupon levy against such property a special assessment to defray the cost and expense to the city of having the garbage or rubbish removed. This assessment shall stand as a charge against the property so assessed as taxes. The same shall be collected and payment enforced in the same manner as other city taxes. 
(Code 1957, § 7-4.03) 
Secs. 13-26-13-37. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LITTER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Distribution of handbills, Ch. 3, Art. II. 

Sec. 13-38. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Aircraft shall mean any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designed for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Authorized private receptacle shall mean a litter storage and collection receptacle constructed so to reasonably confine and retain litter and trash. 
    Garbage shall mean animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter shall mean garbage, refuse, rubbish and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Park shall mean a park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and its inhabitants, and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises shall mean any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designated or used wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place shall mean any street, sidewalk, boulevard, alley or other public way and any public park, square, space, grounds or building. 
    Refuse shall mean all solid waste, except body waste, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned motor vehicles and solid market industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish shall mean nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, plastic and similar materials. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
Sec. 13-39. - Placing in receptacles-Required. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk, or other public place within the city except in public receptacles, or in authorized receptacles for collection. 
Sec. 13-40. - Same-So as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
Sec. 13-41. - Sweeping into gutters; cleanliness of sidewalks. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any private or public sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 13-42. - Merchants' duty to keep sidewalks free from litter. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep all premises, including sidewalk, service alleys, and parking area of their business, free of litter. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 13-43. - Throwing from vehicle prohibited. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 13-44. - Vehicle loads. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 13-45. - Parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. 
Sec. 13-46. - Bodies of water. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, stream, ditch, canal or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
Sec. 13-47. - Throwing from aircraft prohibited without permit. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill, or any other object, without obtaining a permit from the city. 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 13-48. - Private property. 
    It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to throw, deposit, keep or allow to be kept or deposited, or to allow to remain, any litter, garbage, refuse or rubbish on any occupied or unoccupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter, garbage, refuse, or rubbish will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Ord. No. 268-87, § 1, 6-1-87) 
Sec. 13-49. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 268-87, § 2, adopted June 1, 1987, provided for the deletion of § 13-49, requiring the owner to maintain private premises. Such section bore no history note. 
Sec. 13-50. - Vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city whether owned by such person or not. 
Sec. 13-51. - Posting of signs. 
    The public works department of the city is directed to install and maintain adequate signs at appropriate places throughout the city outlining the substance of this article, such signs warning the public that any violations hereof will be prosecuted. In addition, the city clerk is authorized to give proper publicity hereto. 
Secs. 13-52-13-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Regulation of junk dealers and junkyards, Ch. 9, Art. II. 

Sec. 13-63. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
(1)  Junk shall mean any wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, abandoned or discarded appliance, furniture, machinery, vehicles, trailers, all terrain vehicles, off-road vehicles, boats, snowmobiles, and tools of every nature. 
(2)  Owner of real property shall mean any person in possession of any lands under an oral or written lease, the person listed as the real property owner in the tax records of the city assessor or the last grantee in the chain of title at the register of deeds office. 
(3)  Disabled motor vehicle. Disabled motor vehicle shall mean a motor vehicle which is either: 
a.  Dismantled, in whole or in part, or which is unable to be operated on a public street as the result of a mechanical defect, malfunction or absence of properly functioning required safety equipment. A mechanical defect or malfunction includes, but is not limited to, one (1) or more deflated or missing tires, or a motor vehicle resting on supports other than inflated tires. The absence of minor and non-essential parts such as antennas, or ornaments, hub caps, etc., shall not cause a motor vehicle to be deemed dismantled and thus disabled; or 
b.  Not licensed and insured as required by law for operation in the rights-of-way of the streets, alleys or highways of the city. 
(Ord. No. 431-98, § 1, 4-20-98) 
Sec. 13-64. - Keeping prohibited. 
(a)  In general. No owner shall permit any disabled motor vehicle to be parked, placed, or allowed to remain within the City of Sault Ste. Marie in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Prohibited on streets. Disabled motor vehicles shall not be permitted on rights-of-way of the streets, alleys or highways of the city; provided, however, that this prohibition shall not apply to the towing or similar transportation of such vehicles; and provided further, that a reasonable time (not to exceed seventy-two (72) hours from the time of disability) shall be permitted for the removal or servicing of the disabled vehicle in an emergency caused by an accident or sudden breakdown of the vehicle. 
(c)  Prohibited from front, side and rear yards. Disabled motor vehicles or any parts of a motor vehicle shall not be permitted in the front, side, or rear yards of all parcels of land in the city, except as provided below: 
(1)  Disabled motor vehicles or parts of motor vehicles may be kept in an entirely enclosed garage or other entirely enclosed structure; or 
(2)  A disabled motor vehicle is permitted to be stored in conjunction with a permitted gasoline service station, auto repair garage, or a junk yard, as those uses are defined in the city zoning ordinance, subject to the zoning ordinance regulations controlling the location and the operation of such uses, and provided that such use has all appropriate licenses and zoning approvals. 
(Ord. No. 431-98, § 1, 4-20-98) 
Sec. 13-65. - Junk regulated. 
    With the exception of a lawfully established junk yard conforming to all of the terms and regulations of the city zoning ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to keep or deposit, or allow to be kept or deposited, or allow to remain, any junk on property located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 431-98, § 2, 4-20-98) 
Sec. 13-66. - Public nuisance. 
    The presence of junk and/or disabled vehicle or vehicles, in violation of the provisions of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 431-98, § 2, 4-20-98) 
Secs. 13-67-13-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RECYCLING AND COMPOSTING 

Sec. 13-100. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
    City designated disposal facility: A facility which the city has identified from time to time as an approved location for the disposal of refuse, leaves, yard waste, and/or recyclable materials. 
    City refuse bag: A bag sold by the City of Sault Ste. Marie as a suitable container for the purpose of residential refuse collection. 
    City refuse tag: A tag sold by the City of Sault Ste. Marie which may be attached to an acceptable refuse container for the purposes of residential refuse collection. 
    Commingled: Source-separated, nonputrescible recyclable materials that have been mixed at the source of generation (i.e., placed in the same container). 
    Compostables: Yard waste to include grass clippings, leaves and brush trimmings which are less than one-quarter-inch in diameter or less than a standard pencil in diameter. 
    Newspaper: All newsprint and materials that are a part of a newspaper only. 
    Recyclable material: A material which would otherwise become solid waste, which can be collected, separated or processed and returned to the economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products. 
    Recycling drop off: Any facility designed and operated solely for the receiving and storing of source separated, nonputrescible metal, glass, paper, plastic containers and cardboard. 
    Site of generation: Any premises in the City of Sault Ste. Marie in or on which solid waste or recyclable materials is generated by any person. 
    Solid waste: Garbage, refuse and other discarded materials resulting from industrial, commercial and agricultural operations and from domestic and community activities, and shall include all other waste materials, including liquids. 
    Source separate: To separate recyclable materials from the solid waste stream at the point of waste generation. 
    Yard waste: All grass, weeds, leaves, small twigs and shrub clippings, flowers and basic waste materials resulting from landscaping. 
    Yard waste collection season: A period each year as scheduled by the city manager during which a yard waste collection service is provided in specified areas of the city. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-101. - Purpose. 
(a)  The City of Sault Ste. Marie finds that the reduction of the amount of solid waste and conservation of recyclable materials is an important public purpose. 
(b)  The separation and collection of paper, cardboard, glass, cans and vegetative yard waste for recycling from the residential, commercial and institutional establishments in this municipality will minimize the adverse environmental effects of landfilling by reducing the need for landfills and conserving existing landfill capacity, facilitate the implementation and operation of other forms of resource recovery, conserve natural resources and reduce the cost of solid waste disposal in general. The promotion and use of recyclable materials, goods produced from recyclable materials and goods which facilitate recycling, will further serve the same purposes by encouraging and facilitating recycling. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-102. - Police powers. 
(a)  The city manager and those assistants and employees of the city designated by the city manager, shall be authorized to issue warning notices, violation notices, court complaints, civil or criminal, for violation of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  When enforcing the provisions of this article the city manager, assistants, and employees shall be ordinance officers and shall have all the powers of the same as exists under the laws of this state for the purpose of enforcing this article. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-103. - Curbside program established; collection schedule. 
(a)  There is hereby established within the city a program ("curbside program") for the separate collection of compostables and recyclable materials from all residents of the city and from all other persons, including commercial or institutional establishments located inside the city. 
(b)  Separate collections of compostables and recyclable material shall occur in the manner and on the schedule as set forth by the city manager. 
(c)  Such schedules shall be published by the city and shall define the area and dates of collection and the material designated for recycling. 
(d)  All residents and other persons in charge of any premises located within the city areas serviced by the curbside program, established by this article, shall source separate all designated recyclables and compostables and place them between curb and sidewalk where possible at the side of the public right-of-way fronting their premises in the manner designated by this article on the dates specified for collection. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-104. - Preparation of compostables and recyclables for curbside collection. 
(a)  All compostables and recyclables placed at the curbside for collection shall be prepared for collection in accordance with the requirements of this article together with the special requirements as may be set by the city manager. 
(b)  All newspapers shall be placed in paper bags or tied in bundles not exceeding thirty-five (35) pounds in weight nor exceeding one (1) foot in thickness. 
(c)  All brush shall be cut into three-foot lengths or less and tied into bundles weighing not more than thirty-five (35) pounds in weight. No individual piece of brush may exceed six (6) inches in diameter. 
(d)  All compostables must be placed in a city yard waste bag or in a container clearly marked with a city yard waste tag. Compostables not so bagged or tagged will not be picked up. The gross weight of city refuse bags, or containers with city refuse tags, placed for collection shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight. 
(e)  The city may provide brush clipping services upon request of the owner or occupier of any premises. The fee for such services may be set by the city manager, which fee may be requested in advance of such services being rendered. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-105. - Separation of brush, leaves, yard waste and other compostables or recyclables. 
(a)  No person shall dispose of leaves, yard waste, compostables, or designated recyclables, nor arrange for the disposal of the same or cause the same, to be disposed of at any solid waste facility other than at the city designated disposal facility. 
(b)  All persons who gather leaves, yard waste, compostables or designated recyclables, shall source separate the items and place them for collection at the times and in the manner heretofore or hereafter specified by this chapter, article or the city manager. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall prevent any person from gathering leaves for compost, mulch or other gardening purposes. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-106. - Unlawful activities, scavenging. 
(a)  Designated recyclable materials and compostable materials placed at curbside in accordance with this article shall become the exclusive property of the city or the city's authorized agent. There shall be a presumption that the occupier or owner of the premises intended to recycle or compost the material under this article if the material is placed at curbside. It shall be unlawful for any person not duly authorized by the city, to collect, remove, pick up, or cause to be collected, removed, or picked up, any such material. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate, cause to be violated, or assist in the violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or to cause to be placed any material other than compostable or designated recyclable material in or near any recycling drop off or city designated disposal facility. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-107. - Failure to separate. 
    The city, or any other person collecting solid waste generated within the city limits, may refuse to collect solid waste from any person who has failed to source separate designated recyclables or compostables. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-108. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Civil penalties: 
(1)  Any person, firm, partnership or corporation that violates the provisions of sections 13-103, 13-104, or 13-105, of this article shall be deemed responsible for a civil infraction for which a civil fine in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or less may be ordered. 
(2)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs. 
(b)  Criminal penalties: Any person, firm, partnership, or corporation violating any section of this article, other than sections 13-103, 13-104 or 13-105, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable under Section 1-6 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-109. - Other remedies. 
(a)  In addition to any other remedy provided in this article, this municipality may institute a suit in equity where unlawful conduct or public nuisance exists as defined in this article for an injunction to restrain a violation of this article. In addition to an injunction, the court may impose penalties as authorized by section 13-108. 
(b)  The penalties and remedies prescribed by this article shall be deemed concurrent. The existence or exercise of any remedy shall not prevent this municipality from exercising any other remedy provided by this article or otherwise provided at law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-110. - Authority, costs, notice to remove solid waste. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to notify, in writing, the owner and/or tenant(s) of any premises to remove solid waste found to be not in compliance with this chapter or article on such premises unless the same is on the abutting public right-of-way in which case no notice is required. Such notice shall be by hand delivery or certified mail, addressed to the said owner and/or tenant(s) at the last known address. 
(b)  If solid wastes are not removed from the premises within six (6) days after the date of mailing such notice, or if the solid waste is on abutting public right-of-way, the owner and/or tenant(s) of the premises shall be subject to penalties as set forth in section 13-108(b) of this article. The city manager is also hereby authorized and empowered to pay for the removal of the solid waste or to order the removal [of the solid waste] by the city. 
(c)  When the city has effected the removal of such solid waste or has paid for its removal, the actual cost thereof, plus accrued interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month from the date of removal, shall be charged to the owner of the premises on the next regular tax bill forwarded to such owner by the city, and said charge shall be due and payable at the time of payment of such tax bill. 
(d)  Where cost of removal is not paid by the owner within sixty (60) days after the removal of such solid waste as set forth in parts (b) and (c) of this section, then the city manager shall cause to be recorded in the treasurer's office the date and premises on which removal was done. The recording of such statement shall constitute a lien on the property and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest until final payment has been made and shall be collected in the manner provided by law for collection of taxes; further, the total amount shall be subject to a delinquency penalty of one (1) percent per month in the event same is not paid in full on or before the date of the tax bill upon which said charge appears becomes delinquent; said sworn statements recorded in accordance with the provisions hereof shall be notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interest, constitutes a charge against the premises described in the statement that the same is due. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-111. - Refuse bag and tag specifications. 
(a)  City refuse bags shall be of a distinctive color or material and printed with the city seal or other appropriate words which indicate to refuse collectors that the refuse bags are intended for residential refuse collection service. 
(b)  City refuse tags shall be of a distinctive color, and printed with the city seal or other appropriate words which indicate to refuse collectors that when the tag is affixed to a refuse container it is intended for residential collection. 
(c)  Specifications for city refuse bags and tags and their use, and any future changes to those specifications shall be developed in accordance with this article. Those specifications shall include, but shall not be limited to, the materials used and the content of printed information. 
(d)  The city refuse bags and tags shall be sold at a price determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(e)  The city or its authorized representatives may sell city refuse bags and tags to individuals and/or retail sales establishments. Participating sales establishments shall sell city refuse bags and tags for not more than the maximum price specified by the city commission. However, the appropriate sales tax may be charged by the retail establishment if so required by state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-112. - Yard bag and tag specifications. 
(a)  City yard waste bags shall be of a distinctive color or material and printed with the city seal or other appropriate words which indicate to yard waste collectors that the bags are intended for residential yard waste collection service. 
(b)  City yard waste tags shall be of a distinctive color and printed with the city seal or other appropriate words which indicate to yard waste collectors that when the tag is affixed to yard waste container, it is intended for residential yard waste collection service. 
(c)  Specifications for city yard waste bags and their use and any future changes to those specifications shall be developed in accordance with this article. These specifications shall include, but shall not be limited to, the materials used and the content of printed information. 
(d)  City yard waste bags shall be sold at a price determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(e)  The city or its authorized representatives may sell city yard waste bags to individuals and/or to retail sales establishments. Participating sales establishments shall sell city yard waste bags for not more than the maximum price specified by the city commission. However, the appropriate sales tax may be charged by the retail establishment if so required by state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 13-113. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city manager shall promulgate rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The rules and regulations shall be enforceable in the same manner as set forth in section 13-108. 
(Ord. No. 343-90, § 1, 9-17-90) 
Chapter 14 - LICENSES AND PERMITS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to license, § 2.3(r). 
Cross reference- License for bowling, pool and billiards, Ch. 6, Art. II, Div. 2; license for public dance halls and dances, Ch. 6, Art. III, Div. 2; licenses for carnivals, circuses and other similar exhibitions, Ch. 6, Art. IV, Div. 2; license for transitory shows and exhibitions, Ch. 6, Art. V, Div. 2; license required for slaughtering of animals for human consumption, § 7-2; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; licenses for electrical work, Ch. 8, Art. III, Div. 2; license for drain laying, Ch. 8, Art. IV, Div. 2; businesses and business regulations, Ch. 9; license required for junk dealers, § 9-24; license for peddlers, Ch. 9, Art. III, Div. 2; license for solicitors and canvassers, Ch. 9, Art. IV, Div. 2; license for transient and itinerant merchants and vendors, Ch. 9, Art. V, Div. 2; license for dealers of used automobiles and parts, § 9-129; license for auctioneers, Ch. 9, Art. VII, Div. 2; license for pawnbrokers, § 9-172; license for massage parlors, Ch. 9, Art. IX, Div. 2; permit for blasting, § 12-65; licenses for storage of explosives, § 12-66; license for operation of gasoline service station, § 12-76; permit for use of hazardous chemicals, § 12-90; licensing of garbage and rubbish collectors, § 13-22; permit for throwing objects from aircraft, § 13-47; permit for setting off fireworks, § 16-60; permit to use loud instruments to attract attention, § 18-7(9); sign erector's licenses, § 20-40 et seq.; permit for placing or removing of poles and wires, § 22-46; bicycle license, Ch. 24, Art. IV, Div. 2; permit for cutting, trimming, etc., trees in public places, § 25-18; permit to plant certain species of trees on private property, § 25-21; license for taxicabs, Ch. 26, Art. II, Div. 2. 

Sec. 14-1. - Required. 
    No person shall engage or be engaged in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business, or privilege for which any license, permit or fee is required by this Code without first obtaining a license or permit from the city clerk in the manner provided for in this chapter and by the sections of this Code requiring such license or permit. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.01) 
Sec. 14-2. - Application; oath. 
    Unless otherwise provided in the section requiring a license or permit, such person required to obtain a license or permit from the city to engage in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business or privilege shall make application for such license or permit to the city clerk upon forms provided by the clerk. All statements required to be made as to facts which are required or which are applicable to the issuing of any license or permit required by this city shall be made under oath or affirmation, if so required by the city clerk. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.03) 
Sec. 14-3. - Investigation of application. 
    The city clerk may refer any application for a license or permit to the appropriate city official or department for an investigation and recommendation on matters pertaining to the exercise of the license or permit applied for, and the city clerk may require the giving of fingerprints and such other information as may be necessary to establish the identity of the applicant. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.04) 
Sec. 14-4. - Conditions of issuance. 
    No license or permit shall be granted or delivered until the applicant therefor has complied with all the conditions precedent to its issuance, as set forth in the sections of this Code requiring such license or permit. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.02) 
Sec. 14-5. - State license or permit prerequisite to issuance. 
    No license or permit required by this Code shall be issued to any person who is required to have a license or permit from the state until such person shall submit evidence of securing such state license or permit. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.05) 
Sec. 14-6. - Fees; schedule. 
(a)  No license or permit shall be issued under this Code except upon payment of the fee therefor provided for in this Code; provided, however, that no license fee shall be required to be paid by any person who is exempt from the payment of such fee by any provision of state or federal law. Such person shall comply with all other provisions or requirements in connection with the issuance of the license. 
(b)  The license issued by the city clerk shall constitute a receipt for the license fee paid. 
(c)  The city commission from time to time will determine which activities undertaken inside the city will require the issuance of a license or permit. All licenses and permits presently established will remain in effect until modified by city commission resolution. 
    All fees and charges for the above stated license and permit shall be as presently established or as changed from time to time by the city commission. 
(d)  With respect to sign permits a double permit fee will be charged if the construction and/or erection of a sign is started before issuance of the permit but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve said persons from the responsibility of fully complying with the requirements of this article in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed herein. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.07; Code 1957, Ch. 9, Art. 2; Ord. No. 3, § 1, 7-1-57; Ord. No. 233-83, § 1, 3-21-83; Ord. No. 245-85, § 1, 7-1-85; Ord. No. 281-87, § 1, 9-14-87; Ord. No. 288-88, § 1, 2-15-88; Ord. No. 375-93, § 1, 6-21-93) 
Sec. 14-7. - Termination. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this Code, a license or permit shall begin on May first of each year and shall terminate on April thirtieth of the following year. Annual licenses issued after May first in any year shall terminate on April thirtieth of the following year. In all cases where the provisions of this Code permit the issuance of licenses for a period of less than one year, any license so issued shall become effective on the date of the issuance thereof and shall terminate at the end of the period for which it is issued. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.08) 
Sec. 14-8. - Renewal. 
    Applications for the renewal of any license shall be considered to be and shall be treated in the same manner as an original application for such license. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.09) 
Sec. 14-9. - Carrying and display. 
    No person to whom a license or permit has been issued shall fail to carry such license or permit upon the person thereof when engaged in the operation, conduct or carrying on of the trade, profession, business or privilege for which the license was issued; except that where such trade, profession, business or privilege is operated, conducted or carried on at a fixed place or establishment, such license or permit shall be exhibited at all times in some conspicuous place in such place or establishment. No person shall fail to produce any license or permit issued by the city when requested to do so by any city police or health officer or by any person representing the issuing authority. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.12) 
Sec. 14-10. - Prohibited display. 
    No person shall display any expired license or permit or any license or permit for which a duplicate has been issued. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.13) 
Sec. 14-11. - Transferability. 
    Licenses or permits issued by this city shall not be transferable, unless specifically authorized under this Code, and then only in accordance with the provisions thereof. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.14) 
Sec. 14-12. - Suspension or revocation. 
    Any license or permit required by this Code may be suspended or revoked, or the renewal thereof refused, for misrepresentation of any material fact in the application for such license or permit or for any good cause by the city manager. The term "good cause" as used in this section shall mean any act, omission, or the permitting of a condition to exist, with respect to the license or permit in question, which is: 
(1)  Contrary to the health, morals, safety or welfare of the public; 
(2)  Unlawful or fraudulent; 
(3)  A violation of the section under which the license or permit was issued; 
(4)  Beyond the scope of the license or permit issued; 
(5)  A fact, circumstance or condition which, had it existed or been known to the issuing authority at the time the license or permit was issued, would have been sufficient grounds for the refusal thereof; 
(6)  The sale or offering for sale of any article or commodity purporting to be in quantities of standard weight or measure, when the same is not actually of the weight or measure purported; 
(7)  The sale or offering for sale of any defective, faulty, incomplete or deteriorated articles of merchandise, when the goods are not so represented to the purchaser or prospective customers; 
(8)  Any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.10) 
Sec. 14-13. - Appeal of denial, suspension or revocation. 
    An applicant for any license or permit who has been refused such license or permit, or whose license or permit has been revoked or suspended, for any reason, by the authorized issuing officer or the city manager, unless an appeal is provided to another agency by the section of this Code requiring such license or permit, may appeal such action to the commission by setting forth all the facts in written petition and filing the same with the city clerk within fourteen (14) days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last-known address. The city clerk shall submit such petition and a report by the clerk or the report of the officer taking such action to the commission before its next regular meeting. The city commission shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in writing of the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee or permittee at the last-known address of such licensee or permittee at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing. The commission may act on the petition upon the facts set forth therein or may grant a further hearing to the applicant. The decision of the commission on such appeal shall be final. 
(Code 1957, §§ 9-1.06, 9-1.11) 
Sec. 14-14. - Clerk's records. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record of all applications for licenses or permits made under this Code, indicating whether the license or permit applied for in each case has been issued or withheld, and if withheld, the reason therefor. 
(Code 1957, § 9-1.15) 
Chapter 15 - MINORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Age requirement for license for bowling, pool and billiards, § 6-28; curfew for minors at transitory shows and exhibitions, § 6-91; loitering by minors prohibited on premises of junk dealers, § 9-26; purchases by dealers of used automobiles and parts from minors prohibited, § 9-130; issuance of massage parlor licenses to minors prohibited, § 9-195(3); operation of off-road vehicles, §§ 24-159, 24-160. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Curfew. 
(a)  No person under the age of sixteen (16) years shall loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon any public street, highway, road, alley, park, public building, place of amusement or entertainment, vacant lot or other unsupervised place after the hour of 10:00 p.m. or before the hour of 6:00 a.m. unless such minor is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other responsible adult person, having the care and custody of such minor or unless the minor is upon an emergency errand or legitimate business directed by a parent, guardian or other responsible adult person, having the care and custody of the minor, or unless such a minor has been in attendance at a function sponsored by a church, school, civic or fraternal organization and is returning home from such a function at an hour not later than 12:30 a.m. 
(b)  Any person of the age of sixteen (16) years or over, including but not limited to parents and guardians, assisting, aiding, abetting, allowing, permitting or encouraging any minor under the age of sixteen (16) years to violate the provisions of section 15-1(a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1957, § 6-2.01; Ord. No. 215-81, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-81) 
State Law reference- Curfew for minors, MCL § 722.751 et seq., MSA § 28.342(1) et seq. 
Sec. 15-2. - Misrepresentation of age. 
(a)  No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall falsely represent himself to be of the age of eighteen (18) or over when purchasing or procuring, offering to purchase or procure, or attempting to purchase or procure beer, wine or other alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  No person shall make any false representation concerning the age of another under the age of eighteen (18) years in order to procure the sale or furnishing of beer, wine or other alcoholic beverages to the minor. 
(c)  No person shall give false information concerning the age of a person under the age of eighteen (18) years to any law enforcement officer when such officer has good reason for requesting such information. 
(Code 1957, § 6-2.02) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL §§ 750.141c, 750.141d; MSA §§ 28.336(3), 28.336(4). 
Sec. 15-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 581-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 15-3, in its entirety. Former § 15-3 pertained to "Soliciting and peddling," and was derived from Code 1957, § 6-2.03. 
Sec. 15-4. - Responsibility of parents and guardians. 
    No parent, guardian or other adult person, having the care and custody of a person under the age of eighteen (18) years, shall permit such minor to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1957, § 6-2.04) 
Sec. 15-5. - Complaint under juvenile laws when found to be incorrigible, neglected or delinquent. 
    If investigation discloses that any minor violating the provisions of this article is an incorrigible, a neglected, or a delinquent child, a complaint shall be made by the chief of police, city manager or judge of competent jurisdiction under the juvenile laws of the state. 
(Code 1957, § 6-2.01) 
Secs. 15-6-15-26. - Reserved. 
Chapter 16 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES AND PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Public place defined. 
    "Public place" as used elsewhere in this chapter shall be deemed to include the grounds and buildings of any public or private elementary or secondary school located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 6-3.01(gg), 12-17-73) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 16-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 542-13, adopted December 2, 2013, repealed § 16-2 in its entirety. Former § 16-2 pertained to begging and was derived from Code 1957, § 6-3.01(o). 
Sec. 16-3. - Loitering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on any street or sidewalk or in a park or public building or conduct themselves in any public place so as to obstruct the free and uninterrupted passage of the public. 
(Code 1957, § 6-3.01(n)) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Disorderly persons, MCL § 750.167, MSA § 28.364. 
Sec. 16-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-4, in its entirety. Former § 16-4, pertained to "Illegal businesses," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-5. - Frequenting unlawful establishments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to attend, frequent, operate, own or be an occupant or inmate of any place where prostitution, gambling, the illegal sale of intoxicating liquor, or any other illegal or immoral business or occupation is permitted or conducted. 
(Code 1957, § 6-3.01(r)) 
State Law reference- Frequenting gaming places, MCL § 750.309, MSA § 28.541. 
Sec. 16-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-6, in its entirety. Former § 16-6, pertained to "Inciting, inducing or exhorting commission of offense," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-7, in its entirety. Former § 16-7, pertained to "Obstructing, resisting officers," and was derived from Code 1957, § 6-3.01(n). 
Sec. 16-8. - Falsely personating public officers. 
    Any persons who falsely assume or pretend to be an officer or employee of this city, and shall take upon themselves to act as such, or to require any person to aid and assist them in any matter pertaining to their duties, or shall falsely take upon themselves to act or officiate in any office or place of authority, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; police, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 750.215, MSA § 28.412. 
Sec. 16-9. - Spitting in public. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit on any sidewalk or on the floor or seat of any public carrier, or on any floor, wall, seat or equipment of any place of public assemblage. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 16-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-10, in its entirety. Former § 16-10, pertained to "Playing in streets," and was derived from Code 1957, § 7-1.05. 
Sec. 16-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-11, in its entirety. Former § 16-11, pertained to "Possessing instruments for commission of crime," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-12. - Possessing or consuming alcoholic beverages in schools, city buildings, etc. 
(a)  No person shall possess or consume any alcoholic beverage, including, but not limited to, intoxicating liquors, beer and wine, in any building owned by the city, when posted, including any building which may be leased by the city for special events, or in any elementary or high school building located within the city. 
(b)  No person shall consume or possess any alcoholic beverage, including, but not limited to, intoxicating liquors, beer and wine in a container which is uncapped or upon which the seal is broken in or upon any public street, walkway, alley or right-of-way or any public or private parking area which is open to or accessible to the public and not otherwise posted or authorized by special license and/or previous approval by authorities within the city. 
(Ord. No. 94, § 6-3.01(ee), 2-7-72; Ord. No. 230-82, § 1, 11-1-82) 
Sec. 16-13. - School premises-Unlawful entering or remaining on school grounds. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into or remain in any public, private or parochial school building or enter or remain upon any grounds of such a school on days in which school is in session who is not a regularly enrolled student thereof or an employee thereof, or who is not lawfully attending school-sponsored or school-authorized activities therein, unless such person shall have immediately upon entry proceeded to the administrative offices of such school and shall have identified themselves and have stated their business to the principal or to the principal's representative, and shall have thereafter received permission of the principal or the duly authorized representative of the principal to remain upon such school grounds or in such school building for the purpose of transacting such business as so stated. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into or remain in any public, private or parochial school building or upon the grounds of such school between the hours of sunset and sunrise, unless such person is participating in or attending as a spectator at some school-authorized or school-sponsored activity. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 6-3.01(ff), (gg), 12-17-73) 
Sec. 16-14. - Same-Disrupting classes. 
    Any person who shall by acts, words, conduct or mere presence unlawfully divert or unlawfully tend to divert the attention of pupils, teachers, or other persons from the normal instructional program of a public or private school shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 16-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-15, in its entirety. Former § 16-15, pertained to "Same-Borrowing from students," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-16. - Abandoned refrigerator. 
    Any person who knowingly leaves, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container of a kind and size sufficient to permit the entrapment and suffocation of a child therein, without first removing the snaplock or other locking device from the lid or cover thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 750.493d., MSA § 28.761(4). 
Sec. 16-17. - Catching fish by "snagging" unlawful. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to snag or attempt to snag any fish within the corporate limits of the city, except that the city manager may designate an area for those persons who are authorized by law to snag. It shall be further unlawful to possess any snagging apparatus, and the possession of such apparatus within one hundred fifty (150) feet of waters where fish are found, shall be prima facie evidence of attempt to snag. 
(b)  As used in this section: 
Snagging means the taking or the attempt to take fish by a hook, either barbed or unbarbed, through penetration of some part of the fish's body other than the mouth. 
Snagging apparatus means any pointed hook, barbed or unbarbed, attached to a line or pole in such manner that the weight or sinker is on or below the shank of the hook, or any hook used without bait or lure for fishing. 
(c)  Any person shall upon conviction of violation of this section be punished by fine not to exceed the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00), by confiscation of snagging apparatus in possession and by imprisonment in the Chippewa County Jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, at the discretion of the trial court. 
(Ord. No. 237-83, §§ 2-4, 8-17-83) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 237-83, §§ 2-4, adopted Aug. 17, 1983, did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as § 16-17, has been at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 16-18. - Rotary Park maximum age limitation for fishing. 
(a)  The area of water bounded on the northeast by Rotary Park Island and its causeway and bounded on the southwest by Portage Ave/Riverside Drive shall be known as the city children's fishing pond. 
(b)  No person seventeen (17) years of age or older shall be allowed to engage in the act of fishing in the city children's fishing pond except as provided in subsection (c). 
(c)  An intellectual and developmental disabilities person or resident of a home for the aged who has been issued a permit pursuant to MCL 324.43515 shall be allowed to fish in the city children's fishing pond. It shall be a rebuttable presumption of this section that a person age seventeen (17) years or over has not been issued a permit under MCL 324.43515. 
(d)  Fishing is defined by MCL 324.43503 or any amendatory statute relating to this section. 
(Ord. No. 476-04, § 1, 5-17-04; Ord. No. 548-14, 4-21-14) 
Secs. 16-19-16-27. - Reserved.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-32, in its entirety. Former § 16-32, pertained to "Nonsupport," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-33. - Unlawful discrimination in housing and/or real property. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. 
(1)  In furthering the policy of the state as expressed in its Constitution and other laws; in order that the safety and general welfare, peace and health of all the inhabitants of the city may be ensured, it is hereby declared the policy of the city, to assure equal opportunity to all residents, regardless of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or physical disability to live in decent, sanitary, healthful, standard living quarters. 
(2)  It is the policy of the city that no owner, lessee, sub-lessee, assignee, managing agent, or other person, firm or corporation having the right to sell, rent, lease (or otherwise control) any housing accommodation and/or real property within the city, or any agent of these shall refuse to sell, rent, lease, or otherwise deny to or withhold from any person or group of persons such housing accommodations and/or real property because of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability of such person or persons or discriminate against any person or persons because of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed or disability in the conditions, terms, privileges of the sale, rental or lease of any housing accommodation and/or real property or in the furnishing of facilities and/or services in connection therewith. 
(3)  Relocation shall be carried out in a manner that will promote maximum choice within the community's total housing supply; lessen racial, ethnic, and economic concentrations; and facilitate desegregation and racially inclusive patterns of occupancy and use of public and private facilities. 
(b)  Definitions. Unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context, the following terms shall have the meaning as described in this subsection and as used in this section. 
    Decent, sanitary, healthful standard living quarters means housing which is in sound, clean, and weather tight condition in conformance with applicable local, state, and national codes. 
    Discriminate or discrimination mean any difference expressed in any way toward a person or persons in the terms of the sale, exchange, lease, rental or financing for housing accommodation and/or real property in regard to such sale, exchange, rental, lease or finance because of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability of such person. 
    Housing accommodation includes any building, structure, or portion thereof which is used or occupied, maintained, arranged or designed to be used or occupied as a home, residence or sleeping place of one (1) or more human beings, or any real estate so used, designed or intended for such use. 
    Financial institution means any person, institution or business entity of any kind which loans money to persons and receives as security for said loans a secured interest of any kind in the real property of the borrower. 
    Owner means any person/persons who hold legal or equitable title to, or own any beneficial interest in any real property or who hold legal or equitable title to shares of, or hold any beneficial interest in any real estate cooperative which owns any real property and/or housing accommodations. 
    Real estate broker means any person, partnership, association, corporation and/or agent thereof, who for a fee or other valuable consideration offers, sells, purchases, exchanges or rents, or negotiates for the sale, purchase, exchange or rental of a housing accommodation and/or real property of another, or collects rental for the use of housing accommodation and/or real property of another. 
    Real property means any real estate, vacant land, building, structure or housing accommodations within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any owner of real estate, lessee, sub-lessee, real estate broker or salesman, financial institution or employee of the financial institution, advertiser, or agent of any or all of the foregoing, to discriminate against any person or persons because of their race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability with regard to the sale, exchange or rental, or any dealing concerning any housing accommodation and/or real property. 
    In addition to the foregoing, it shall also be unlawful for any real estate broker or employee thereof, owner or other person, or financial institution dealing with housing or real property in the city: 
(1)  To discriminate against any person in the availability of or the price, terms, conditions, or privileges of any kind relating to the sale, rental, lease, or occupancy of any housing accommodation or real property in the city or in furnishing of any facilities or services in connection therewith. 
(2)  To publish or circulate, or cause to be published or circulated, any notice, statement or advertisement, or to announce a policy, or to use any form of application, for the purchase, lease, rental or financing of real property, or to make any record of inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase, rental or lease of such real estate, which expresses directly or indirectly any discrimination as to race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed or disability of any person. 
(3)  To discriminate in connection with lending money, guaranteeing loans, accepting mortgages or otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the purchase, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of any housing accommodation and/or real property. 
(4)  To solicit for sale, lease, or listing for the sale or lease, of any housing accommodation and/or real property on the grounds of loss of value because of the present or prospective entry into any neighborhood of any person or persons of any particular race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability. 
(5)  To distribute or cause to be distributed, written material or statements designed to induce any owner of any housing accommodation and/or real property to sell or lease his or her property because of any present or prospective change in the race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability of persons in the neighborhood. 
(6)  To make any misrepresentations concerning the listing for sale or the anticipated listing for sale or the sale of any housing accommodation and/or real property for the purpose of inducing or attempting to induce the sale or listing for sale of any housing accommodation and/or real property by representing that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of any particular race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability in the area will or may result in the lowering of property values in the block, neighborhood or area in which the property is located. 
(7)  For an owner to solicit any real estate broker to sell, rent or otherwise deal with such owner's housing accommodations and/or real property with any limitation on its sale based on race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability. 
(8)  For an owner to refuse to sell, rent, or otherwise deal with any housing accommodation and/or real property because of race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry, sex, creed, or disability of the proposed buyer or tenant. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. This section shall in no way abrogate or impair the right of the city, to specifically enforce, by any legal means, any of the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 567-16, §§ 1-4, 7-5-16) 
Secs. 16-34-16-43. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 

Sec. 16-59. - Disturbing the peace generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb the peace, quiet or good order of any neighborhood by loud, boisterous or vulgar conduct. 
(Code 1957, § 6-3.01(j), (k)) 
Sec. 16-60. - Fireworks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite, discharge, or use any fireworks in the city in a manner that allows the waste materials of the device to land upon any public or private land not owned by the person. MCL 28.451 et seq. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite, discharge, or use any fireworks on any public property including any streets or rights-of-way. It shall be unlawful for any person to set off any fireworks on any private property not owned by the person unless they have expressed permission of the property owner. MCL 28.451 et seq. 
(c)  (1)  It shall be lawful for any person to ignite, discharge, or use any fireworks between the hours of: 11:00 a.m. December 31 until 1:00 a.m. the immediate following January 1; 
11:00 a.m. to 11:45 p.m the Saturday and Sunday immediately preceding Memorial Day; 
11:00 a.m. to 11:45 p.m June 29 through July 4 inclusive; 
11:00 a.m. to 11:45 p.m July 5 but only if that date is a Friday or Saturday; 
11:00 a.m. to 11:45 p.m the Saturday and Sunday immediately preceding Labor Day. MCL 28.457. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite, discharge, or use any fireworks between the hours of 11:00 p.m. to 11:00 a.m. except as allowed in (c)(1) above. MCL 28.457. 
(d)  Notwithstanding subsection (a)-(c) the city clerk may issue a permit to any applicant to allow the applicant to set off fireworks in a manner or place prohibited by this ordinance. 
(e)  A violation of this ordinance shall be assessed a civil fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation of the ordinance and no other fine or sanction. Five hundred dollars ($500.00) of the fine collected under this ordinance shall be remitted to the local law enforcement agency responsible for enforcing the ordinance. MCL 28.457(3). 
(Code 1957, § 6-3.01(z); Ord. No. 540-13, § 1, 8-19-13; Ord. No. 592-19, § 1, 4-1-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 540-13, § 1, adopted August 19, 2013, amended § 16-60 to read as set out herein. Previously § 16-60 was titled setting off fireworks. 
Cross reference- Regulation of explosives and pyrotechnics, Ch. 12, Art. III, Div. 3; licenses and permits, Ch. 14.

Sec. 16-72. - Burlesque shows and live entertainment; specific activities prohibited. 
(a)  Burlesque shows and live entertainment, as herein defined, means the presentation of acts which are presented live for the enjoyment of the audience. 
(b)  No person, firm, corporation or licensee shall present or allow to be presented, or participate in, any live acts which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting, describing or relating to specific sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined below: 
(1)  Specified sexual activities: 
a.  Human genitals in state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
b.  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse, or sodomy; 
c.  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, public region, buttock or female breast. 
(2)  Specified anatomical areas: 
a.  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
1.  human genitals, pubic region; 
2.  buttock; and 
3.  female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
b.  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(c)  Any person, member of a partnership, and/or officer and director of a corporation, violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and be punished by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of not to exceed ninety (90) days for each offense. 
(d)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon that day during or when the violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 243-84, 11-5-84) 
Editor's note- For purposes of classification, provisions enacted by Ord. No. 243-84, relative to specific prohibited live performances and designated as §§ 16-72-16-75, have been included herein as § 16-72(a)-(d).
