ARTICLE VI. - WEAPONS 

Sec. 16-97. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the word "firearms," except as otherwise specifically defined in this Code, shall be construed to include any weapon from which a dangerous projectile may be propelled by using explosives, gas or air as a means of propulsion. 
Sec. 16-98. - Exemptions. 
    Police officers, peace officers and persons in the military service, in pursuit of official duty, and persons duly authorized by federal or state law to carry firearms, are exempt from the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 16-99. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-99, in its entirety. Former § 16-99, pertained to "Transportation," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-100. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-, in its entirety. Former § 16-, pertained to "Minors," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-101. - Unlawful handling and discharging of guns. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to draw, handle, flourish, fire, or set off any gun in any street, alley, park, or other public place except under the conditions enumerated below: 
(1)  This restriction shall not apply to any police officer acting in the line of duty; 
(2)  This restriction shall not apply to black powder muzzle loaded guns when the guns are used in conjunction with an organized event sponsored by a legal entity and supervised by representatives of that organization or entity and so long as the discharging of the gun occurs on a shooting range approved by the chief of police and so long as the organization or entity carries one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) of liability insurance naming the city as a co-insured and so long as the public shall be notified by public advertisement as to the time and location of the discharging of the black powder muzzle loaded weapons. 
(b)  The chief of police is enabled by this section to set standards and guidelines for the implementation of the section. 
(Code 1957, § 6-3.01(y); Ord. No. 242-84, §§ 1, 2, 5-22-84) 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. 242-84, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 22, 1984, did not specifically amend the Code, such provisions have been codified as superseding former § 16-101, which pertained to the same subject matter. 
State Law reference- Reckless use and discharge of firearms, MCL § 752.a863, MSA § 28.436(24). 
Sec. 16-102. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 582-18, § 1, adopted May 21, 2018, repealed § 16-102, in its entirety. Former § 16-102, pertained to "BB guns; use by minors, prohibition, exception," and was derived from Original Code. 
Sec. 16-103. - Destroying or injuring property by careless, reckless or negligent use of bow or arrow. 
    Any person who, because of carelessness, recklessness or negligence, but not willfully or wantonly, shall cause or allow any bow or arrow under such person's control to be used so as to destroy or injure the property of another, real or personal, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Cross reference- See also § 16-103. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 752.882, MSA § 28.436(32). 
Sec. 16-104. - Throwing missiles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or propel any ball, snowball, stone, stick, brick, bottle, glass or other missile in or into any street, lane, alley or other public place. 
(Code 1957, § 6-3.01(w)) 
Sec. 16-105. - Bow or arrow usage inside the city limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any bow or arrow inside the city limits unless: 
(1)  A special permit is issued by the chief of police for usage on public property; or 
(2)  The bow and/or arrow is used upon private property with the express consent of the owner; and 
(3)  All arrows fired by the bow remain upon the private property at all times while in flight. 
Violation of this Section shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 267-87, § 1, 6-1-87) 
Cross reference- See also, § 16-103. 
Sec. 16-106. - St. Mary's River, mainland, and island prohibited area for firearms. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to draw, handle, flourish, fire, or set off any firearm, except pursuant to a permit issued by the chief of police, in the area of the city described as follows: 
Beginning at a point on the intersection of the west line of fractional Section six, township forty-seven north of range one east and the north right-of-way of West Pier Drive (formerly Portage Avenue) and being the brass disk in the historical stone monument marking the Michigan Meridian; thence running from said point easterly along the northerly right-of-way line of West Pier Drive to West Portage Avenue; thence continuing in a more or less easterly direction along the north right-of-way of West Portage Avenue to Riverside Drive; thence continuing easterly and southerly along the north right-of-way of Riverside Drive to an intersecting point on the south line of fractional section 15, Township 47 North of range 1 east; thence easterly along the south line extended of said fractional section 15 to a point in the center of the principal or tug channel of the branch of the St. Mary's River entering into Lake Nicolet (former Hay Lake) and being the most southeasterly point of the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan as of the year 2005; thence northerly along the center of said channel and following the easterly boundary of said City of Sault Ste. Marie to the said international boundary line in the main and steamboat channel of the St. Mary's River; thence westerly along the said international boundary line until the same reaches an intersecting point produced from the extended west line of fractional section six, township forty-seven north of range one east; thence south along said west line of fractional section six to the place of Beginning; said description embracing portions of fractional sections six, five, four, nine, ten, fifteen and sixteen, township forty-seven north of range one east, and encompassing the islands and bed of the St. Mary's River lying within the limits of the said City of Sault Ste. Marie, all in the County of Chippewa and State of Michigan, according to its original government survey. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any police officer acting in the line of duty. 
(Ord. No. 485-05, 9-6-05)

Chapter 17 - MOBILE HOMES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; special permits for trailer courts, App. A, § 10-1.17(1707)(3); MH mobile home districts, App. A, § 10-28. 

Sec. 17-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Double wides shall mean two (2) or more mobile home units, separately towable but designed without a permanent foundation to be joined into one integral unit, capable of being again separated for repeated towing. 
    Expandables shall mean a mobile home containing a collapsible or telescoping unit which meets highway towing standards when "closed"; expanded at site ("pulled out like a bureau drawer to form a bay or an ell") for added living space. 
    Mobile home, trailer, house trailer shall mean a transferable, single-family dwelling unit suitable for year-round occupancy and containing the same water supply, waste disposal and electrical conveniences as immobile housing. 
    Trailer coach means a mobile home, a trailer or single-family manufactured living unit which is transported to a site as one or more modules, any of which is so constructed as to permit occupancy as a dwelling or sleeping place by one or more persons, and licensable as a "trailer coach" under Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949 [MCL § 257.1 et seq., MSA § 9.1801 et seq.], as amended. 
(Code 1957, § 8-5.04; Ord. No. 12, § 1 (8-5.04), 3-7-60; Ord. No. 96, § 8-5.04, 2-28-72; Ord. No. 142, § 8-5.04, 4-15-74) 
Sec. 17-2. - Permanent occupancy; temporary parking permit. 
(a)  Mobile homes, trailer coaches, trailers, house trailers, double wides and expandables shall not be used as a permanent place of abode or as a permanent dwelling or for indefinite periods of time in any area of the city not zoned for the use of such vehicles; provided, that not more than one such trailer properly connected with the city water supply and sanitary sewer systems, and constructed and located in compliance with all requirements of the building, plumbing, sanitary, health, zoning and electrical ordinances of the city and not inhabited by a greater number of occupants than that for which it was designed may be permitted on any premises under permits properly secured as provided for in the building, plumbing, electrical, sanitary, health and zoning ordinances. 
(b)  Prior to any trailer being parked or occupied under this section, the owner of the property upon which it is to be placed, or the person who is to occupy such trailer, shall obtain a temporary trailer parking permit from the city clerk. Such trailer parking permit shall be kept current at all times and shall be displayed on the trailer for which it is issued, on the side of such trailer nearest the fronting public street in a manner which shall make it readily noticeable, and shall be protected in such a manner as to prevent such permit from becoming illegible. 
(Code 1957, § 8-5.04; Ord. No. 12, § 1 (8-5.04), 3-7-60; Ord. No. 96, § 8-5.04, 2-28-72; Ord. No. 142, § 8-5.04, 4-15-74) 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate house trailers, § 2.3(t). 
Chapter 18 - NUISANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to abate nuisances, § 2.3(q), (v). 
Cross reference- Distribution of handbills, Ch. 3, Art. II; air pollution prevention and control, Ch. 4; keeping of animals when causing annoyance in neighborhood prohibited, § 7-1; slaughtering of animals, § 7-2; disposition of animals when sick or dead, § 7-3; garbage, rubbish, litter and junk, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; removal of noxious weeds, § 25-1; removal of tree roots causing damage to public property, § 25-20; Dutch elm disease, Ch. 25, Art. III; zoning regulations considered to be public nuisances per se, App. A, § 10-1.25(2501). 

Sec. 18-1. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the word "nuisance" is hereby defined as anything prohibited by this chapter or as any person doing an unlawful act, or omitting to perform a duty, or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either: 
(1)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; or 
(2)  Offends decency; or 
(3)  Is offensive to the senses; or 
(4)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street, highway, sidewalk, stream, ditch or drainage; or 
(5)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property; or 
(6)  Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property, or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others. 
Sec. 18-2. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.02) 
Sec. 18-3. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager may elect to enforce the provisions of this chapter by one of the following methods or by any combination thereof: 
(1)  Prosecute the person committing, creating or maintaining the nuisance for a violation of the provisions of this Code; or 
(2)  Cause the nuisance to be immediately abated under section 18-12; or 
(3)  Give notice in the manner provided in section 18-8 ordering such nuisance to be abated. 
(b)  Whenever any nuisance endangers the health of the public the health officer shall have the power to enforce this chapter in the same manner as such power is delegated to the city manager in subsection (a). 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.03) 
Sec. 18-4. - Illustrative enumeration. 
    The maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain on any public or private property of any of the following items, conditions or actions are hereby declared to be and constitute a nuisance; provided, however, this enumeration shall not be deemed or construed to be conclusive, limiting or restrictive: 
(1)  Noxious weeds and other rank vegetation; 
(2)  Accumulation of rubbish, trash, refuse, junk and other abandoned materials, metals, lumber or other things; 
(3)  Any condition which provides harborage for rates, mice, snakes, and other vermin; 
(4)  Any building or other structure which is in such a dilapidated condition that it is unfit for human habitation, or kept in such an unsanitary condition that it is a menace to the health of people residing in the vicinity thereof, or presents a more than ordinarily dangerous fire hazard in the vicinity where it is located; 
(5)  All unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibrations, including animal noises; 
(6)  All disagreeable or obnoxious odors and stenches, as well as the conditions, substances or other causes which give rise to the emission or generation of such odors and stenches; 
(7)  The carcasses of animals or fowl not disposed of within a reasonable time after death; 
(8)  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by sewage, dead animals, creamery, industrial wastes or other substances; 
(9)  Any building, structure or other place or location where any activity which is in violation of local, state or federal law is conducted, performed or maintained; 
(10)  Any accumulation of stagnant water permitted or maintained on any lot or piece of ground; 
(11)  Dense smoke, noxious fumes, gas, soot or cinders, in unreasonable quantities. 
Sec. 18-5. - Barbed wire fences near public places. 
    No fence composed, in whole or in part, of barbed wire or so constructed as to be dangerous and liable to injure persons passing near the same shall be constructed or maintained around or along any area or bordering upon any sidewalk, street, alley or any public place. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.05) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 18-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1D., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed § 18-6, which pertained to interference with radio and television reception, and derived from the 1957 Code, § 6-1.07. 
Sec. 18-7. - Noise. 
(a)  Enumeration. No person shall make any unnecessary or unusual noise which either annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, convenience, repose, health or safety of the public. Each of the following acts is declared unlawful and is prohibited, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Horn or signal device. No person shall use a horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle otherwise than as a reasonable warning nor shall any person make any unnecessary or unreasonably loud or harsh sound by means of a horn or other sound device. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 
(2)  Radio, phonograph or musical instrument. No person shall play any radio, phonograph or any musical instrument in such a manner or with such volume, particularly during the hours between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office or in any building, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or any persons in the vicinity. 
(3)  Yelling, whistling and singing. No person shall yell, shout, hoot, whistle, sing or make any loud noise on the public streets between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. or make any such noise at any time so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of the citizens of the city. 
(4)  Hawking goods. No person shall hawk goods, merchandise or newspapers in a loud and boisterous manner. 
Cross reference- Peddlers, Ch. 9, Art. III. 
(5)  Animals. No person shall keep any animal or bird whose noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person. 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 7. 
(6)  Whistles and sirens. No person shall blow any whistle or siren except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger. 
(7)  Engine exhausts. No person shall discharge into the open air the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal-combustion engine, motor vehicle engine or any other type of engine except through a muffler or other device which effectively prevents loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 
(8)  Construction. No person shall carry on the erection (including excavation), demolishing, alteration or repair of any building, street or highway other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. unless a permit is first obtained from the city clerk, who shall issue such permit only after certification by the superintendent of public works that such construction, for emergency reasons, is necessary and ought to be permitted. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
(9)  Instruments to attract attention. No person shall use any drum, musical instrument, loudspeaker, amplifier or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention for any purpose; provided, that any governmental unit or any bona fide nonprofit organization may use such a device if proper application is made to the city clerk and a permit is issued therefor. In no case shall the city clerk grant such a permit for use on a Sunday or at any time or in any manner which, in the opinion of the city clerk, will constitute a nuisance. 
(b)  Exceptions. None of the terms or prohibitions of subsection (a) shall apply to or be enforced against any police or fire vehicle, car or ambulance while engaged upon necessary public emergency business or the reasonable use of stationary amplifiers or loudspeakers in the course of public addresses which are noncommercial in character. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.08) 
Cross reference- Noise control at transitory shows and exhibitions, § 16-90. 
Sec. 18-8. - Notice to abate. 
    Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city or within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction, the city manager or some other duly designated officer of the city shall give five (5) days written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which such nuisance exists or upon the person causing or maintaining the nuisance. 
Sec. 18-9. - Contents of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance issued under the provisions of this chapter shall contain: 
(1)  An order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time, which shall be reasonable under the circumstances; 
(2)  The location of the nuisance, if the same is stationary; 
(3)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance; 
(4)  A statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance; 
(5)  A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time, the city will abate such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person. 
Sec. 18-10. - Service of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance shall be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law. 
Sec. 18-11. - Abatement by city. 
    Upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to abate the same, the city manager or other duly designated officer of the city shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
Sec. 18-12. - Emergency abatement by city. 
    When, in the opinion of the city manager or other duly designated officer, there is actual and immediate danger to the public or occupants of a particular premises caused by a nuisance on such premises, the city manager or duly designated officer is hereby authorized and empowered, without any notice or hearing, to order and require such premises to be vacated. The city manager or other duly designated officer shall immediately post the premises, warning of the dangerous condition, and shall then abate such nuisance and prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
Sec. 18-13. - Collection of city's costs of abatement. 
    Any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this chapter shall be collected from the owner or occupant of the property upon which the nuisance was committed, created or maintained in an action at law, or they may be charged against the premises as a special assessment in accordance with the provisions of article V of chapter 21. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.03) 
Sec. 18-14. - Motor vehicle sound. 
    An owner, operator, person in charge of, in possession, exercising control over or responsible for a motor vehicle, whether in operation or parked, on public or private property, from which sound, music, noise, loud voices and the like, produced by radio, phonograph, stereo system, compact disc player, cassette player, eight track, television set, amplified or unamplified musical instrument, microphone, sound system, sound amplification device or any other means of sound production, is plainly audible at a distance of thirty (30) feet from the vehicle which is the source of the above referenced noise is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Ord. No. 456-02, § 1, 6-3-02) 
Secs. 18-15-18-23. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-24. - Prohibition on installation of outdoor wood- or coal-fired boilers and outdoor furnaces. 
    No person shall install an outdoor furnace or boiler or cause or permit the installation of an outdoor furnace or boiler within the city. 
(Ord. No. 497-07, § 1, 9-17-07) 
Sec. 18-25. - Outdoor furnace and boiler defined. 
    Outdoor furnace or boiler shall mean, but is not limited to, any device, apparatus, or structure that: 
(a)  Is designed or used to provide heat or hot water to any structure; and 
(b)  Operates by burning wood, wood products, paper or coal; and 
(c)  Is not located within the structure for which it is providing heat or hot water. 
(Ord. No. 497-07, § 1, 9-17-07) 
Sec. 18-26. - Existing uses. 
    Section 18-24 shall not apply to any outdoor furnace or boiler that was installed connected and operating as of September 18, 2006. 
(Ord. No. 497-07, § 1, 9-17-07) 
Secs. 18-27-18-50. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 584-18, § 1D., adopted November 19, 2018, repealed §§ 18-27-30 and 18-40-18-43, which pertained to moratorium on installation of wind powered electricity generating devices; and moratorium on marijuana dispensary manufacture facilities, and derived from Ord. No. 507-09, adopted April 6, 2009; Ord. No. 521-10, adopted September 28, 2010; Ord. No. 526-11, adopted March 7, 2011; and Ord. No. 529-11, adopted September 6, 2011. 
Sec. 18-51. - Designating and regulating flood hazard areas. 
    Preamble. An ordinance to designate an enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the City of Sault Ste. Marie located in Chippewa County, and to designate regulated flood hazard areas under the provisions of the State Construction Code Act, Act No. 230 of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended. 
A.  Agency designated. Pursuant to the provisions of the state construction code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, the Building Department Building Official of the City of Sault Ste. Marie is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the City of Sault Ste. Marie under Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, State of Michigan. The City of Sault Ste. Marie assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of said Act through out the corporate limits of the community adopting this section. 
B.  Code appendix enforced. Pursuant to the provisions of the state construction code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, Appendix G of the Michigan Building Code shall be enforced by the enforcing agency within the jurisdiction of the community adopting this section. 
C.  Designation of regulated flood prone hazard areas. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Flood Insurance Study (FIS) Entitled "Chippewa County, Michigan (All Jurisdictions)" and dated 10/16/2014 and the Flood Insurance Rate Map(s) (FIRMS) panel number(s) of 26033C; 0244D, 0263D, 0264D, 0477D, 0479D, 0481D, 0482D, 0501D, 0502D, 0506D, 0508D, dated 10/16/2014 are adopted by reference for the purposes of administration of the Michigan Construction Code, and declared to be a part of Section 1612.3 of the Michigan Building Code, and to provide the content of the "Flood Hazards" section of Table R301.2(1) of the Michigan Residential Code. 
D.  Repeals. All ordinances inconsistent with the provisions of this section are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 553-14, § 1, 10-6-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 553-14, § 1, adopted October 6, 2014, designated the inclusion of a new § 18-25. Inasmuch as said section already existed in the Code, said section has been redesignated as § 18-51 at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 18.5 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18.5-1-18.5-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOW AND MODERATE INCOME HOUSING DEVELOPMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1-7 of Ordinance No. 192, adopted June 5, 1978, enacted provisions not specifically amendatory of the Code, hence codification herein as Art. II, §§ 18.5-11-18.5-18, was at the discretion of the editors. Additionally, it should be noted that Ord. No. 388-94, adopted Dec. 19, 1994, provided for "a service charge in lieu of taxes for proposed multiple-family dwelling projects for senior citizens of low or moderate income . . . which include Downtown Commercial Redevelopment in a target area of the city." Such provisions are not set out at length in this Code, but are on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 18.5-11. - Title. 
    This article shall hereafter be known and cited as "Low and Moderate Income Housing Developments Article." 
(Ord. No. 192, § 1, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-12. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is acknowledged that it is the public purpose of the State of Michigan and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its citizens of low and moderate income, with such purpose and policy being enunciated in Act No. 346 of the Public Acts of 1966 of the State of Michigan, as amended MCLA Section 125.1415-a, which provides for exemption from all property taxation of those housing developments for persons of low and moderate income financed with a mortgage loan made by the state housing development authority. 
(b)  It is further acknowledged that such property tax exemption will serve to stimulate the development of housing for citizens of low and moderate income, and the city will be benefited and improved by the development of such housing. 
(Ord. No. 192, § 2, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-13. - Definitions. 
    Act: The State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
    Authority: The Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
    Housing development: A development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low and moderate income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal and educational facilities as the authority determines improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low and moderate income. 
    Mortgage loan: A loan to be made by the authority to the sponsor for the construction and permanent financing of the housing development. 
    Mortgagor: Persons or entities which have applied to the authority for mortgage loan to finance a housing development. 
    Property: A portion of the vacated public square as described in the Whelphey Survey of 1854-1856, in the City of Sault Ste. Marie; being the north two hundred (200) feet in depth parallel to the north line of said vacated public square (south line of Ridge Street) and bounded on the east by the east line of said vacated public square (west line of Pine Street), on the west by the west line of said vacated public square (east line of Magazine Street). 
(Ord. No. 192, § 3, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-14. - Class of housing projects established. 
    The city herein establishes a class of housing projects, such class being defined as multiple dwelling for families and elderly persons of low and moderate income. 
(Ord. No. 192, § 4, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-15. - Establishment of annual service charge. 
    The city, acknowledging that the reliance of the mortgagor and the authority on the exemption from all property taxes and payments in lieu thereof as described above has hereby ordained and established that the property and the development to be constructed on the property shall be exempt from all property taxes as provided in the act from and after their commencement of construction of the development, and, in consideration of the foregoing and on behalf of the city, the city council hereby agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes in an amount equal to four (4) percent of the ninety-five (95) percent of the contract rents (as defined by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development in rules promulgated pursuant to the U.S. Housing Act of 1937, as amended by the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974) of the preceding calendar year exclusive of the utilities and the amount paid to the city during the preceding calendar year for the annual service charge. 
(Ord. No. 192, § 5, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-16. - Development exempt from all property taxes. 
    Pursuant to the authority vested in the city council of the city by the act and by the charter of the city, the city council hereby determines that the development is qualified for exemption from all property taxes as provided in the act. 
(Ord. No. 192, § 6, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-17. - Duration. 
    This article shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property. 
(Ord. No. 192, § 7, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-18. - Malcolm School Property development. 
(a)  The city acknowledges that Tempo, Incorporated, on behalf of a limited dividend housing association to be formed as mortgagor, proposes to erect, own and operate a housing development identified as Malcolm School Property, which development is of the class described above, on certain property located at property described as: 
A portion of the vacated public square as described in the Whelphey Survey of 1854-1856, in the City of Sault Ste. Marie; being the north two hundred (200) feet in depth parallel to the north line of said vacated public square (south line of Ridge Street) and bounded on the east by the east line of said vacated public square (west line of Pine Street), on the west by the west line of said vacated public square (east line of Magazine Street) 
in the city, which development will be financed with a mortgage loan made by the authority, and which development is intended to serve persons of low and moderate income. 
(b)  The mortgagor has agreed to pay to the city, on or before the fifteenth day of September of each year, on account of the development, an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes from and after the commencement of construction of the development so long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property. 
(Ord. No. 192, § 2, 6-5-78) 
Sec. 18.5-19. - Supportive Housing Project. 
(a)  Definitions. [For the purposes of this section, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
    Annual shelter rent means the total collections during an agreed annual period from all occupants of a housing development representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants. 
    Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
    Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal and educational facilities as the authority determines [will] improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
    Mortgage loan means a loan to be made by the authority to the sponsor for the construction and/or permanent financing of the housing development. 
    Sponsor means the person(s) or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan to finance a housing development. 
    Utilities means fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the housing development. 
(b)  Class of housing developments. It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of taxes shall be family housing developments, which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that the Supportive Housing Project is of this class. 
(c)  Establishment of annual service charge. The housing development identified as the Supportive Housing Project and the property on which it is constructed shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the commencement of construction. The city, acknowledging that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of Ordinance No. 453-02 and the qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established in such ordinance, and in consideration of the sponsor's officer, subject to receipt of a mortgage loan from the authority, to construct, own and operate the housing development, agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be equal to four (4) percent of the annual shelter rents actually collected, except that for the first year in which the housing development shall be occupied by rent paying tenants, there shall be no service charge. 
(d)  Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. Notwithstanding subsection (c) above, the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low-income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
    The term "low-income" as used herein shall be the same as found in section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(e)  Contractual effect of ordinance. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of Ordinance No. 453-02. 
(f)  Payment of service charge. The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under Ordinance No. 453-02 shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable to the city except that the annual payment shall be paid on or before April 1 of each year. 
(g)  Duration. This section shall remain in effect for as long as the mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid of [or] the authority has an interest in the property; provided that construction of the housing development commences within two (2) years from the effective date of this section. 
(Ord. No. 453-02, §§ 3-9, 2-18-02; Ord. No. 467-03, § 1, 4-21-03) 
Sec. 18.5-20. - Park Place City Center development. 
(1)  [Title.] This section shall be known and cited as the "City of Sault Ste. Marie Park Place City Center Development Ordinance". 
(2)  Preambles. It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its citizens of low income and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 PA 346, as amended, MCL § 125.1401 et seq.). The city is authorized by this Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under this Act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for this Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, is a valid public purpose; further, that the continuance of the provisions of this section for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of taxes during the period contemplated in this section are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance on such taxation. 
The City of Sault Ste. Marie acknowledges that Park Place City Center LDHA, LLC (the "sponsor") has offered subject to receipt of an allocation under the Low Income Housing Tax Credit ("LIHTC") program, to erect, own and operate a housing development identified as Park Place City Center, on certain property located at 416 and 418 Ashmun Street in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, more particularly described: 
As Lot 138, Assessors Subdivision Number 2, City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan. 
And 
Lot 139 and Lot 140, Assessors Subdivision Number 2, City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan 
to serve persons of low income, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes. 
(3)  Definitions. 
(a)  Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
(b)  Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966 of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
(c)  Annual shelter rent means the total collections during a calendar year from all occupants of a housing development representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants. 
(d)  Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines to improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
(e)  Low-income persons and families means those persons and families who are determined to be eligible to move into the housing. 
(f)  Utilities means fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the housing development. 
(g)  Sponsor means person(s) or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan or allocation under the LIHTC program to finance a housing development. 
(h)  Authority mortgage loan means the loan(s) entered into between the authority, as mortgagee, and the sponsor, as mortgagor. 
(4)  Class of housing developments. It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be housing developments which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that this development is of this class. 
(5)  Establishment of annual service charge. The housing development identified as Park Place City Center shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the commencement of construction. The city acknowledged that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this section and qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established in this section, and in consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to receipt of an allocation under the LIHTC program, to construct, own and operate the housing development, agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be equal to four (4) percent of the annual shelter rents actually collected. 
(6)  Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. Notwithstanding subsection (5), the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low-income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. The term "low-income" as used here shall be the same as found in section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(7)  Contractual effect of section. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor, with the authority as a third-party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes as previously described is effectuated by enactment of this section. 
(8)  Payment of service charge. The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under the section shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes and are payable to the city except that the annual payment shall be paid on or before the first day of July each year (beginning in 2009), based upon rents collected during the preceding calendar year. 
(9)  Duration. This section shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as the authority's mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property; or the housing development remains subject to income and rent restrictions pursuant to section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, provided, that the construction of the housing development commences within four (4) years from the effective date of this section. 
(10)  Severability. The various sections ands provisions of this section shall be deemed to be severable and should any section or provision of this section be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid the same shall not affect the validity of the section as a whole or any section or provision of this section other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 498-07, § 1, 11-5-07; Ord. No. 509-09, § 1, 7-6-09; Ord. No. 513-09, § 1, 11-16-09) 
Sec. 18.5-21. - Wood Creek Apartments development. 
(1)  [Title.] This section shall be known and cited as the "City of Sault Ste. Marie Wood Creek Apartments Development Ordinance". 
(2)  Preambles. It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its citizens of low income and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 PA 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). The city is authorized by this Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under this Act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for this Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, is a valid public purpose; further, that the continuance of the provisions of this section for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of taxes during the period contemplated in this section are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance on such taxation. 
    The city acknowledges that JPS Wood Creek Limited Dividend Housing Association, Limited Partnership (the "sponsor") has offered subject to receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit ("LIHTC") program, to rehabilitate, own and operate a housing development identified as Wood Creek Apartments, on certain property located at 1708 Meridian Street in the city, more particularly described: 
A PART OF THE SOUTHEAST 1/4 OF THE SOUTHEAST 1/4 OF THE NORTHEAST 1/4 OF SECTION 12, T47N, R1W, CITY OF SAULT STE. MARIE, CHIPPEWA COUNTY, MICHIGAN, AS DESCRIBED AS FOLLOWS: BEGINNING AT THE EAST 1/4 CORNER OF SAID SECTION 12; THENCE SOUTH 89°47'14" WEST, ALONG THE EAST-WEST 1/4 LINE, 658.87 FEET; THENCE NORTH 00°19'39" WEST 328.38 FEET; THENCE NORTH 89°46'02" EAST 658.42 FEET TO THE EAST LINE OF SAID SECTION 12; THENCE SOUTH 00°24'20" EAST 328.61 FEET TO THE POINT OF BEGINNING. 
to serve persons of low income, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes. 
(3)  Definitions. 
(a)  Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
(b)  Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
(c)  Annual shelter rent means the total collections during a calendar year from all occupants of a housing development representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants. 
(d)  Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines to improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
(e)  Low-income persons and families means those persons and families who are determined to be eligible to move into the housing development assisted by the authority and/or rural development. 
(f)  Utilities means fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the housing development. 
(g)  Sponsor means person(s) or entities which have applied to the authority or rural development for a mortgage loan or allocation under the LIHTC program to finance a housing development. 
(h)  Rural development means the United States Department of Agriculture-Rural Development through the rural rental housing program under section 515 of the Federal Housing Act of 1949, as amended. 
(i)  Mortgage loan means a loan made, transferred, to be made or to be transferred by rural development and/or the authority to the sponsor for the construction, rehabilitation and/or permanent financing of the housing development. 
(4)  Class of housing developments. It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be housing developments, which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that this development is of this class. 
(5)  Establishment of annual service charge. The housing development identified as Wood Creek Apartments shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the earlier of: transfer of deed to the sponsor or commencement of construction. The city acknowledged that the sponsor and rural development or the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this section and qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established in this section, and in consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to receipt of an allocation under the LIHTC program or a rural development mortgage loan, to construct, own and operate the housing development, agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be equal to six (6) percent of the annual shelter rents actually collected. 
(6)  Limitation on the payment of annual service charge. Notwithstanding subsection (5), the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low-income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
The term "low income" as used here shall be the same as found in section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(7)  Contractual effect of section. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority and/or rural development as third-party beneficiaries under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this section. 
(8)  Payment of service charge. The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under the section shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes and are payable to the city except that the annual payment shall be paid on or before the first day of July, each year (beginning in 2009) based upon rents collected during the months of the preceding calendar year. For the 2009 payment, only the rents collected during the 2008 period of ownership by the sponsor shall be used to calculate the service charge. 
(9)  Duration. This section shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as the authority's or rural development's mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority or rural development has any interest in the property; or the housing development remains subject to income and rent restrictions pursuant to section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, provided, that the construction or rehabilitation of the housing development commences within one (1) year from the effective date of this section. 
(10)  Severability. The various sections and provisions of this section shall be deemed to be severable and should any section or provision of this section be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid the same shall not affect the validity of the section as a whole or any section or provision of this section other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 505-08, § 1, 9-15-08) 
Sec. 18.5-22. - Edge of the Woods Apartments. 
(1)  [Title.] This section shall be known and cited as the "City of Sault Ste. Marie Edge of the Woods Apartments Ordinance". 
(2)  Preambles . It is acknowledged that it is a proper public purpose of the state and its political subdivisions to provide housing for its citizens of low income and to encourage the development of such housing by providing for a service charge in lieu of property taxes in accordance with the State Housing Development Authority Act of 1966 (1966 PA 346, as amended, MCL 125.1401 et seq.). The city is authorized by this Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under this Act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for this Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, is a valid public purpose; further, that the continuance of the provisions of this section for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of taxes during the period contemplated in this section are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance on such taxation. 
    The city acknowledges that EDGES-2006 LDHA, LP (the "sponsor") has offered subject to receipt of an allocation under the low income housing tax credit ("LIHTC") program, to rehabilitate, own and operate a housing development identified as Edge of the Woods Apartments, on certain property located at 301 24th Avenue West in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Chippewa County, Michigan, more particularly described as follows: 
    Parcel 1 : Commencing at the West 1/4 corner of Section 18, Township 47 North, Range 1 East; thence North 89 degrees 08'14" East along the East-West 1/4 line of said Section 18, a recorded distance of 620.60 feet; thence South 00 degrees 00'08" West 30.00 feet to the Point of Beginning of this description, said Point of Beginning being on the South right of way line of 24th Avenue; thence North 89 degrees 08'14" East along said right of way line 681.26 feet (recorded as 680.60 feet) to the West 1/8 th line of Section 18; thence South 00 degrees 24'10" East along the West 1/8 line 625.87 feet to the South line of the North 1/2 of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4 (North 1/2 of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4) of said Section 18; thence South 88 degrees 58'43" West along said South line 685.72 feet to a point which lies North 88 degrees 58'43" East along said South line 620.60 feet from the West line of said Section 18; thence North 00 degrees 00'08" East 627.82 feet to the Point of Beginning; being a part of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4 of said Section 18. 
    Parcel II: (Easement Parcel) An exclusive perpetual easement for stormwater drainage purposes, 20 feet in width, over and across the premises lying to the South, extending first Southerly approximately 609 feet, thence Westerly approximately 590.6 feet and then Southerly an additional approximately 511.9 feet, as set forth in Liber 394, page 269. 
to serve persons of low income, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes. 
(3)  Definitions . 
(a)  Authority means the Michigan State Housing Development Authority. 
(b)  Act means the State Housing Development Authority Act, being Public Act 346 of 1966, of the State of Michigan, as amended. 
(c)  Annual shelter rent means the total collections during a calendar year from all occupants of a housing development representing rent or occupancy charges, exclusive of charges for gas, electricity, heat, or other utilities furnished to the occupants. 
(d)  Federally-aided mortgage means any of the following: 
(i)  A below market interest rate mortgage, insured, purchased, or held by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
(ii)  A market interest rate mortgage insured by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and augmented by a program of rent supplements. 
(iii)  A mortgage receiving interest reduction payments provided by the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
(iv)  A mortgage on a housing project to which the Authority allocates low income housing tax credits. 
(e)  Housing development means a development which contains a significant element of housing for persons of low income and such elements of other housing, commercial, recreational, industrial, communal, and educational facilities as the authority determines to improve the quality of the development as it relates to housing for persons of low income. 
(f)  Low income persons and families means those persons and families who are determined to be eligible to move into the housing. 
(g)  Utilities means fuel, water, sanitary sewer service and/or electrical service which are paid by the housing development. 
(h)  Sponsor means person(s) or entities which have applied to the authority for a mortgage loan or allocation under the LIHTC program to finance the acquisition and rehabilitation of a housing development. 
(4)  Class of housing developments . It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be housing developments which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that this development is of this class. 
(5)  Establishment of annual service charge . The housing development identified as Edge of the Woods Apartments shall be exempt from all property taxes from and after the acquisition of this housing development and the commencement of rehabilitation. The city acknowledged that the sponsor and the authority have established the economic feasibility of the housing development in reliance upon the enactment and continuing effect of this section and qualification of the housing development for exemption from all property taxes and a payment in lieu of taxes as established in this section, and in consideration of the sponsor's offer, subject to receipt of an allocation under the LIHTC program, to rehabilitate, own and operate the housing development, agrees to accept payment of an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all property taxes. The annual service charge shall be equal to four (4) percent of the annual shelter rents actually collected. 
(6)  Limitation on the payment of annual service charge . Notwithstanding subsection (5), the service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for the part of the housing development which is tax exempt and which is occupied by other than low income persons or families shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the housing development if the housing development were not tax exempt. 
    The term "low income" as used here shall be the same as found in section 15(a)(7) of the Act. 
(7)  Contractual effect of section . Notwithstanding the provisions of section 15(a)(5) of the Act, to the contrary, a contract between the city and the sponsor with the authority as a third party beneficiary under the contract, to provide tax exemption and accept payments in lieu of taxes, as previously described, is effectuated by enactment of this section. 
(8)  Payment of service charge . The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined under the section shall be paid on or before the thirtieth day of June each year (beginning in 2011) based upon rents collected during the preceding calendar year. Calculations, which in the sole opinion of the city, are sufficiently detailed to document the service charge, as based upon rents collected during the preceding calendar year shall be provided with the payment. 
(9)  Duration . This ordinance shall remain in effect and shall not terminate so long as the authority's mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid or the authority has any interest in the property; or a federally-aided mortgage remains outstanding and unpaid or the Department of Housing and Urban Development has any interest in the property; or the housing development remains subject to income and rent restrictions pursuant to section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, provided, that the rehabilitation of the Housing Development commences within four years from the effective date of this section. 
(10)  Severability . The various sections and provisions of this section shall be deemed to be severable and should any section or provision of this section be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid the same shall not affect the validity of the section as a whole or any section or provision of this section other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 514-09, § 1, 3-1-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 514-09, § 1, adopted March 1, 2010, added § 18.5-21 to the Code. Inasmuch as said section already existed, the new provisions have been redesignated as herein set out at the editor's discretion and with the agreement of the city.

(2)  Preambles. The city is authorized by this Act to establish or change the service charge to be paid in lieu of taxes by any or all classes of housing exempt from taxation under this Act at any amount it chooses not to exceed the taxes that would be paid but for this Act. It is further acknowledged that such housing for persons of low income is a public necessity, and as the city will be benefited and improved by such housing, is a valid public purpose; further, that the continuance of the provisions of this section for tax exemption and the service charge in lieu of taxes during the period contemplated in this section are essential to the determination of economic feasibility of housing developments which are constructed and financed in reliance on such taxation.

Marie, Chippewa County, Michigan, described as follows: Commencing at the East 1/4 corner of said Section 12; thence South 89° 47' 14" West, along the East-West 1/4 line, 658.87 feet; thence North 00° 19' 39" West 328.38 feet to the Point of Beginning; thence continuing North 00° 19' 39" West 328.37 feet; thence North 89° 44' 52" East 657.97 feet to the East line of said Section 12; thence South 00° 24' 20" East, along said East Section line, 328.60 feet, thence South 89° 46' 02" West 648.42 feet to the Point of Beginning. 
Property Address: 1606 Meridian, Sault Ste. Marie, MI 49783 
Parcel Number: 17-051-062-023-00 
    to serve persons of low income, and that the sponsor has offered to pay the city on account of this housing development an annual service charge for public services in lieu of all taxes.

It is determined that the class of housing developments to which the tax exemption shall apply and for which a service charge shall be paid in lieu of such taxes shall be housing developments, which are financed or assisted pursuant to the Act. It is further determined that this development is of this class.

The annual service charge shall be equal to eight (8) percent of the annual shelter rents actually collected.

(8)  Payment of service charge. Calculations, which in the sole opinion of the city, are sufficiently detailed to document the service charge, as based upon rents collected during the preceding calendar year shall be provided with the payment.

(10)  Severability. The various sections and provisions of this section shall be deemed to be severable and should any section or provision of this section be declared by any court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid the same shall not affect the validity of the section as a whole or any section or provision of this section other than the section or provision so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid.
