(a)  Signs utilizing unusual foundations or mountings (such as vehicles or equipment), or which are attached to or painted on such unusual structures or mountings, may be permitted subject to the decision of the city manager and based on his findings that such sign meets the general intent and the size, area, height and location criteria established for more conventional signs in the same zoning district, and that such sign will not impair the property values of adjacent parcels nor adversely affect the general health, safety and public welfare of the community. The manager may impose such conditions on any approval of such a sign as he deems necessary, to insure reasonable equivalence with more conventional signs. 
(b)  In cases where more than one (1) business utilizes a common vehicular entrance or exit and/or traffic control and safety are affected, the city manager may authorize one (1) or more directional signs, subject to a maximum of six (6) square feet per sign, even though such sign or signs may be off-premise to the property it is directing to. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the sign size limitations in section 20-22(c) "Commercial district signs", the city manager may permit an increase in the maximum size of a freestanding sign to one hundred fifty (150) square feet for freeway service uses such as restaurants, motels, gasoline service stations, duty-free shops and the like where such use either abuts or is within seven hundred fifty (750) feet of the centerline of the freeway and such sign would be visible from the freeway. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Secs. 20-27-20-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXISTING SIGNS 

Sec. 20-30. - Nonconforming signs. 
    Signs lawfully erected prior to adoption of this chapter which do not meet the standards of this chapter may be continued if properly repaired and maintained as provided in this chapter and continue to be in conformance with other city ordinances. Such signs are nonconforming signs. 
(1)  Any nonconforming sign shall not be enlarged, reworded, redesigned or altered in any way except to bring it into conformity with the provisions of this chapter, provided that a business which continues in the same location providing substantially the same services or products as the business to which the nonconforming sign is accessory, may alter such nonconforming sign to reflect the changed name of the business. Such alteration may only change the face of the sign and may not replace any structural members holding, anchoring or framing the face. 
(2)  Any such sign which has been destroyed or damaged to such an extent that the cost of restoration would exceed fifty (50) percent of the replacement value of the sign at the time of the destruction or damage, shall not be repaired or replaced except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-31. - Unsafe and unlawful signs. 
    When any sign becomes unsecured, in danger of falling, or otherwise unsafe, or if any sign shall be unlawfully installed, erected or maintained in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, the owners thereof or the person or firm maintaining the sign shall, upon written notice of the administrating official, forthwith in the case of immediate danger and in any case within not more than ten (10) days, make such sign safe, eliminate the dangerous condition, or shall remove it. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-32. - Abandoned signs. 
    An abandoned sign, including any support pole, mounting base, mounting brackets, etc., must be removed by the owner of the property upon which the sign is located. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-33. - Maintenance of signs. 
    The owner of any sign shall ensure that such sign be kept in good repair and shall provide that such sign is properly painted or otherwise cleaned and washed, and that all parts and supports of said sign be cleaned or painted, unless the same are galvanized or treated to prevent rust. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Secs. 20-34-20-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIGN ERECTOR LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 

Sec. 20-40. - Chapter 14 applicable. 
    The provisions of chapter 14, insofar as the same may be applicable and not in conflict, shall apply to and govern the issuance of any license under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-41. - Sign erector's license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of erecting, altering or removing, or installing signs for which permits are required by this chapter without first obtaining a license therefor and paying the fee required by section 14-6, provided, however, that a sign erectors's license shall not be required for the following signs: 
(1)  Painted wall signs; 
(2)  Interior window signs; 
(3)  Portable signs; 
(4)  Non-electric directional signs; 
(5)  Non-electric wall signs having a sign area of sixteen (16) square feet or less; and/or 
(6)  Non-electric ground or freestanding signs having a sign area of sixteen (16) square feet or less and an overall height of six (6) feet or less. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-42. - Scope. 
    The license to engage in the business of erecting signs shall be known as a sign erector's license and shall only be issued to those persons who show sufficient knowledge and experience to satisfy the building department as to their ability to erect signs in a safe and substantial manner in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-43. - Examination, approval. 
    No license shall be issued under this article until such applicant, or the partners, proprietors or officer in charge where the applicant is other than an individual, shall have been examined by the chief inspector as to the applicant's qualifications, and the chief inspector has approved such qualifications in writing. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-44. - Proof of insurance. 
    No sign erector's license shall be issued until the applicant provides proof of insurance, naming the city as additionally insured. The types and limits of such coverage shall be determined by the city clerk. The city shall be held harmless from any costs, damages or expense of any kind whatsoever which may be suffered by the city, or which may be put to, or which may accrue against it by charging to or recovering from the city from or by reason of the granting of the permission to erect such signs, or by reason of any acts or things done under or by the authorizing or permission granted to erect such signs in the city, or by reason of the negligence, failure or refusal of any person to comply with all the provisions of this chapter applicable to such signs. At any time the insurance of any sign erector lapses, the sign erector's license automatically becomes invalid or void. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-45. - Changes. 
    Holders of a sign erector's license shall notify the building department of any change in address and where a firm or corporation, of any change in ownership or management. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Secs. 20-46-20-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 20-50. - Application of city building code. 
    In the absence of provisions governing details of construction of signs in this chapter, the provisions of the applicable standards in the building codes adopted by or applying to construction in the city (state construction code, existing structures code, mechanical code, and electrical code) shall apply. Unless otherwise provided, in those instances where there is a conflict between construction requirements, the more restrictive requirements shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-51. - Protection of public in erection or removal; permit to barricade street. 
    Before starting the erection or removal of any sign erected upon or over a street, alley, sidewalk or public place, or which involves the use of a street, alley, sidewalk or public place to achieve access to the sign, the sign erector shall protect the public from possible danger in connection with such sign work by adequately barricading the portion of the street, alley, sidewalk or public place to be used in erecting or removing such sign. A permit for such work in the public right-of-way, including any barricading, shall first be obtained from the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Secs. 20-52-20-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 20-60. - Administration. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be administered by the city manager or by such department of the city as he may delegate for such work, such department head to be the administrating official of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-61. - Permits required. 
    Except as provided in section 20-41, no permit for the erection or alteration of a permanent sign shall be issued to any person who is not a licensed sign erector under this chapter. No person shall erect or alter any sign without first obtaining a permit from the administrating official, except that no permit shall be required for the erection or alteration of the following types of signs: 
(1)  Signs exempted from the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Temporary signs as enumerated in section 20-8, provided that such signs are nonetheless required to meet the provisions of this chapter as set forth in section 20-8 "Temporary signs." 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-62. - Application. 
    Application for sign permits shall be made upon forms provided by the administrating official and shall contain or be accompanied by such plans, drawings and specifications as are necessary to advise the administrating official of the type, size, shape, location, construction and materials of the proposed sign and the building, structure or premises upon which it is to be placed. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-63. - Fees. 
    A fee as established from time to time by the city commission, shall accompany the application. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-64. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, maintain, enlarge, alter, move or convert any sign in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, or cause or permit the same to be done, contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6 of the general provisions of the city Code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or when a violation occurs or continues. Any sign constituting an immediate hazard to health and safety shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be removed by the administrating official at the expense of the owner of the sign and assessed under the provisions of the city Code; and provided further, that any other sign unlawfully erected, altered, or maintained may be removed by the administrating official at the expense of the sign owner and assessed under the provisions of the city Code after said sign owner has been ordered in writing to remove said sign and has refused to do so without providing justification for so refusing at a hearing to be held by the administrating official. The city attorney may apply to a court of appropriate jurisdiction for an order requiring the removal of a sign in violation of this chapter. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties prescribed in paragraph (a), any sign erected in violation of this chapter in a public right-of-way may be removed by the administrating official and stored in a safe location for at least seventy-two (72) hours. During this period of time the owner of the sign may obtain his sign upon request and payment of a fee as established by the city commission for each sign to cover the costs of removal and storage. After seventy-two (72) hours, the administrating official may dispose of the sign. 
(Ord. No. 389-94, 12-19-94) 
Sec. 20-65. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by any decision, ruling or order from the administrating official, may appeal to the city manager. Appeals shall be taken within ten (10) days after the occurrence of the event which forms the basis for the appeal, by filing in writing a request for appeal. Upon a finding of just cause resulting from unique circumstances affecting the property, development, or sign, the city manager may permit a variance to the strict provisions of this chapter, provided that: 
(1)  The variance would not be contrary to the public interest or general purpose and intent of this chapter. 
(2)  The variance does not adversely affect properties in the immediate vicinity of the proposed sign, and 
(3)  The variance is not contrary to a zoning ordinance provision. 
Any such order permitting or denying the request may be appealed to the city commission, such appeal to be filed in writing within ten (10) days after the decision of the city manager. The decision of the city commission shall be final. 
Chapter 21 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Special assessments, Ch. 10; detailed procedure to be fixed by ordinance, § 10.2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Cost shall include the expense of survey, spreading of roll, notice, advertising, printing, financing, legal, engineering, construction and condemnation, and all other costs incidental to the making of improvements. 
    Engineer shall mean the city engineer unless an outside engineer is specifically employed for the work on an improvement in which case the word "engineer" shall mean the person so employed. 
    Improvement shall mean any public improvement, any part of the cost of which is to be assessed against one or more lots or parcels of land to be especially benefited thereby, in proportion to the benefit to be derived therefrom. 
    Lot or parcel of land shall mean any subdivision lot or portion thereof as officially platted or any unplatted parcel of land as may be described upon any official records. 
    Owner shall mean the last-recorded titleholder of any lot or parcel of land, or the person whose name is last listed upon the city tax roll as owner of a certain piece or parcel of land. 
(Code 1957, §§ 4-1.01-4-1.05) 
Secs. 21-2-21-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADVISORY PETITIONS 

Sec. 21-16. - Receipt by city commission. 
    The commission, in order to ascertain whether or not a reasonable number of property owners to be assessed desire any particular improvement to be made, may request and receive a petition therefor, or may receive such a petition voluntarily presented; but in either event, such petition shall be advisory only and shall not be jurisdictional. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.06) 
Sec. 21-17. - Contents. 
    All advisory petitions filed under this article shall be addressed to the commission and contain a brief description of the improvement sought to be made or the nuisance or hazard sought to be abated and shall be signed by property owners only, whose signatures shall be followed by a brief description of the property owned by them. The signatures on such petitions shall be verified by the oath of one or more of the circulators of such petition, before filing. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.07) 
Sec. 21-18. - Filing. 
    Advisory petitions under this article shall be filed with the clerk, who shall check them for signatures and correctness; and if they are found to be in order, the clerk shall refer them to the manager who shall present them to the commission at its next regular or special meeting called for that purpose, together with such manager's recommendations. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.08) 
Secs. 21-19-21-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPROVEMENT PROCEDURE 

Sec. 21-30. - Initiatory resolution. 
    When, by the provisions of the Charter and the laws of the state, the commission shall have power to make a public improvement by special assessment, they shall, by resolution, set forth the improvement intended to be made and direct the manager to prepare a report, with the assistance of the engineer, containing any information they may request concerning such improvement. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.09) 
Sec. 21-31. - Plans and specifications. 
    The city manager, pursuant to section 21-30, shall request the engineer to prepare, or cause to be prepared, plans and specifications of the improvement to be made, an estimate of the life of the improvement and of the cost thereof, and plats of the lands affected thereby, and such other information as the commission may have requested. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.10) 
Sec. 21-32. - Report of manager. 
    The city manager shall prepare a report and include in it a schedule of all property affected by the proposed improvement under section 21-30, listing the assessed valuation, tax delinquencies, whether land is vacant or improved, and pertinent information on such parcels as are owned by public authorities, and such other information as the commission may have requested, and shall present it to the commission along with the plans and specifications of the engineer, together with such manager's recommendation as to what proportion of the cost should be paid by special assessment and what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city; the number of installments in which the assessment should be spread and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.11) 
Sec. 21-33. - Notice of hearing. 
    After the filing of the report and plans and specifications referred to in this article, a public hearing shall be held before the commission, which hearing shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice of the time and place thereof has been published and sent by the clerk by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.12) 
Sec. 21-34. - Public hearing. 
    At the time and place specified in the notice for the public hearing under section 21-33, the commission shall meet and hear any person to be affected by the proposed public improvement. The hearing may be adjourned from time to time by the commission and the commission may make any changes in the proposed work or assessment which shall seem reasonable or proper in view of any objections, or for any other reason which may appear to be for the best interests of the city; provided that if the improvements intended to be made are enlarged upon or additions made to the district to be assessed, the same shall not be done until after another hearing is held pursuant to notice as required for original hearings. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.13) 
Sec. 21-35. - Resolution of determination. 
    After the public hearing under section 21-34, the commission may, by resolution, determine to make the improvement and defray the whole or any part of the cost of the improvement by special assessment upon the property especially benefited in proportion to the benefits derived or to be derived. By such resolution the commission shall approve the plans and specifications for the improvement, determine the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied, direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the commission's determination, and designate the name by which such assessment roll shall be known and referred to. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.14) 
Sec. 21-36. - Special assessment roll. 
    The assessor shall, after a resolution of determination has been adopted under section 21-35, prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the commission and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands in the special assessment district as the benefit to such lot or parcel of land bears to the total benefits to all lands in such district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assessed to the city at large. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.15) 
Sec. 21-37. - Certificate of assessor. 
    When the assessor shall have completed the assessment roll under section 21-36, such assessor shall attach thereto, or endorse thereon, a certificate to the effect that such roll has been made by such assessor pursuant to a resolution of the commission, giving date of adoption of same, and that in making the assessment therein, the assessor has, as near as may be, according to such assessor's best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and the Charter and the provisions of this chapter. Thereupon, the assessor shall file such special assessment roll with the clerk, who shall present the same to the commission. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.16) 
Sec. 21-38. - Notice of hearing on roll. 
    Upon receipt of the special assessment roll under section 21-37, the commission shall order it filed in the office of the clerk for public examination and shall fix the time and place when it will meet and review such roll, which meeting shall be held not less than ten (10) days after notice thereof has been published and sent by the clerk by first class mail to all property owners in the proposed district as shown by the current assessment roll of the city. Such notice shall specify the time and place of such meeting. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.17) 
Sec. 21-39. - Written objections. 
    Any persons deeming themselves aggrieved by the special assessment roll under this article may, in accordance with Section 10.2(c) of the Charter, file their objections thereto in writing with the clerk prior to the close of the hearing, which written objections shall specify in what respect they deem themselves aggrieved. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.18) 
Sec. 21-40. - Hearing on objections. 
    The commission shall meet and review the special assessment roll under this article at the time and place appointed or at an adjourned date therefor and shall consider any written objections thereto. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.19) 
Sec. 21-41. - Objection to improvement. 
    If, at or prior to final confirmation of any special assessment, more than fifty (50) per cent of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed for any improvement, or in case of paving or similar improvements, if the owners of more than fifty (50) per cent of the frontage to be assessed for any such improvement shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, the improvement shall not be made without the affirmative vote of five (5) members of the commission, provided that this section shall not apply to sidewalk construction. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.20) 
Sec. 21-42. - Corrections and changes. 
    The commission may correct the special assessment roll under this article as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the commission minutes. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.21) 
Sec. 21-43. - Confirmation or rejection of roll. 
    After the hearing and review on the special assessment roll under this article, the commission may confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made, if any, or may refer it back to the assessor for revision or may annul it and any proceedings in connection therewith. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.22) 
Sec. 21-44. - Certificate of confirmation. 
    The clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation upon each special assessment roll under this article and upon confirmation such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.23) 
Sec. 21-45. - Contractual assessment. 
    In the event that all persons or property owners to be affected by any proposed improvement agree that such proposed improvement be made and that a special assessment be levied in connection therewith, the city may, in lieu of the foregoing procedure, enter into a written contract with all of the persons or property owners affected thereby, which contract when properly approved and executed shall operate as a complete special assessment procedure and the assessment shall be made in accordance with such contract. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.24) 
Secs. 21-46-21-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SIDEWALK PROCEDURE 

Sec. 21-57. - Initiatory resolution. 
    When, in the opinion of the commission, any sidewalk needs to be constructed, rebuilt or repaired, they shall by resolution direct the manager to prepare a report, with the assistance of the engineer, containing any information they may request concerning such work. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.30) 
Sec. 21-58. - Plans and specifications. 
    The manager shall request the engineer to prepare or cause to be prepared plans and specifications of the work to be done pursuant to this article, a schedule of the lands affected and such other information as the commission may have requested. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.31) 
Sec. 21-59. - Report of manager. 
    The manager shall prepare a report as directed by section 21-57 and include in it a schedule of all property affected by the work proposed to be done, and pertinent information on such parcels as are owned by public authorities, and such other information as the commission may have requested, and shall present it to the commission along with the plans and specifications of the engineer, together with a recommendation as to what part, if any, should be a general obligation of the city, the number of installments in which the assessment should be spread and the lands which should be included in the special assessment district. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.32) 
Sec. 21-60. - Initiative by manager. 
    When, in the opinion of the manager, any sidewalk needs to be constructed, rebuilt or repaired, the manager may request the engineer to prepare or cause to be prepared plans and specifications of the work needed to be done, and a schedule of the lands affected, and the manager shall submit such information along with a report and recommendations to the commission, in the same manner as though the commission had requested it. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.33) 
Sec. 21-61. - Resolution of determination; notice. 
    After reviewing the plans and specifications and the report of the manager under this article, the commission shall, if they so desire, determine by resolution that the work be done, setting forth the details concerning it, prescribe a form of notice and direct the clerk to give such notice by first class mail, addressed to the last-known address of the owner of the land to be assessed. The notice shall specify the extent of the work to be done, describe the property affected by the work and require the owner to perform the work promptly in accordance with the plans and specifications of the engineer and designate a time within which the same shall be done. 
(Code 1957, §§ 4-1.34, 4-1.35) 
Sec. 21-62. - Work done by city. 
    If, at the expiration of the time limit specified in the notice under section 21-61, within which the work must be done, the owner has not complied with the requirements thereof, the commission shall, by resolution, order such sidewalk to be constructed, rebuilt or repaired under the direction of the manager by the proper department or by contract or by hire. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.36) 
Sec. 21-63. - Manager's duties. 
    The manager shall take all steps necessary to carry out the direction of the commission in performing the work ordered under this article, shall keep, or cause to be kept, an accurate record of all expense in connection therewith, and upon completion of the work to be performed, shall submit a report of the work done and of all expense in connection therewith, to the commission. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.37) 
Sec. 21-64. - Assessment of costs. 
    The commission shall, by resolution, after examination of the manager's report under this article, determine what amount or part of each such expense shall be charged and the person, if known, against whom, and the premises upon which the same shall be levied as a special assessment. By such resolution, the commission shall determine the number of installments in which the assessment may be paid, designate the district or land and premises upon which special assessments shall be levied, direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the commission's determination, and designate the name by which such assessment roll shall be known and referred to. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.38) 
Secs. 21-65-21-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SINGLE LOT PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Removal of junkyards by the city and assessment of cost to property owner, § 9-38; abatement of nuisances, § 18-13; abatement of Dutch elm disease, § 25-38. 

Sec. 21-76. - Report of manager. 
    When any expense shall have been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single lot or parcel of land, which expense is chargeable against such lot or parcel of land and is not of that class required to be prorated among several lots or parcels of land in a special assessment district, the amount of labor and material or any other expense or service for which such expense was incurred, with a description of the lot or parcel of land upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred, and the name of the owner, if known, shall be reported by the manager to the commission. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.39) 
Sec. 21-77. - Resolution of determination. 
    After reviewing the report of the manager under section 21-76, the commission may, if they so desire, determine by resolution what amount or part of each such expense shall be charged, and the person, if known, against whom, and the premises upon which the same shall be levied as a special assessment. By such resolution, the commission shall determine the number of installments in which the assessment may be paid, designate the land and premises upon which the special assessment shall be levied, direct the assessor to prepare a special assessment roll in accordance with the commission's determination, and designate the name by which such assessment roll shall be known and referred to. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.40) 
Secs. 21-78-21-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT ROLL-SIDEWALK OR SINGLE LOT PROCEDURE 

Sec. 21-89. - Preparation by assessor. 
    Upon resolution by the city commission pertaining to a special assessment in connection with sidewalks or a single lot, the assessor shall thereupon prepare a special assessment roll including all lots and parcels of land within the special assessment district designated by the commission and shall assess to each such lot or parcel of land such sums as may have been directed by the commission. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.41) 
Sec. 21-90. - Certificate of assessor. 
    When the assessor shall have completed the assessment roll under section 21-89, such assessor shall attach thereto and endorse thereon a certificate to the effect that such roll has been made by such assessor pursuant to a resolution of the commission, giving date of adoption of same, and that in making the assessment therein, he has, as near as may be, according to such assessor's best judgment, conformed in all respects to the directions contained in such resolution and the Charter and the provisions of this Code. Thereupon, the assessor shall file such special assessment roll with the clerk. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.42) 
Sec. 21-91. - Notice of hearing. 
    Upon receipt of a special assessment roll under section 21-90, the clerk shall give notice by first class mail, which notice shall state the basis of the assessment, the amount thereof, describe the property affected thereby and give a reasonable time, which shall not be less than thirty (30) days, in which a hearing may be had thereon or payment made. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.43) 
Sec. 21-92. - Hearing on objections. 
    In the event payment is not made within the time specified in the resolution and notice under section 21-91, the commission shall meet at the time and place provided and hear any objections to such roll as prepared. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.44) 
Sec. 21-93. - Corrections and changes. 
    The commission may correct the assessment roll prepared under this article as to any assessment or description of any lot or parcel of land, or other errors appearing therein. Any changes made in such roll shall be noted in the commission minutes. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.45) 
Sec. 21-94. - Confirmation. 
    After the hearing on the assessment roll under section 21-92, the commission shall confirm such special assessment roll with such corrections as may have been made and the clerk shall endorse the date of confirmation thereon and upon confirmation, such roll shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.46) 
Secs. 21-95-21-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - LIENS 

Sec. 21-106. - Creation; character. 
    All special assessments and all interest and charges thereon, from the date of confirmation of the roll, shall be and remain a lien upon the property assessed of the same character and effect as the lien created by the Charter for city taxes, and shall include accrued interest and penalties, until paid. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.47) 
Sec. 21-107. - Destruction or impairment. 
    No judgment or decree, nor any action of the commission vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the premises assessed for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the same, or as by regular mode of proceeding, might have been lawfully assessed thereon. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.48) 
Sec. 21-108. - Effect of failure of owner to receive notice. 
    Failure of any owner to receive any notice required to be sent under the provisions of the Charter and this Code shall not invalidate any special assessment or special assessment roll. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.49) 
Sec. 21-109. - Personal liability of owner. 
    In addition to the property tax lien created under this article, any special assessment levied by the city shall constitute a debt owed to the city from the owner of the lot or parcel of land assessed and may be collected in the same manner as any contracted debt, or in the same manner as provided by law for the collection of personal property taxes. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.50) 
Secs. 21-110-21-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 21-121. - Installment payments. 
    Annual installments for special assessment payments shall not exceed ten (10) in number, as the commission may determine at the time of confirmation of the roll; and in the event a division of the assessment operates to make any installment less than ten dollars ($10.00), the assessor shall reduce the number of installments so that each installment shall be above and as near to ten dollars ($10.00) as possible. The initial installment payment shall be due on such date as the commission shall prescribe, and subsequent annual installments shall be due on the anniversary of the due date of the first installment. 
    The commission may, however, provide that subsequent yearly installments be spread on the annual city tax roll. In such cases the second installment shall be collected as part of the first city tax roll which becomes due six (6) months or more after the due date of the initial installment. 
    All unpaid installments except the initial installment shall bear interest at the rate of six (6) per cent per year from such date as the commission shall prescribe. Such interest on the entire unpaid balance shall be spread as one item with each unpaid installment and shall be computed to the last day on which such installment may be paid without collection fee. The commission may provide for advance payment of unpaid installments with interest computed to such date as the commission prescribes. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.51) 
Sec. 21-122. - Notice to pay. 
    The assessment roll shall be transmitted by the clerk to the treasurer for collection immediately after confirmation, and in the event it is not a part of the annual tax roll, the treasurer shall give notice to each owner of such owner's assessment by first class mail specifying when and where payments may be made thereon; provided, however, that failure to mail any such statement shall not invalidate the assessment or entitle the owner to an extension of time within which to pay the assessment. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.52) 
Sec. 21-123. - Charter procedure. 
    Each special assessment or installment thereof shall be collected in accordance with Section 10.7 of the Charter. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.53) 
Secs. 21-124-21-134. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - REFUNDS, REASSESSMENTS AND ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENTS 

Sec. 21-135. - Compilation of cost and adjustment of assessment roll. 
    The manager shall, within sixty (60) days after the completion of each local or special public improvement, compile the actual cost thereof and certify the same to the assessor, who shall adjust the special assessment roll to correspond therewith. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.54) 
Sec. 21-136. - Additional assessments. 
    When any special assessment roll shall prove insufficient to pay the cost of the improvement for which it was made, the commission may make an additional pro rata assessment. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.55) 
Sec. 21-137. - Refunds. 
    Should a special assessment prove larger than necessary by five (5) per cent or less, the same shall be reported to the commission, who may place the excess in the city treasury or make a refund thereof pro rata according to the assessment. If the assessment exceeds the amount necessary by more than five (5) per cent, the entire excess shall be refunded to the owners of the property upon which payments have been made in full, pro rata according to the assessment. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.56) 
Sec. 21-138. - Refund procedure on installments. 
    Any excess refund under section 21-137 where payment in full has not been received shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments in the inverse order in which they are payable to the extent such installments exist, and the balance of such refund shall be made in cash. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.57) 
Sec. 21-139. - Restriction against refund. 
    No refunds of special assessments may be made which impair or contravene the provisions of any outstanding obligation or bond secured in whole or in part by such special assessment. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.58) 
Sec. 21-140. - New assessments to cure illegal or invalid assessments. 
    Whenever the commission shall deem that any special assessment is invalid or defective for any reason whatsoever, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall have adjudged such assessment to be illegal, for any reason whatsoever, in whole or in part, the commission shall have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made, whether the improvement or any part thereof has been completed or not, and whether any part of the assessment has been collected or not. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.59) 
Sec. 21-141. - Reassessment proceedings. 
    All proceedings on reassessments and for the collection thereof shall be made in the same manner as provided in an original assessment; and if any portion of the original assessment shall have been collected and not refunded, it shall be applied upon the reassessment and the reassessment shall to that extent be deemed satisfied. If more than the amount reassessed shall have been collected, the balance shall be refunded to the persons making such payments. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.60) 
Secs. 21-142-21-152. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - RESTRICTIONS IMPOSED 

Sec. 21-153. - Creation of special fund required. 
    Except as otherwise provided in the Charter, and this Code, moneys raised by special assessments to pay the cost of any local improvement shall be held in a special fund to pay such cost or to repay any moneys borrowed therefor. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.61) 
Sec. 21-154. - Restricted use of funds. 
    Each special assessment account must be used only for the improvement project for which the assessment was levied except as otherwise provided in Chapter 10 of the Charter. 
(Code 1957, § 4-1.62) 
Chapter 22 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to regulate streets and sidewalks, § 2.3(f). 
Cross reference- Advertising, Ch. 3; airport, Ch. 5; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; junkyards prohibited near public rights-of-way, § 9-37; use of streets by peddlers, § 9-48; cemeteries, Ch. 10; kindling of fires in public places, § 12-44; garbage, rubbish, litter and junk, Ch. 13; sweeping litter into gutters prohibited, § 13-41; merchants' duty to keep sidewalk free from litter, § 13-42; miscellaneous offenses and provisions, Ch. 16; public place includes school grounds, § 16-1; loitering, § 16-3; spitting in public, § 16-9; indecent exposure, § 16-70; nuisances, Ch. 18; barbed wire fences near public places prohibited, § 18-5; signs, Ch. 20; subdivision regulations, Ch. 23; street improvements in subdivisions, § 23-50; sidewalk improvements in subdivisions, § 23-51; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24; operation of off-road vehicles in alleys, on streets and sidewalks prohibited, § 24-159; vegetation, Ch. 25; water supply and sewage disposal system, Ch. 27; zoning ordinance, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Promulgation of rules and regulations by city manager. 
(a)  The city manager shall make such additional rules and regulations pertaining to the making of openings or excavations in streets, the building of any vault, stair or areaway in or under the streets; or the transportation of any heavy or frequent load upon or over the streets, as are necessary to secure the health, safety and property of the public. 
(b)  Any such rule or regulation so made shall be in writing and a copy thereof shall be filed with the city clerk before it is put into effect. The clerk shall present such rule or regulation to the city commission for its consideration not later than the next regular meeting of the commission after the filing of same. No such rule or regulation shall remain in effect if disapproved by the city commission. 
(c)  Such rules or regulations shall not be violated by any person and shall constitute the standards upon which the required permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.08; Ord. No. 428-98, § 1, 2-2-98) 
Sec. 22-2. - Inspection by city manager relative to permits issued. 
    The city shall inspect all work done or privileges exercised under any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. The city manager may, for cause, suspend or revoke any permit if the workmanship or materials used do not conform to the plans and specifications approved or required upon issuance of the permit, or if any of the terms of any permit or of this chapter are violated. No person shall perform any work authorized by any permit or cause any such work to be performed while such permit is suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.07) 
Sec. 22-3. - Bond and insurance policies necessary for permits. 
    In each case where a bond or policy of insurance is required of any person as a condition precedent to the granting of any permit required by this chapter, such bond or policy of insurance shall be in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) unless a larger bond shall be required by the city manager at the time any permit is granted. All bonds or policies of insurance shall be conditioned to pay all damages to the streets of the city, to hold the city harmless from every other damage of every other nature, whether to persons or property for which such city may be held liable by reason of, or which is occasioned by, the doing of a thing or the exercise of the privilege for which the permit upon which the bond or policy of insurance was based, not granted. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.09) 
Sec. 22-4. - Curb construction and repair. 
(a)  No person shall construct, reconstruct, repair or remove any curb, gutter or structure for regulating, governing or facilitating the flow of water except in accordance with line, grade and specifications established by the city engineer, and without first obtaining a written permit from the city clerk. 
(b)  No person shall make any opening in or through any curb of any street or alley without first obtaining a written permit from the city clerk. Such opening shall be in accordance with plans and specifications established by the city engineer and approved by the engineer. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued under this section: 
(1)  When such opening is to be made permanent and is within twenty (20) feet of any other permanent opening on the same premises; 
(2)  When such opening is to be made permanent and is intended to be more than thirty-five (35) feet in its total width; 
(3)  When such opening is on corner property and is within the quadrant of the intersection or the sidewalk area; and 
(4)  When it is the finding of the city manager that such opening will interfere with the safety of the public. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.02) 
Sec. 22-5. - Street openings and excavations. 
(a)  Unless acting under a contract with the city, no person, other than a duly authorized city official or employee in the course of their employment, or an official or employee of a recognized public utility company, or a licensed drain layer, shall make any excavation or opening in or under any public street or alley or upon any public property without first obtaining the approval of the city manager and a written permit from the city clerk; provided, however, no railroad company shall be required to obtain a permit for the purpose of repairing the roadbed of its railway or replacing or repairing the pavement or surface between its tracks and two (2) feet outside thereof; provided further that in case of emergency arising out of office hours when an immediate excavation may be necessary for the protection of public or private property, the same shall be reported to the city police, who may grant permission to make the necessary excavation upon the express condition that an application to the city clerk be made before noon of the next following business day. 
(b)  The issuance of such permit shall be contingent upon fulfillment of the following conditions: 
(1)  That the applicant shall keep the operations carefully barricaded, lighted at night, and otherwise protected as required by the city manager or the city police for the protection of the public; 
(2)  That the applicant shall work as continuously as practicable to complete operations within the time specified in the permit. 
(c)  No person shall fail to complete the work within the time limit specified in the permit. If, in the judgment of the city manager, the work is not prosecuted in such a manner as to insure completion within the time limit specified, the city may undertake the work and may collect the cost therefor from the applicant in an action at law. 
(d)  Unless previously approved by the city manager, no person shall render more than one-half the traveled width of any street or alley unavailable for travel in connection with any opening or excavation. If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(e)  All work, including backfilling, shall be done under the supervision and in accordance with the instructions of the city engineer. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.03) 
Sec. 22-6. - Permit required to interfere with normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(a)  Any person who, for any purpose, substantially: blocks, obstructs, impedes, or otherwise interferes with the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic of any highway, street, alley, or sidewalk shall first obtain a "street closing permit" from the city clerk. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to department of public works, police or fire employees acting in performance of their duties. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.04; Ord. No. 559-15, § 1, 4-20-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 559-15, § 1, adopted April 20, 2015, amended § 22-6 to read as set out herein. Previously § 22-6 was titled "Closing of streets." 
Sec. 22-7. - Entry into construction area prohibited. 
    No person shall enter upon: any excavated area, utility construction area, street construction area, sidewalk construction area, new pavement, new sidewalk, new curbing, or new gutter, until: 
(1)  The same has been completed, and 
(2)  Any street closing sign or barricade posted or placed thereon has been removed by the proper city officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 559-15, § 1, 4-20-15) 
Sec. 22-8. - Interference with signs and barricades prohibited. 
    No unauthorized person shall move, alter, deface, injure or destroy any part or accessory of any street or alley or any sign or barricade erected or placed thereon to protect, warn or guide the public. 
(Ord. No. 559-15, § 1, 4-20-15) 
Secs. 22-9-22-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to construct and maintain sidewalks, § 2.3(u). 

Sec. 22-18. - Permit required; specifications established by city engineer. 
    No person shall construct, reconstruct, repair or remove any sidewalk without first obtaining a written permit from the city clerk for such work in accordance with line, grade, slope and specifications established by the city engineer. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.01) 
Sec. 22-19. - State of disrepair prohibited; notice to abate; abatement. 
(a)  No person shall permit any sidewalk which adjoins such person's property to fall into a state of disrepair or to become unsafe. 
(b)  Whenever the city manager shall determine that a sidewalk is unsafe, notice may be given in the manner set forth in section 1-8. 
(c)  In the event the owner fails to repair the sidewalk within five (5) days after delivery or posting of such notice, it shall be a violation of this section and each additional day the sidewalk shall remain out of repair shall be a separate violation. 
(d)  If the sidewalk remains out of repair for more than five (5) days after such notice has been given, the city manager may cause the same to be repaired and may collect the cost of the repairs from the owner in accordance with article V of chapter 21. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.01) 
Sec. 22-20. - Protection around openings required. 
    No person shall open or use any opening in a sidewalk unless the same is provided with a suitable protection and guard approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.01) 
Sec. 22-21. - Rebate to owner or occupant after completion. 
    In case the owner or occupant of any premises in the city shall, either upon permission being granted, or after being ordered by the city manager, construct or reconstruct a sidewalk according to specifications, and in accordance with this article, such owner or occupant shall be entitled, upon completion of the same, to the satisfaction of the city manager, to a rebate from the city as follows: 
For new sidewalks, twenty (20) per cent of the total cost of the construction in front of the property and all of the cost of construction in street or alley intersections; for sidewalks constructed to replace walks out of repair and requiring replacement, fifty (50) per cent of the total cost of such construction, provided, the rebate to be made by the city for the cost of construction of a sidewalk under which space is occupied in whole or in part as a part of the adjacent building and the construction of which requires special reinforcement and construction, shall be determined by resolution of the city commission. In case the owner of any property in the city shall neglect to, or refuse to, construct any concrete walk when the same is ordered by the city manager, and such walk be constructed at the expense of the city, then and in such case the owner of such property shall not be entitled to a rebate therefrom, but the entire cost if not paid shall be assessed against the abutting property. 
(Ord. No. 20, § 7-1.01, 4-22-63) 
Secs. 22-22-22-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 24. 

Sec. 22-34. - Scope. 
    The requirements of this article shall be so construed as to allow the full exercise of municipal authority with respect to the public peace, health, safety and convenience in any manner which may be desirable. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Sec. 22-35. - Generally. 
    No person shall in any way obstruct or encroach upon any street, sidewalk or alley. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Sec. 22-36. - Adjacent property owners or occupants to obey orders of superintendent of public works to remove obstructions. 
    No person, having the care, either as owner or occupant, of any premises bordered by a paved or graded sidewalk, shall fail to remove promptly therefrom all rubbish, litter, obstructions of any kind, or nuisances of every sort, and snow and ice when ordered by the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.01) 
Sec. 22-37. - Moving of buildings. 
    No person shall move or cause to be moved any building along or across any public street, alley or other public property unless the same can be moved without impairing the public safety, without undue risk of damage or injury to property, public or private, and without unreasonable interference with traffic. An application to move any building shall be filed with the city clerk. The application shall set forth in detail the size and type of building proposed to be moved, and the points between which it is proposed to move the same. The city clerk shall cause an investigation to be made. If the city clerk finds the building can be moved without impairing the public safety, or unreasonably interfering with traffic, or undue risk of damage to private or public property, a permit may be issued upon payment of the proper fee. Such permit shall specify the time and route over which the moving shall be done. No such permit shall be issued until the applicant shall have filed with the city clerk a bond or policy of insurance as provided in section 22-3. If the city clerk shall refuse any permit, the applicant may appeal to the city manager who shall grant a hearing thereon. The decision of the city manager shall be final. In granting a permit, the city manager may impose such conditions as such manager deems desirable to protect the safety of persons and property during the moving of such building and to assure the replacement of any utility wires, poles and other street appurtenances moved or taken down therefor. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 22-38. - Construction or repair of structures lying in right-of-way. 
    No person shall construct or repair any structure of any nature whatsoever lying within the limits of a street or alley right-of-way without first obtaining a written permit from the city clerk. Such construction or repairs shall be in accordance with the line, grade and specifications established by the city engineer and shall be approved by such engineer. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 22-39. - Leaving leaves or grass in streets or alleys. 
    No person shall place or leave any leaves or grass in the public streets or alleys except for immediate disposal. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Sec. 22-40. - Ashes left in public alleys. 
    No person having the care, either as owner or occupant, of any premises bordered by a public alley shall allow any ashes to remain in the alley adjacent to the premises. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Sec. 22-41. - Construction materials and facilities. 
    No person shall use any street or alley for the temporary storage of building material, equipment, merchandise or facilities or for barricading or protecting building operations without first obtaining a written permit from the city clerk. No building material, equipment or facilities so stored shall be placed in such a manner as to interfere with the normal drainage facilities of the street or alley. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 22-42. - Suspension of awnings or other articles. 
    No person shall suspend or support in any manner any article or thing which will overhang any portion of a public street or alley, except as otherwise provided in this Code. Awnings overhanging a public sidewalk or other public pedestrian-way are permitted, provided such awnings have no less than seven and one-half (71/2) feet of clearance between the lowest projection of the awning and the surface of the public sidewalk or pedestrian way and provided that the awning projects over the public sidewalk or pedestrian way no more than nine (9) feet, or two (2) feet less than the width of the sidewalk, whichever is less, from the lot line of the adjacent premises. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05; Ord. No. 369-92, § 1, 5-4-92) 
Sec. 22-43. - Business merchandise, food and beverage. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to suspend, place or set out for display or sale any goods, wares, food, beverage, or merchandise on any public sidewalk. 
(2)  On sidewalks (i) contained in the area described in subsection (4) and (ii) adjacent to properties zoned under the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Sault Ste. Marie as T, B-2 and B-3, the adjoining owners, lessees or occupants may use the sidewalks in accordance with the provisions of this section for open-air display of goods, tools, equipment, flowers and similar merchandise, and for temporary seating and tables to the extent that such uses are accessory to the adjoining properties as defined by the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Sault Ste. Marie, subject to the following restrictions: 
(a)  Displays, tables, or seating areas shall be limited to such areas that preserve an unobstructed five (5) feet of sidewalk width (as measured perpendicular from curb to private lot line of the business making the display) for pedestrian use. 
(b)  All displays (including shelving and racks) chairs and tables shall be removed from the sidewalk whenever the adjoining retail operation is closed and no later than 10 p.m. each night. 
(c)  Any display or seating area that interferes with the passage of pedestrians shall be removed. Items shall not pose trips hazards or otherwise pose a hazard to pedestrians including pedestrians with sight impairments. No display or seating area shall occupy the area two (2) feet inward from the side lot lines of the business making the display. 
(d)  Any display or seating area shall be positioned so as not to conflict with door openings of parked cars. 
(e)  All areas shall be well maintained and cleaned regularly by the adjoining property owner, lessee or occupant. 
(f)  No items may be placed in the area at street corners or alley/street corners created by extending the building lines to the traveled portion of the streets or alleys as described below. 
(3)  The use of the sidewalks as provided in subsection (2) shall be permissive and shall constitute no more than a license revocable at will by the city. The city may, if the use of the sidewalk in any way interferes with the use of the rights-of-way, require any or all items to be removed temporarily or permanently from the sidewalk areas. No use of the sidewalks under this section shall in any way entitle an owner, lessee, or occupant of any right, title or interest in and to the sidewalk or any right to continue the uses provided in subsection (2). 
(4)  The area of land in the city eligible for subsection (2) uses of sidewalk must be contained in the following boundaries: 
The physical boundary description is defined as being those properties encompassed by a line drawn and commencing at a point in the centerline of the Edison Sault Electric Company Power Canal and the Bingham Avenue Bridge, thence in a northeasterly direction along the easterly property line boundaries of those properties adjoining or abutting Bingham Avenue on the east side of the street, to a point where this line intersects the St. Mary's River; thence westerly along the shores of said St. Mary's River and the St. Mary's Falls Canal to a point where a line from Magazine Street extended intersects the shore line of said St. Mary's Falls Canal; thence southwesterly along the centerline of Magazine Street to a point approximately 200 feet south of the south line of Portage Avenue West, thence easterly along the rear lot lines of those lots fronting on Portage Avenue to the centerline of Ferris Street, thence southerly along the centerline of Ferris Street to a point in the centerline of Ridge Street, thence easterly along the centerline of Ridge Street to the westerly property lines of those properties abutting Osborn Boulevard to a point where Osborn Boulevard extended through the intersection with Peck Street proceeds to the centerline of the Edison Sault Electric Company Power Canal; thence along the Power Canal centerline in an easterly meandering direction to a point along the westerly property lines of those properties abutting Ashmun Street, thence southwesterly along said westerly property lines of those properties abutting Ashmun Street to the north line of James Street, thence easterly along the north line of James Street to the centerline of Ashmun Street, thence northeasterly along the centerline of Ashmun Street to a point where the centerline of Ashmun Street and the centerline of Adams Street intersects, thence easterly along the centerline of Adams Street to the easterly property line of those properties fronting on Ashmun Street, thence northeasterly along said easterly property l ine of those properties fronting on Ashmun Street to the a point in the centerline of Easterday Ave., thence easterly along the centerline of Easterday Avenue to a point where the centerline of Easterday Avenue and the centerline of Court Street intersects, thence northeasterly along the centerline of Court Street to the centerline of the Edison Sault Electric Company Power Canal, thence southeasterly along said centerline to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05; Ord. No. 479-04, 9-20-04) 
Sec. 22-44. - Keeping of animal carcasses. 
    No person shall hang, keep or cause, permit or suffer to be hung or kept, the carcass of any animal or fowl, or any part thereof, for any purpose, in, upon, or over any public sidewalk. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 22-45. - Use of raising and lowering devices. 
    No person shall raise anything from, or lower anything to, any street, alley or public place by means of rope, chain, pulley or similar device without first obtaining a written permit from the city clerk, and providing protection for pedestrians and traffic using such street or alley. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Sec. 22-46. - Poles and wires. 
    No person other than the officials or employees of a recognized public utility company shall place or remove any pole, string or wire in the public streets or alleys without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk. Such permit shall be granted only if the placement or removal of such pole or wire will not endanger the public safety and if the amount of tree trimming required can be held to a minimum. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 22-47. - Deposit of snow or ice. 
    No person within the city shall deposit snow or ice from any premises or sidewalks and driveways leading to the premises onto the portion of any street or adjacent public right-of-way which is being plowed and maintained for winter pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 51, § 1(7-1.05), 10-2-67; Ord. No. 421-97, § 1, 1-20-97) 
Sec. 22-48. - Designation of sidewalks for snow removal; notice to property owners. 
    The superintendent of public works is hereby authorized to designate from time to time those graded or paved sidewalks from which the snow and ice shall promptly be removed by the owner or occupant of the adjacent premises who has the care of the same. Suitable notice shall be given the public by signs and public announcements of the periods so designated. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.01) 
Charter reference- Authority to compel property owners to remove snow and ice from abutting sidewalks, § 2.3(w). 
Sec. 22-49. - Legal liability of adjacent property owners or occupants. 
    Any person having the care either as owner or occupant of any premises bordered by a public street or alley shall be liable to the city for any legal liability that may be adjudged against the city as a result of the placing of obstructions of any nature in such public street or alley by such person, employees or agents thereof. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.05) 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKS AND RECREATIONAL AREAS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, adopted Aug. 2, 1982, enacted provisions regulating activities in parks and recreational areas designated as Art. IV, §§ 22-50-22-66, to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 22-50. - Closing hours. 
    No unregistered camper or park visitor is to enter or remain in park, campground, day use area, beach or parking area between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-51. - Disorderly conduct prohibited. 
    No person shall engage in any violent, abusive, loud, boisterous, vulgar, lewd, wanton, obscene or otherwise disorderly conduct; to disturb or annoy other persons; or to lounge, sit or lie upon outdoor furniture, walks, paths or roads, in such a manner as to obstruct the free use or passage of other people. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-52. - Excessive noise regulated. 
    No person shall use a loudspeaker, public address system or sound amplification system, of any kind, or operate a motor vehicle, radio, television, or any device in such a manner that produces excessive noise without proper written permission of the park and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-53. - Destruction of vegetation. 
    No person shall destroy, damage or remove any city property, living tree or shrub, planted grasses or other vegetation without proper written permission of the park and recreation department. This does not apply to the picking and removal of mushrooms, berries and other edible fruits and nuts and those wildflowers and the removal of which is not made unlawful by state law or other ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-54. - Refuse and waste disposal. 
    No person shall deposit refuse or waste material which has originated outside the park, campground, or recreational area, in receptacles provided for on-site users, to set fire to the contents of a refuse container; or to place or burn garbage in a fire ring or stove. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-55. - Storage or abandonment of personal property. 
    No person shall store or leave a boat, fish shanty, camping equipment, or any other personal property for more than twenty-four (24) hours without proper written permission of the park and recreation department and community services board. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-56. - Business or commercial uses; permit required. 
    No person shall use the lands for a business or commercial purpose without proper written permission of the parks and recreation department and community services board. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-57. - Destruction of signs or markers. 
    No person shall move, remove, destroy, mutilate or deface posters, notices, signs or markers of the city or any other agency. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-58. - Advertising and construction activities; permit required. 
    No person shall post, place or erect signs; place or distribute advertising material; erect a fence or barrier; construct or occupy improvements or enclose the lands without proper written permission of the parks and recreation department and community services board. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-59. - Weapons restricted. 
    No person shall possess a firearm, air gun, gas gun, spring loaded gun or sling shot. Bows and arrows are allowed only with proper written permission of the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-60. - Camping. 
    Camping is allowed only at designated campsites, no more than one (1) camp shall occupy a campsite. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-61. - Fires. 
    No person shall build a fire except in a designated place or in a stove, grill, or fire ring, as designated by a representative of the park and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-62. - Camp occupancy time limit. 
    No person shall camp in one (1) location for more than ten (10) days without the written permission of the parks and recreation department. Seasonal permit owners can be asked to move or remove their vehicles, for just cause, provided they are given a twenty-four-hour advance notice. Refunds to seasonal permit owners shall be prorated at a regular daily rate, based upon the date the permit was obtained by the camper. The intent of this rule is to protect municipal parks from becoming a second home, and to [prevent] camper or campground problems. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-63. - Animals. 
(a)  No person shall possess a dog or other animal unless it is under immediate and complete control of a leash, not more than six (6) feet long. 
(b)  No animal is to be tied to any inanimate object, i.e. tree, car, table, post, etc. 
(c)  No person shall leave any animal unattended at any park, campground, or recreational site. 
(d)  No person shall in any way harass or attempt to do harm to any natural wildlife or domestic animals at any park or recreational site. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-64. - Operation of vehicles; permit required. 
    No person shall use or operate any wheeled or motorized vehicle: 
(1)  Where there is no visible evidence of a forest road or trail without the written permission of the park and recreation department; 
(2)  In an organized event including but not limited to races and acceleration or endurance contests without the written permission of the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-65. - Certain vehicles prohibited from recreational areas. 
    No person shall operate an off the road motor driven vehicle, such as a minibike, motorcycle, snowmobile, amphibious vehicle or any other motor vehicle except for entrance to and departure from a recreational area. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-66. - Obstruction of accessways. 
    No person shall obstruct any road or trail in a manner that hinders public access to public recreational properties. 
(Ord. No. 226-82, § 1, 8-2-82) 
Sec. 22-67. - Alcoholic beverages regulated. 
    Alcoholic beverages shall not be allowed within the designated swimming area of Sherman Park, and one hundred (100) feet to the south of the designated swimming area, or in the adjacent waters within fifty (50) feet to the east and west of the swimming area, as posted. 
(Ord. No. 309-89, § 1, 8-21-89) 
Sec. 22-68. - Glass containers regulated. 
    Glass containers shall not be allowed within the designated swimming area of Sherman Park, and one hundred (100) feet to the south of the designated swimming area, or in the adjacent waters within fifty (50) feet of the east and west of the swimming area, as posted. 
(Ord. No. 310-89, § 1, 8-21-89) 
Chapter 23 - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 234-83, adopted Apr. 18, 1983, amended Ch. 23, subdivision regulations, in its entirety to read as herein set forth. Prior to such amendment, Ch. 23 had pertained to the same subject matter, substantive sections thereof being §§ 23-1-23-5, 23-17-23-20, 23-32-23-37, 23-49-23-56, 23-68-23-71, as derived from Ord. No. 48, §§ 11-1.01-11-1.08, adopted Dec. 5, 1966. 
Cross reference- Planning and development commission, § 2-59 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; water supply and sewage disposal system, Ch. 27; zoning ordinance, App. A. 
State Law reference- Subdivision control act, MCL § 560.101 et seq., MSA § 26.430(101) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the City of Sault Ste. Marie Subdivision Regulations. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-2. - Statutory authority. 
    This chapter is enacted pursuant to Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of 1967 (the Subdivision Control Act), Act 285 of the Public Acts of 1931 (the Municipal Planning Act) and sections 2.3(x) and 7.7 of the city charter. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-3. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the orderly growth and harmonious development of the community; to secure adequate traffic circulation through coordinated street systems with relation to major thoroughfares, adjoining subdivisions, and public facilities; to achieve individual property lots of maximum utility and liability; to secure adequate provisions for water supply, drainage and sanitary sewerage, and other health requirements; to secure adequate provisions for recreational areas, school sites and other public facilities; and to provide procedures for the achievement of these purposes. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-4. - Application. 
    Any division of land which results in a subdivision as herein defined shall be surveyed and a plat thereof submitted, approved and recorded as provided by the provisions of this chapter and the State Subdivision Control Act. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-5. - Interpretation. 
    The provision of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion and preservation of the public health, safety and general welfare of the city. These regulations are not intended to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any manner interfere with existing regulations or laws of the city nor to conflict with any statutes of the state or county, except that these regulations shall prevail in cases where these regulations impose a greater restriction than is provided by existing statutes, laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-6. - Construction of language and definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms, words and phrases shall, wherever used in this chapter, have the meanings defined as follows: 
    Alley shall mean a public or private right-of-way shown on a plat which provides secondary access to a lot, block or parcel of land. 
    Caption shall mean the name by which the plat is legally and commonly known. 
    Cul-de-sac (court) shall mean a minor street of short length, having one (1) end open to traffic and being permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
    Easement shall mean a quantity of land set aside or over which a liberty, privilege or advantage is granted by the owner to the public, a corporation, or some particular person or part of the public for specific uses and purposes, and shall be designated a "public" or "private" easement depending on the nature of the user. 
    Final plat shall mean a map of all or part of a subdivision prepared and certified as to its accuracy by a registered engineer or land surveyor. Such maps must meet the requirements of the Subdivision Control Act, as amended, and be suitable for recording by the county register of deeds. 
    Improvements shall mean street pavements, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, crosswalks, water mains, sanitary and storm sewers, street trees, street signs and other appropriate items. 
    Land shall mean all land areas occupied by real property. 
    Lot shall mean a measured portion of a parcel or tract of land, which is described and fixed in a recorded plot. 
    Major thoroughfare shall mean an arterial street of great continuity which is intended to serve as a large volume trafficway for both the immediate area and any region beyond and may be designated in the major thoroughfare plan as a major thoroughfare, parkway, expressway or equivalent term to identify streets comprising the basic structure of the street plan. 
    Marginal-access street shall mean a minor street parallel and adjacent to a major thoroughfare; and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
    Master plan shall include graphic and written proposals indicating the general locations recommended for the streets, parks, schools, public buildings, zoning districts, and all physical developments of the city and includes any unit or part of such plan separately adopted, and any amendments to such plan or parts thereof duly adopted by the planning and development commission. 
    Minor street shall mean a street supplementary to a secondary street intended to serve the local needs of the neighborhood and of limited continuity used primarily as access to abutting residential properties. 
    Outlot, when included within the boundary of a recorded plot, means a lot set aside for purposes other than a building site, park or other land dedicated to public use or reserved to private use. 
    Parcel or tract shall mean a continuous area or acreage of land which can be described as provided for in this chapter. 
    Plat shall mean a map or chart of a subdivision of land. 
    Preliminary plat shall mean a map showing the salient features of a proposed subdivision submitted to an approving authority for purposes of preliminary consideration. 
    Proprietor shall mean a natural person, firm, association, partnership, corporation or combination of such which may hold any ownership interest in land whether recorded or not. 
    Public utility shall mean a person, firm, corporation or municipal or other public authority providing gas, electricity, water, steam, telephone, sewer or other services of a similar nature. 
    Public walkway shall mean a right-of-way dedicated for the purpose of a pedestrian access through residential areas and located so as to connect to two (2) or more streets, or a street and public land parcel. 
    Secondary thoroughfare shall mean a street intended to serve as a major means of access from minor streets to major thoroughfares and has considerable continuity within the framework of the major thoroughfare plan.
