    Street shall mean a right-of-way dedicated to public use, which provides vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent properties whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, road, avenue, lane or however otherwise designated, and includes the land between the right-of-way lines whether improved or unimproved, and may comprise pavement, curbs and gutters, shoulders, sidewalks, parking areas, lawn areas and other areas within the right-of-way lines. 
    Subdivide or subdivision shall mean the partitioning or dividing of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by such proprietor's heirs, executors, administrators, legal representatives, successors or assigns for the purpose of sale, or lease for more than one (1) year, or of building development, where the act of division creates five (5) or more parcels of land each of which is ten (10) acres or less in area; or five (5) or more parcels of land each of which is ten (10) acres or less in area are created by successive divisions within a period of ten (10) years. 
    Subdivider shall mean any person proceeding under this chapter to effect a subdivision of land for such person or for another. 
    Subdivision Control Act shall mean Public Act 288 of 1967 of the State of Michigan (MCL Sec. 560.101 et seq., MSA Sec. 26.430(101) et seq.) as amended. 
    Surveyor shall mean either a land surveyor who is registered in Michigan as a registered land surveyor or a civil engineer who is registered in Michigan as a registered professional engineer. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-7. - Platting procedure. 
    The preparation of a subdivision for platting shall be carried out through three (3) stages, comprised of preliminary plat-tentative approval, preliminary plat-final approval and final plat. Approval of such plats shall be conditioned upon compliance with the provisions of this chapter and the State Subdivision Control Act. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Secs. 23-8, 23-9. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRE-PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 23-10. - Pre-preliminary plat. 
    Prior to the preparation of a preliminary plat, the subdivider is encouraged to meet informally with the city manager to investigate the standards of the city with reference to this chapter and the proposals of the master plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located. The subdivider shall be concerned with the following factors: 
(1)  The area for the proposed subdivision shall be properly zoned for the intended use; 
(2)  An investigation of adequacy of existing schools and the adequacy of public open spaces including parks and playgrounds to service the proposed subdivision shall be made by the subdivider; 
(3)  The relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for widening of thoroughfares shall be investigated by the subdivider. 
(4)  Standards for sewage disposal, water supply and drainage of the city and health standards of the county and state shall be investigated by the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Secs. 23-11-23-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PRELIMINARY PLAT; TENTATIVE APPROVAL 

Sec. 23-20. - General requirements. 
    Before making or submitting a final plat for approval, the proprietor shall make a preliminary plat and submit copies to the city for review and tentative approval. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-21. - Filing. 
    An application, together with seven (7) copies of the preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision and the filing fee, shall be submitted to the city clerk at least three (3) weeks prior to the regular planning and development commission meeting (which meeting shall be considered as the date of filing). The following information shall be included in the application and preliminary plat submission: 
(1)  Proposed name of subdivision, such name to not duplicate the name of any plat previously recorded in Chippewa County, unless the subject plat is contiguous to a plat of the same name. 
(2)  Legal description of the property. 
(3)  Names and addresses of the subdivider or owner and the designer, engineer or surveyor who designed the subdivision layout, together with the seal of the engineer or surveyor who prepared the plat. The subdivider shall indicate his interest in the land as to whether it is a land contract interest or if the subdivider owns the property in fee. 
(4)  The plat shall be drawn to a scale of not more than two hundred (200) feet to one (1) inch and shall be dated. 
(5)  The plat shall include the following existing conditions: 
a.  An overall map showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings; 
b.  The location of the proposed subdivision in relation to schools, shopping, parks and other community facilities; 
c.  The boundary line of the proposed subdivision and section or municipal corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract; 
d.  Adjacent tracts of subdivided and unsubdivided land shown in relation to the tract; 
e.  Locations, widths and names of existing or prior platted streets and private streets and public easements within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision; 
f.  Location of existing sewers, water mains, storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the tract; 
g.  Topography drawn as contours with an interval at least five (5) feet, except as may otherwise be required for proper review of special grading or drainage problems. 
(6)  The plat shall include the following information on the proposed development: 
a.  Layout of streets indicating proposed street names, right-of-way widths and connection with adjoining platted streets, and widths and locations of alleys, easements and public walkways or bikeways; 
b.  Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots, including building setback lines, and proposed addresses as designated by the engineering department; 
c.  Identification of parcels to be set aside or dedicated to public use for the use of property owners in the subdivision, or lands set aside for future street connections to adjacent tracts, or lots set aside for other purposes in conformance with the zoning ordinance; 
d.  The proposed systems for sanitary sewerage, water supply and storm drainage; 
e.  Proposed contour changes and areas of cut or fill; 
f.  Profile drawings showing proposed street center line profiles, the proposed sanitary sewer profiles and the proposed storm sewer profiles; 
g.  In the case where a subdivider wishes to subdivide a given area, but wishes to begin with only a portion of the total area, the preliminary plat shall include the layout for the entire area. The part which is proposed to be subdivided first shall be clearly identified, and a staging program shall be submitted. Each subsequent plat shall follow the same procedures until the entire area is subdivided. 
The city clerk shall receive the preliminary plat and check for completeness and, if complete, cause the proposal to be placed on the agenda of the next planning and development commission meeting. Should any requirement in this section be omitted, the city clerk shall notify the subdivider of the additional data required and delay further planning and development commission action until the required data is received. The clerk shall transmit a copy of the preliminary plat to the city engineer and city planner for their technical review. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-22. - Filing fee. 
    A fee payable to the city shall accompany an application for preliminary plat review. The fee amount shall be as presently established or as changed from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83; Ord. No. 375-93, § 1, 6-21-93) 
Sec. 23-23. - Review by the planning and development commission. 
(a)  The planning and development commission shall review a preliminary plat at a public hearing, notice of such hearing to be sent by registered mail to the applicant and the owners of land immediately adjoining the proposed tract as their names appear on the tax records of the city and to all utility companies serving the city; such notice to be sent not less than seven (7) days prior to such meeting. 
(b)  The planning and development commission shall review all details of the proposed subdivision within the framework of the master plan, the zoning ordinance and within the design standards of this chapter. 
(c)  Land requirements for public use within the framework of the master plan shall be considered in the review of a submitted preliminary plat. 
(d)  The planning and development commission, within thirty (30) days of the date such preliminary plat first appears on a regular meeting agenda, shall act on the preliminary plat, unless the subdivider agrees to an extension of time in writing: 
(1)  Should the planning and development commission reject the plat, it shall record the reasons in the minutes of the meeting, a copy of which shall be sent to the subdivider and to the city commission; 
(2)  Should the planning and development commission approve the plat, the chairman shall make a notation to that effect on each copy of the preliminary plat and return one (1) copy to the subdivider, forwarding three (3) copies to the city commission with recommendation for tentative approval, and retain one (1) copy for permanent records; 
(3)  Should the planning and development commission conditionally approve the plat, the preliminary plat shall not be forwarded to the city commission until such conditions have been satisfied by the subdivider. The revised design shall follow submittal procedure in section 23-21 except that no additional fee shall be required. The planning and development commission may set a time limit for satisfaction or said conditions and deem the plat rejected without further action if not resubmitted within the time limit. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-24. - City commission action. 
    Following receipt of the planning and development commission recommendations, the city commission shall consider the plat at such meeting that the matter is placed on the regularly scheduled agenda. The city commission shall take action within ninety (90) days from the date of filing of the preliminary plat: 
(1)  Should the city commission reject the plat, it shall indicate the requirements necessary for obtaining tentative approval, returning one (1) copy to the subdivider. 
(2)  Should the city commission approve the plat, such approval shall constitute tentative approval and shall be so noted on each copy of the preliminary plat, returning one (1) copy to the subdivider and retaining two (2) copies in the city's permanent records. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-25. - Approval; time limit. 
    Tentative approval of a preliminary plat by the city commission shall confer upon the subdivider for a period of one (1) year from the date of action, approval of lot sizes, lot orientation and street layout. Such tentative approval may be extended if applied for by the subdivider and granted by the city commission in writing. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Secs. 23-26-23-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PRELIMINARY PLAT; FINAL APPROVAL 

Sec. 23-30. - General requirements. 
    Prior to submitting a preliminary plat for final approval to the city, the subdivider shall obtain the approval of the plat by all applicable county and state agencies required to review the plat, including the county road commission, county drain commission, department of transportation, conservation department, water resources commission, health department and county plat board. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-31. - Filing. 
    The subdivider shall submit the following information to the city clerk within one (1) year of the tentative approval of preliminary plat: 
(1)  A list of all authorities required to review the preliminary plat as per Sections 112 to 119 of the Subdivision Control Act. 
(2)  Approved copies of the preliminary plat, after all necessary approvals have been secured. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-32. - City commission action. 
    Following receipt of the necessary approved copies of the preliminary plat, the city commission shall consider and review the preliminary plat at its next meeting, or within twenty (20) days from the date of submission: 
(1)  Should the city commission reject the plat, it shall state the reasons in writing; 
(2)  If the subdivider has met all conditions laid down for approval of the preliminary plat, and substantially conforms to the tentatively approved plat, the city commission shall give final approval to the preliminary plat and shall notify the subdivider in writing. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-33. - Approval; time limit. 
    Final approval of a preliminary plat shall confer upon the subdivider for a period of two (2) years from the date of action, the conditional right that the general terms and conditions under which the approval was granted will not be changed. The two-year period may be extended if applied for by the subdivider and granted by the city commission in writing. Written notice of such extension shall be sent by the city commission to the other approving authorities. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Secs. 23-34-23-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 23-40. - General requirements. 
    The final plat shall comply with the provisions of the Subdivision Control Act, and shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved. The final plat may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposed to develop at the time. The final plat shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  A final plat shall be submitted no later than the two-year limit granted to a preliminary plat as stipulated in section 23-33. All approvals made on the preliminary plat shall expire as provided in section 23-33 and no final plat shall be accepted after the date of expiration of preliminary plat approval. 
(2)  All improvements set forth in this chapter shall have been completed to city standards and shall be so certified as acceptable by the city engineer prior to the approval of a final plat by the city commission. Provided, however, that a guarantee for such improvements in accordance with section 23-61, may be accepted in lieu of such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-41. - Filing. 
    Five (5) copies of the final plat shall be filed by the subdivider with the city clerk at least one (1) week prior to the regular planning and development commission meeting at which it will be considered. The plat shall meet all specifications and provide all information and certificates as provided in the Subdivision Control Act. The subdivider shall provide an abstract of title certified to date of the proprietor's certificate to establish recorded ownership interests and any other information deemed necessary for the purpose of ascertaining, whether the proper parties have signed the plat, or a policy of title insurance, currently in force, covering all the land included with the boundaries of the proposed subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-42. - Filing and review fees. 
    The following fees shall be deposited with the city clerk: 
(1)  A filing and recording fee, of twenty dollars ($20.00), such fee to be forwarded to the county plat board by the city clerk following approval of the final plat; 
(2)  A review fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), payable to the City of Sault Ste. Marie. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-43. - Review by the planning and development commission. 
    The planning and development commission shall review the final plat as to its conformance with the approved preliminary plat and shall act on the final plat: 
(1)  Should the planning and development commission find that the final plat is in agreement with the approved preliminary plat, it shall approve same and notify the city commission of this action. 
(2)  Should the planning and development commission find that the final plat does not substantially conform to the approved preliminary plat and that it is not acceptable, the commission shall recommend to the city commission that the final plat be disapproved until the objections causing disapproval have been changed to meet with the approval of the planning and development commission. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-44. - City commission action. 
    Following receipt of the planning and development commission's recommendations, the city commission shall consider the final plat at its next regular meeting. The city commission shall take action within twenty (20) days of the filing of the final plat with the city clerk, unless the subdivider agrees to an extension of time in writing. The city commission shall review all recommendations of the planning and development commission, ensure that all required improvements have been either constructed or guaranteed, and take action to approve or disapprove the final plat. The city commission may, at its discretion, approve a final plat with conditions. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-45. - Certification of plat by city clerk. 
    Following approval of a final plat by the city commission, and the satisfaction of such conditions as may have been required by the city commission, the city clerk shall certify on the plat to the governing body's approval, and shall deliver the plat, together with the filing and recording fee to the clerk of the county plat board. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-46. - Subsequent approvals by county and state agencies. 
    Subsequent approvals of the final plat shall be as specified, and shall follow the procedure, set forth (by county and state agencies) in the Subdivision Control Act. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Secs. 23-47-23-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 23-50. - General requirements. 
    The subdivision design standards set forth herein shall be considered minimum standards for the design of streets, blocks, lots and other aspects of the subdividing of land. No subdivision plat which is isolated from, or which isolates other lands from, existing public streets shall be approved. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-51. - Streets. 
    Streets shall conform to at least all minimum requirements, general specifications, typical cross sections and other conditions set forth in Article VII of this chapter in addition to the following regulations: 
(1)  Location and arrangements of streets: 
a.  The proposed subdivision shall conform to the various elements of the master plan and shall be considered in relation to existing and planned major thoroughfares and secondary thoroughfares and roads of the proposed plat which would be part of such thoroughfares, and shall be platted in the location and the width indicated on such plan. 
b.  The street layout shall provide for continuation of secondary thoroughfares in the adjoining subdivisions or of the proper projection of streets when adjoining property is not subdivided (generally not more than 1,300 feet apart); or conform to a plan for a neighborhood unit drawn up and adopted by the planning and development commission. 
c.  The street layout shall include minor streets so laid out that their use by through traffic shall be discouraged. 
d.  Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain an existing or proposed major thoroughfare, the city commission may require marginal access streets, reverse frontage, or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation and reduction of traffic hazards. 
e.  Should a proposed subdivision border on or contain an expressway, or other limited-access highway right-of-way, the city commission may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land, as for parks in residential districts or for commercial or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for approach grades to future grade separation. 
(2)  Design standards of streets: 
a.  Major thoroughfares shall have a right-of-way width of not less than one hundred twenty (120) feet, provided that a width of one hundred (100) feet may be permitted by the planning commission and the city commission in cases where a substantial portion of the length of the thoroughfare has already been platted with a width less than one hundred twenty (120) feet. 
b.  Secondary thoroughfares shall have a right-of-way width of eighty-six (86) feet. 
c.  Minor streets shall have a right-of-way width of sixty (60) feet. 
d.  Marginal-access streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than thirty-four (34) feet, unless approved by the city commission. 
e.  Cul-de-sac streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than sixty (60) feet and shall terminate in a vehicular turnaround with a minimum diameter of one hundred twenty-five (125) feet and with an approved roadway width of not less than one hundred (100) feet in diameter. Maximum length for cul-de-sac streets shall be five hundred (500) feet. 
f.  Turnaround streets shall have a right-of-way width of not less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet and shall have an improved roadway width of not less than one hundred (100) feet in diameter at its terminating loop. 
g.  Half-streets shall be prohibited, except where absolutely essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of this chapter and where the city commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is developed. Wherever there exists adjacent to the tract to be subdivided, a dedication or platted and recorded half-street, the other half shall be platted. 
h.  Alleys, where permitted, shall have a width of not less than twenty (20) feet. 
i.  Access to streets across all ditches, watercourses, streams or ravines shall be provided by the subdivider in a standard method approved by the city engineer. 
(3)  Street grades: 
a.  Minimum grades for concrete streets and gutters shall be 0.3 per cent, and for all other types of street surfacing shall be 0.5 per cent. 
b.  Maximum grades for major thoroughfares shall not exceed 3.0 per cent, and for secondary thoroughfares and minor streets shall not exceed 7.0 per cent. 
(4)  Street alignments: 
a.  Vertical curves: 
1.  Major thoroughfares shall have profile grade changes where the grade change is over a total of 1.5 per cent, connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to twenty (20) times the algebraic difference in the rate of grade, expressed in feet/100. 
2.  Secondary thoroughfares shall have profile grade changes where the grade change is over a total of 1.5 per cent, connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to fifteen (15) times the algebraic difference in the rate of grade, expressed in feet/100. 
3.  Minor streets shall have profile grade changes where the grade change is over a total of 1.5 per cent, connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to ten (10) times the algebraic difference in the rate of grade, expressed in feet/100. 
b.  Horizontal curves. The radii of center line curvature shall be: 
1.  Four hundred seventy-five (475) feet radius for major thoroughfares. 
2.  Three hundred (300) feet radius for secondary thoroughfares. 
3.  Two hundred (200) feet radius for minor streets. 
A minimum of fifty (50) feet tangent shall be introduced between reverse curves. 
c.  Visibility requirements: 
1.  Minimum vertical visibility (measured from four and one-half-foot eye-level to eighteen-inch tail light) shall be: 
i.  Five hundred (500) feet on major thoroughfares. 
ii.  Three hundred (300) feet on secondary thoroughfares. 
iii.  Two hundred (200) feet on minor streets. 
iv.  One hundred (100) feet on minor streets less than five hundred (500) feet in length. 
2.  Minimum horizontal visibility shall be: 
i.  Three hundred (300) feet on major thoroughfares, measured on center line. 
ii.  Two hundred (200) feet on major thoroughfares, measured on the center line. 
iii.  One hundred (100) feet on minor streets, measured on the center line. 
d.  Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at ninety (90) degrees. 
e.  Curved streets intersecting with major thoroughfares and secondary thoroughfares shall do so with a tangent section of center line fifty (50) feet in length measured from the right-of-way line of the major thoroughfare or secondary thoroughfare. 
f.  Streets which intersect the same street shall have a distance of no less than one hundred (100) feet between them, measured from center line to center line. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83; Ord. No. 278-87, 8-3-87) 
Sec. 23-52. - Blocks. 
    Blocks within subdivisions shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Size: 
a.  Maximum length for blocks shall not exceed one thousand three hundred (1,300) feet in length, except where in the opinion of the planning and development commission, physical conditions may justify a greater distance. 
b.  Widths of blocks shall be determined by the condition of the layout and shall be suited to the intended layout. 
c.  Block length shall not be less than six (6) times the minimum width of a residential lot, as prescribed in the city's zoning ordinance in the applicable zoning district or five hundred (500) feet, whichever is longer. 
(2)  Public walkways: 
a.  Location of public walkways or crosswalks may be required by the city commission to obtain satisfactory pedestrian circulation within the subdivision where blocks exceed nine hundred (900) feet in length. 
b.  Widths of public walkways where required, shall be at least twelve (12) feet and shall be dedicated as a public right-of-way. 
(3)  Easements: 
a.  Utility line easements shall be provided along the rear or side lot lines as necessary for utility lines. Easements shall give access to every lot, park or public grounds. Such easements shall be a total of not less than twelve (12) feet wide. Six (6) feet from each parcel. 
b.  Recommendations on the proposed layout of telephone and electric company easements shall be obtained from all of the utility companies serving the area. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-53. - Lots. 
    Lots within subdivisions shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Sizes and shapes: 
a.  Lot sizes, widths and building setback lines shall in no case be less than required by the zoning ordinance for the district in which the subdivision is proposed, provided however that in the case of lots to be served with on-site water supply, on-site sewage disposal, or both systems, minimum lot size shall be one-half acre or such larger size as may be required by the health department to ensure the proper operation of such on-site systems and the protection of the health and safety of the community. 
b.  Excessive lot depth in relation to width shall be avoided. A depth-to-width ratio of three to one (3:1) shall normally be considered a maximum. 
c.  Corner lots shall be platted a minimum of at least ten (10) feet wider than interior lots in order to permit conformance to setback lines on side lotted streets. 
d.  Lots abutting a major or secondary thoroughfare shall be no less than one hundred forty-five (145) feet in depth on a major thoroughfare and one hundred thirty-five (135) feet in depth on a secondary thoroughfare. 
e.  Lots intended for purposes other than residential use shall be specifically designed for such purposes, and shall have adequate provision for off-street parking and off-street loading in accordance with the requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Arrangement: 
a.  Every lot shall front on or have direct access to a street. 
b.  Side lot lines shall be at right angles or radial to the street lines, or as nearly possible thereto. 
c.  Residential lots abutting major thoroughfares or secondary thoroughfares, where marginal-access streets are not desirable or possible to attain, shall be platted with reverse frontage lots, or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic streets, or shall be platted with extra depth as required in subsection (1)d. of this section. 
d.  Lots shall have a front-to-front relationship across all streets. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-54. - Floodplains. 
    Any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river, stream, creek or lake, or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by storm water shall not be platted for any use which may increase danger to health, life or property. The subdivider may show, by way of accurately engineered plans, that a change to the topography in the proposed subdivision will eliminate flooding in the area in question and shall clearly demonstrate that any such planned topographical change will not aggravate the flood hazard beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision. If the city commission determines that a flood problem does exist, then it shall reject all or that part of the proposed subdivision lying within the floodplain. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-55. - Natural features. 
    The natural features and character of lands must be preserved wherever possible. Due regard must be shown for all natural features such as large trees, natural groves, watercourses and similar community assets that will add attractiveness and value to the property, if preserved. The preservation of drainage and natural stream channels must be considered by the subdivider and the dedication and provision of adequate barriers, where appropriate, may be required by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-56. - Other design requirements. 
    For industrial or commercial subdivisions, greenbelt buffers, fences, walls or other design features may be required when necessary to protect adjacent residentially zoned properties. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-57. - Easements for public utilities. 
    Easements for public utilities shall be included on the plat and shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet wide where the rear lines of lots are contiguous and at least six (6) feet wide if the lot has no adjoining subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Secs. 23-58, 23-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 23-60. - General requirements. 
    The improvements set forth under this article are deemed to be the minimum acceptable standards for subdivisions. Prior to issuing the certificate of approval on the final plat under section 23-45, all improvements required under this article must have been constructed or guaranteed as to completion as set forth in section 23-61. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-61. - Agreement or guarantee in lieu of construction. 
    In lieu of the completion of all or some of the required improvements: 
(1)  The city may require, as a condition of approval of the final plat, the subdivider to enter into an agreement to construct such improvements within a time, and under such conditions, as may be stipulated by the city commission. 
(2)  The subdivider may choose to guarantee and insure the completion of such improvements by depositing with the city clerk a cash deposit, a certified check or irrevocable bank letter of credit, or surety bond acceptable to the city to insure construction of such improvements. The amount of such cash, check, letter of credit or surety bond shall be established by the city commission based on an estimate of the cost of such improvements by the city engineer. 
a.  If the required improvements are not constructed within one (1) year of the date of the city approval of the final plat, the city commission may direct the use of such guarantee deposit to the completion of the required improvements. 
b.  As work progresses on the completion of improvements, portions of the guarantee deposit shall be rebated to the subdivider in proportion to the work completed and approved as to standards by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-62. - Streets. 
    Streets shall be constructed to proper grade with adequate provisions for drainage and surface and improved in accordance with the following specifications: 
(1)  Major thoroughfares. A right-of-way in accordance with section 23-5(2)a, unless a larger right-of-way is required by the state department of transportation or the board of county road commissioners for roads under those jurisdictions; with pavements and improvements as determined by the city commission, department of transportation or board of county road commissioners. 
(2)  Secondary thoroughfares. An eighty-six-foot right-of-way, with thirty-six-foot concrete pavement outside of curb, with curb and gutter each side of pavement, an eighteen-foot separation strip and six-foot concrete sidewalks on each side of roadway, and a one-foot space between the sidewalk and the right-of-way line on each side. 
a.  In the case of secondary thoroughfares determined to be of primarily rural or industrial use by the city commission, the sidewalk requirements shall be waived. 
b.  A surface of other than concrete pavement may be accepted if such surface is equally satisfactory to, and approved by, the city engineer. 
(3)  Minors streets. A sixty-foot right-of-way, with twenty-seven-foot concrete pavement outside of curb to outside of curb, with curb and gutter each side of pavement, a ten-and-one-half-foot separation strip and five-foot concrete sidewalk on each side of the roadway and one-foot of space between sidewalk and right-of-way line on each side. 
a.  In the case of plats with lots having a minimum area of ten thousand (10,000) square feet and lot widths of at least one hundred (100) feet, sidewalk requirements shall be waived. 
b.  A surface of other than concrete pavement may be acceptable if such surface is equally satisfactory to, and approved by, the city engineer. 
(4)  Marginal-access streets. A thirty-four-foot right-of-way with twenty-foot pavement outside of curb to outside of curb, concrete curb and gutter each side of pavement with a four-foot separation strip measured from the right-of-way line of the adjacent street to the marginal-access street and a three-foot separation strip and a five-foot sidewalk on the opposite side with a one-foot space between the sidewalk and the right-of-way line. 
a.  In the case of plats with lots having a minimum area of ten thousand (10,000) square feet and lot widths of at least one hundred (100) feet, sidewalk requirements shall be waived. 
b.  A surface of other than concrete pavement may be acceptable if such surface is equally satisfactory to, and approved by, the city engineer. 
(5)  Engineering standards. All grading and center line gradients, curbs and gutters, and roadway pavements shall be in accordance with plans, profiles, standards and specifications as determined by the city engineer and approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83; Ord. No. 279-87, 8-3-87) 
Sec. 23-63. - Storm drainage. 
    Storm drainage system and other drainage improvements shall be constructed in accordance with standards and specifications as determined by the city engineer and approved by the city commission. Where drainage systems involve the use of either county or state drainage systems, a letter or document of approval from the county or state must be submitted by the subdivider. Where the proper drainage of the subdivision requires the construction of drainage improvements outside of the subdivided property, the city commission may require the construction of such external drainage improvements as a condition of approval of final plat. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-64. - Sewage disposal. 
    The sewage disposal system for a subdivision shall be in accordance with the standards and specifications as required by the county health department. Those systems which will become part of the municipal system shall be constructed in accordance with such engineering standards and specifications as determined by the city engineer and approved by the city commission, and shall include house and building connections to beyond the curb location. Subdivisions which will dispose of sewage by means of on-site systems on an individual lot basis need not construct such systems at the time of subdividing if the proposed system is approved by the health department. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-65. - Water supply. 
    The water supply system for a subdivision shall be in accordance with the regulations of the state and county health departments. Those systems which will become part of the municipal system shall be constructed in accordance with such engineering standards and specifications as determined by the city engineer and approved by the city commission, and shall include house and building connections to beyond the curb location. Subdivisions which will provide water supply on an individual lot-by-lot basis need not construct such system at the time of subdividing if the proposed system is approved by the health department. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-66. - Street trees. 
    Existing trees near street rights-of-way shall be preserved by the subdivider. Street trees shall be provided on the basis of at least one (1) per lot in the street right-of-way between sidewalk and curbs. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-67. - Street name signs. 
    Street name signs of a type approved by the city engineer shall be placed at all street intersections and shall be of a permanent weather-resistant construction, visible from two (2) directions. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Cross reference- Signs, Ch. 20. 
Sec. 23-68. - Other improvements. 
    When required by the city commission, public walkways shall be constructed with a width of five (5) feet of concrete or asphalt in accordance with standards specified by the city engineer. Green belt buffers, fences or other improvements required by the city commission shall be constructed in accordance with standards specified by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-69. - Common areas. 
    When a subdivider proposes the development of areas to be reserved for the common use of the residents of the subdivision, the city commission will require copies of agreements, covenants or other documents which show the manner in which these common areas are to be maintained and apportioned as to property taxation. The commission may require, as a condition of final plat approval, the creation of such escrow funds or other financial mechanisms as will ensure that such common area does not become a maintenance liability to the city. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
ARTICLE VIII. - LOT SPLITS 

Sec. 23-70. - General requirements. 
    A parcel of land, whose boundaries are fixed in a recorded plat, may be subdivided into not more than four (4) lots or tracts in accordance with the provisions and procedures set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-71. - Filing. 
    An application, together with three (3) copies of a plan of the proposed lot split and the filing fee, shall be submitted to the city clerk at least two (2) weeks prior to the regular planning and development commission meeting. The following information shall be included in the application and on the plan: 
(1)  Legal description of the property; 
(2)  Name and address of the owner; 
(3)  The plan shall be drawn at a scale of one (1) inch to fifty (50) feet, shall be dated, and shall show the north point. 
(4)  Boundary lines and the areas of the lots or tract as they exist and as they are proposed to be split, fully dimensioned. 
(5)  Names, right-of-way widths and roadway widths of all existing and proposed streets which are adjacent to the parcel to be split. 
(6)  Location width and purpose of any easements. 
The city clerk shall receive the lot split application and check for completeness and if complete, cause the application to be placed on the agenda of the next planning and development commission meeting. The clerk shall transmit a copy of the lot split to the city engineer and city planner for their technical review. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-72. - Filing fee. 
    A fee payable to the city shall accompany an application for a lot split. The fee amount shall be as presently established or as changed from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83; Ord. No. 283-87, § 1, 9-14-87; Ord. No. 375-93, § 1, 6-21-93) 
Sec. 23-73. - Review by the planning and development commission. 
(a)  The planning and development commission shall review a lot split at a public meeting, notice of such meeting to be sent to the applicant and to the owners of land immediately adjoining the proposed tract as their names appear on the tax records of the city, and to all utility companies serving the city; such notice to be sent not less than seven (7) days prior to such meeting. 
(b)  The planning and development commission shall review the proposed lot split within the framework of the master plan and the zoning ordinance standards, and in view of other data as may be provided. 
(c)  The planning and development commission shall, within thirty (30) days of the date it first appears on a regular meeting agenda, act on the lot split, unless the applicant agrees to an extension of time in writing. The commission shall either approve, conditionally approve or reject the proposed lot split, with reasons for the action recorded in the minutes. Any conditions, modifications or requirements which bear on the approval or rejection of the proposed lot split shall be specified. 
(d)  The commission's recommendations shall be forwarded to the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Sec. 23-74. - City commission action. 
    On receipt of the planning and development commission's recommendation, the city commission shall consider the proposed lot split. If the city commission approves the lot split, it shall adopt a resolution implementing the lot split and shall transmit such resolution to the city clerk for recording. 
(Ord. No. 234-83, 4-18-83) 
Chapter 23.5 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 23.5-1-23.5-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[1] 

Footnotes:

Secs. 23.5-11-23.5-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 23.5-40. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are to regulate access to and ongoing use of public rights-of-way by telecommunications providers for their telecommunications facilities while protecting the public health, safety, and welfare and exercising reasonable control of the public rights-of-way in compliance with the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002) ("act") and other applicable law, and to ensure that the city qualifies for distributions under the act by modifying the fees charged to providers and complying with the act. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-41. - Conflict. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed in such a manner as to conflict with the act or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-42. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Act means the Metropolitan Extension Telecommunications Rights-of-Way Oversight Act (Act No. 48 of the Public Acts of 2002), as amended from time to time. 
    City means the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan. 
    City commission means the city commission of the City of Sault Ste. Marie Michigan or its designee. This section does not authorize delegation of any decision or function that is required by law to be made by the city commission. 
    City manager means the city manager or his or her designee. 
    Permit means a nonexclusive permit issued pursuant to the act and this article to a telecommunications provider to use the public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities. 
    All other terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as defined or as provided in the act, including without limitation the following: 
    Authority means the metropolitan extension telecommunications rights-of-way oversight authority created pursuant to section 3 of the act. 
    MPSC means the Michigan Public Service Commission in the Department of Consumer and Industry Services, and shall have the same meaning as the term "commission" in the act. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity, or any other legal entity. 
    Public right-of-way means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street, alley, easement or waterway. Public right-of-way does not include a federal, state, or private right-of-way. 
    Telecommunication facilities or facilities means the equipment or personal property, such as copper and fiber cables, lines, wires, switches, conduits, pipes, and sheaths, which are used to or can generate, receive, transmit, carry, amplify, or provide telecommunication services or signals. Telecommunication facilities or facilities do not include antennas, supporting structures for antennas, equipment shelters or houses, and any ancillary equipment and miscellaneous hardware used to provide federally licensed commercial mobile service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of title III of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, and service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. 
    Telecommunications provider, provider and telecommunications services mean those terms as defined in section 102 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2102. Telecommunication provider does not include a person or an affiliate of that person when providing a federally licensed commercial mobile radio service as defined in section 332(d) of part I of the Communications Act of 1934, chapter 652, 48 Stat. 1064, 47 U.S.C. 332 and further defined as commercial mobile radio service in 47 CFR 20.3, or service provided by any wireless, two-way communication device. For the purpose of the act and this ordinance only, a provider also includes all of the following: 
(a)  A cable television operator that provides a telecommunications service. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by the act, a person who owns telecommunication facilities located within a public right-of-way. 
(c)  A person providing broadband internet transport access service. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-43. - Permit required. 
(a)  Permit required. Except as otherwise provided in the act, a telecommunications provider using or seeking to use public rights-of-way in the city for its telecommunications facilities shall apply for and obtain a permit pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Application. Telecommunications providers shall apply for a permit on an application form approved by the MPSC in accordance with section 6(1) of the act. A telecommunications provider shall file one (1) copy of the application with the city clerk, one (1) copy with the city manager, and one (1) copy with the city engineer. Upon receipt, the city clerk shall make copies of the application and distribute a copy to the director of public works. Applications shall be complete and include all information required by the act, including without limitation a route map showing the location of the provider's existing and proposed facilities in accordance with section 6(5) of the act. 
(c)  Confidential information. If a telecommunications provider claims that any portion of the route maps submitted by it as part of its application contain trade secret, proprietary, or confidential information, which is exempt from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, pursuant to section 6(5) of the act, the telecommunications provider shall prominently so indicate on the face of each map. 
(d)  Application fee. Except as otherwise provided by the act, the application shall be accompanied by a one-time nonrefundable application fee in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(e)  Additional information. The city manager may request an applicant to submit such additional information which the city manager deems reasonably necessary or relevant. The applicant shall comply with all such requests in compliance with reasonable deadlines for such additional information established by the city manager. If the city and the applicant cannot agree on the requirement of additional information requested by the city, the city or the applicant shall notify the MPSC as provided in section 6(2) of the act. 
(f)  Previously issued permits. Pursuant to section 5(1) of the act, authorizations or permits previously issued by the city under section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251 and authorizations or permits issued by the city to telecommunications providers prior to the 1995 enactment of section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act but after 1985 shall satisfy the permit requirements of this article. 
(g)  Existing providers. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the act, within one hundred eighty (180) days from November 1, 2002, the effective date of the act, a telecommunications provider with facilities located in a public right-of-way in the city as of such date, that has not previously obtained authorization or a permit under section 251 of the Michigan Telecommunications Act, 1991 PA 179, MCL 484.2251, shall submit to the city an application for a permit in accordance with the requirements of this article. Pursuant to section 5(3) of the act, a telecommunications provider submitting an application under this subsection is not required to pay the five hundred dollars ($500.00) application fee required under subsection (d) above. A provider under this subsection shall be given up to an additional one hundred eighty (180) days to submit the permit application if allowed by the authority, as provided in section 5(4) of the act. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-44. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  Approval or denial. The authority to approve or deny an application for a permit is hereby delegated to the city manager. Pursuant to section 15(3) of the act, the city manager shall approve or deny an application for a permit within forty-five (45) days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit under section 23.5-43(b) for access to a public right-of-way within the city. Pursuant to section 6(6) of the act, the city manager shall notify the MPSC when the city manager has granted or denied a permit, including information regarding the date on which the application was filed and the date on which permit was granted or denied. The city manager shall not unreasonably deny an application for a permit. 
(b)  Form of permit. If an application for permit is approved, the city manager shall issue the permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, in accordance with sections 6(1), 6(2) and 15 of the act. 
(c)  Conditions. Pursuant to section 15(4) of the act, the city manager may impose conditions on the issuance of a permit, which conditions shall be limited to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way. 
(d)  Bond requirement. Pursuant to section 15(3) of the act, and without limitation on subsection (c) above, the city manager may require that a bond be posted by the telecommunications provider as a condition of the permit. If a bond is required, it shall not exceed the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunications provider's access and use. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-45. - Construction/engineering permit. 
    A telecommunications provider shall not commence construction upon, over, across, or under the public rights-of-way in the city without first obtaining a construction or engineering permit as required under Chapter 22 of this Code, as amended, for construction within the public rights-of-way. No fee shall be charged for such a construction or engineering permit. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-46. - Conduit or utility poles. 
    Pursuant to section 4(3) of the act, obtaining a permit or paying the fees required under the act or under this article does not give a telecommunications provider a right to use conduit or utility poles. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-47. - Route maps. 
    Pursuant to section 6(7) of the act, a telecommunications provider shall, within ninety (90) days after the substantial completion of construction of new telecommunications facilities in the city, submit route maps showing the location of the telecommunications facilities to both the MPSC and to the city. The route maps should be in paper and electronic format unless and until the MPSC determines otherwise, in accordance with section 6(8) of the act. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-48. - Repair of damage. 
    Pursuant to section 15(5) of the act, a telecommunications provider undertaking an excavation or construction or installing telecommunications facilities within a public right-of-way or temporarily obstructing a public right-of-way in the city, as authorized by a permit, shall promptly repair all damage done to the street surface and all installations under, over, below, or within the public right-of-way and shall promptly restore the public right-of-way to its preexisting condition. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-49. - Establishment and payment of maintenance fee. 
    In addition to the nonrefundable application fee paid to the city set forth in section 23.5-43(d), a telecommunications provider with telecommunications facilities in the city's public rights-of-way shall pay an annual maintenance fee to the authority pursuant to section 8 of the act. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-50. - Modification of existing fees. 
    In compliance with the requirements of section 13(1) of the act, the city hereby modifies, to the extent necessary, any fees charged to telecommunications providers after November 1, 2002, the effective date of the act, relating to access and usage of the public rights-of-way, to an amount not exceeding the amounts of fees and charges required under the act, which shall be paid to the authority. In compliance with the requirements of section 13(4) of the act, the city also hereby approves modification of the fees of providers with telecommunication facilities in public rights-of-way within the city's boundaries, so that those providers pay only those fees required under section 8 of the act. The city shall provide each telecommunications provider affected by the fee with a copy of this article, in compliance with the requirement of section 13(4) of the act. To the extent any fees are charged telecommunications providers in excess of the amounts permitted under the act, or which are otherwise inconsistent with the act, such imposition is hereby declared to be contrary to the city's policy and intent, and upon application by a provider or discovery by the city, shall be promptly refunded as having been charged in error. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-51. - Savings clause. 
    Pursuant to section 13(5) of the act, if section 8 of the act is found to be invalid or unconstitutional, the modification of fees under section 23.5-50 above shall be void from the date the modification was made. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-52. - Use of funds. 
    Pursuant to section 10(4) of the act, all amounts received by the city from the authority shall be used by the city solely for rights-of-way related purposes. In conformance with that requirement, all funds received by the city from the authority shall be deposited into the major street fund and/or the local street fund maintained by the city under Act No. 51 of the Public Acts of 1951. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-53. - Annual report. 
    Pursuant to section 10(5) of the act, the city manager shall file an annual report with the authority on the use and disposition of funds annually distributed by the authority. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-54. - Cable television operators. 
    Pursuant to section 13(6) of the act, the city shall not hold a cable television operator in default or seek any remedy for its failure to satisfy an obligation, if any, to pay after November 1, 2002, the effective date of this act, a franchise fee or similar fee on that portion of gross revenues from charges the cable operator received for cable modem services provided through broadband internet transport access services. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-55. - Existing rights. 
    Pursuant to section 4(2) of the act, except as expressly provided herein with respect to fees, this article shall not affect any existing rights that a telecommunications provider or the city may have under a permit issued by the city or under a contract between the city and a telecommunications provider related to the use of the public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-56. - Compliance. 
    The city hereby declares that its policy and intent in adopting this article is to fully comply with the requirements of the act, and the provisions hereof should be construed in such a manner as to achieve that purpose. The city shall comply in all respects with the requirements of the act, including but not limited to the following: 
(a)  Exempting certain route maps from the Freedom of Information Act, 1976 PA 442, MCL 15.231 to 15.246, as provided in section 23.5-43(c) of this article; 
(b)  Allowing certain previously issued permits to satisfy the permit requirements hereof, in accordance with section 23.5-43(f) of this article; 
(c)  Allowing existing providers additional time in which to submit an application for a permit, and excusing such providers from the five hundred dollars ($500.00) application fee, in accordance with section 23.5-43(g) of this article; 
(d)  Approving or denying an application for a permit within forty-five (45) days from the date a telecommunications provider files an application for a permit for access to and usage of a public right-of-way within the city, in accordance with section 23.5-44(a) of this article; 
(e)  Notifying the MPSC when the city has granted or denied a permit, in accordance with section 23.5-44(a) of this article; 
(f)  Not unreasonably denying an application for a permit, in accordance with section 23.5-44(a) of this article; 
(g)  Issuing a permit in the form approved by the MPSC, with or without additional or different permit terms, as provided in section 23.5-44(b) of this article; 
(h)  Limiting the conditions imposed on the issuance of a permit to the telecommunications provider's access and usage of the public right-of-way, in accordance with section 23.5-44(c) of this article; 
(i)  Not requiring a bond of a telecommunications provider which exceeds the reasonable cost to ensure that the public right-of-way is returned to its original condition during and after the telecommunication provider's access and use, in accordance with section 23.5-44(d) of this article; 
(j)  Not charging any telecommunications providers any additional fees for construction or engineering permits, in accordance with 23.5-45 of this article; 
(k)  Providing each telecommunications provider affected by the city's right-of-way fees with a copy of this article, in accordance with section 23.5-50 of this article; 
(l)  Submitting an annual report to the authority, in accordance with section 23.5-53 of this article; and 
(m)  Not holding a cable television operator in default for a failure to pay certain franchise fees, in accordance with section 23.5-54 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-57. - Reservation of police powers. 
    Pursuant to section 15(2) of the act, this article shall not limit the city's right to review and approve a telecommunication provider's access to and ongoing use of a public right-of-way or limit the city's authority to ensure and protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-58. - Severability. 
    The various parts, sentences, paragraphs, sections, and clauses of this article are hereby declared to be severable. If any part, sentence, paragraph, section, or clause of this article is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court or administrative agency of competent jurisdiction, the unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect the constitutionality or validity of any remaining provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Sec. 23.5-59. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23.5-60. - Penalty for violations. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article or the terms or conditions of a permit is guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be subject to the penalties stated in section 1-6 of the City Code. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the remedies available to the city in the event of a violation by a person of this article or a permit. 
(Ord. No. 463-02, § 1, 11-4-02) 
Secs. 23.5-61-23.5-69. - Reserved.

(1)  The city commission of the City of Sault Ste. Marie hereby authorizes the granting of a nonexclusive cable television franchise to CC VIII Operating, LLC, doing business as Charter Communications pursuant to the terms set forth in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan, Nonexclusive 2004 Cable Television Franchise with CC VIII Operating LLC d/b/a Charter Communications.

(Ord. No. 483-05, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-05) 
Secs. 23.5-71-23.5-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WIRELESS TELECOMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES 

Sec. 23.5-90. - Purpose. 
    The regulations of this article are intended to conform with federal laws and administrative rules that govern facilities needed to operate wireless communications systems and to set forth procedures and standards for review and approval for the locations of such facilities within the city. It is the city's intent to reasonably regulate the location and design of such facilities to safeguard the integrity, character, property values, and aesthetic quality of neighborhoods and the city and minimize the negative visual impact of wireless communication facilities. 
(Ord. No. 545-14, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Sec. 23.5-91. - Exemptions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  The construction or expansion of wireless telecommunications facilities falling within the parameters set forth in the Michigan Zoning Enabling Act, Section MCL 125.3514(1), as amended. 
(2)  Commercial television and radio towers and public utility microwaves, and public utility TV transmitting towers as allowed by Section 10-1.1707(2). 
(3)  To any tower or antenna owned or operated by a federally licensed amateur radio operator. 
(Ord. No. 545-14, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Sec. 23.5-92. - General standards. 
(a)  To accommodate wireless communications facilities, each petitioner for installation of a communications facility shall provide an inventory of its existing and planned wireless communications facilities located within the city and within one (1) mile of the city's boundaries, including the location, height and design of each facility. The petition shall be filed with the planning commission for site plan approval. The city may share such information with a third party, but the city does not in any way represent or warrant that such information is accurate. 
(b)  Wireless telecommunications facilities shall at all times comply with applicable federal standards for non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation, as they may from time to time be amended. Documentation shall be submitted to the building department upon request verifying compliance with the FCC standards prior to the issuance of any permit and annually if requested by the city. 
(c)  Each petitioner shall exercise due diligence to determine the availability of a location for its antenna on all existing towers, approved towers, and other suitable structures within a half-mile radius of the proposed site. Due diligence shall consist of documented evidence that owners of all existing or approved towers or other suitable structures were contacted by certified mail or overnight courier, and that these sites cannot accommodate the requested antennas for reasons other than economic reasons. Where no suitable structures exist within a half-mile radius of the proposed site, the petitioner shall provide to the city an affidavit stating the same. Petitioners shall provide detailed radio frequency (RF) coverage and capacity maps for all proposed wireless service providers for the proposed site, showing coverage and capacity of the carriers' surrounding network with both existing and planned sites. The planning commission may deny a proposed wireless communication facility if it determines that another existing or approved site can reasonably accommodate the proposed facility and provide generally equivalent service. 
(d)  Certification from the city official with assigned responsibility for management of the city airport that the height of a proposed tower will not be such that it would interfere with airport operations is required from petitioner at the time of site plan submission. 
(e)  Unless otherwise specifically approved by the planning commission, all wireless communications towers shall be monopoles, designed for co-location, which is the provision of more than one (1) antenna array, usually belonging to more than one (1) licensed carrier, on a single monopole. 
(1)  Towers one hundred twenty-five (125) feet in height or less shall be designed for co-location of at least two (2) antenna arrays or carriers. 
(2)  Towers greater than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet or less than or equal to one hundred fifty-five (155) feet in height shall be designed for co-location of at least three (3) antenna arrays or carriers. 
(3)  Towers greater than one hundred fifty-five (155) feet in height shall require a height modification to be approved by the city commission as specified elsewhere in this chapter and shall be designed for co-location of at least four (4) antenna arrays or carriers. 
(f)  Sites proposed for towers shall not have a separate access curb cut proposed for the towers unless no reasonable alternative exists. Such on-site driveways need not be paved, but must have a stable, improved surface adequate to support occasional maintenance vehicles. 
(g)  Vinyl-coated security fencing at a height of six (6) feet, and landscaping around all sides of the compound containing the tower and all associated building and equipment cabinets is required. A petitioner may alternately provide an opaque decorative security wall with a height of six (6) feet. Chain-link fences with slats shall not be considered to fulfill the requirements of this paragraph. Barbed wire or razor wire is not permitted. Landscaping shall consist of materials that meet the screening materials standards in [Section] 10-1.1709, however, where deemed necessary to minimize visual impact of the compound from adjacent properties or right-of-ways, the planning commission shall have the authority to require the use of specific plant species, plant spacing, and/or plant heights. 
(h)  Signs, except for information needed for emergency notification of: the owner of the land; owner and operator of the tower; are not permitted on wireless communications facilities. 
(i)  Artificial illumination of towers is not permitted unless required by federal or state regulations or to protect public safety, as determined by the planning commission. If lighting is required, the lighting alternatives and design chosen must cause the least disturbance to surrounding properties. 
(j)  Towers shall be a low or no maintenance non-contrasting blue or gray in order to be as unobtrusive as possible, unless another color or design is deemed by the planning commission to be less obtrusive. 
(k)  All utility lines serving a wireless communications facility shall be placed underground. Transmission lines installed between ground-based equipment and antennas shall be routed through the interior portion of the monopole tower and may not be attached to its exterior. 
(l)  Wireless communications facilities may be placed in any zone or on sites with legally nonconforming structures or uses without being considered to be expansions of such non-conformities. 
(m)  Where a wireless communication facility is proposed on the roof of a building, the installation of all equipment, enclosures, and antennas, shall be designed, constructed, and maintained to be architecturally compatible by being made to appear an integral part of the building upon which it is to be installed. 
(Ord. No. 545-14, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Sec. 23.5-93. - Placement standards. 
(a)  Towers shall not be located in any required front, side, or rear setback or a required front open space. 
(b)  Setbacks shall be measured from property lines to the base of the tower. Tower height includes the antenna. 
(c)  The minimum required front setback shall be that front setback specified for that zoning district plus one (1) foot for each three (3) feet, or fraction thereof, of tower height. 
(d)  The minimum required side setback shall be that side setback specified for that zoning district plus one (1) foot for each five (5) feet, or fraction thereof, of tower height. 
(e)  The minimum required rear setback shall be that rear setback specified of that zoning district plus one (1) foot for each ten (10) feet, or fraction thereof, of tower height. 
(f)  On any site where side or rear property lines border residentially zoned property, the side or rear setback shall be equal to the tower height and a landscape buffer consisting of materials that meet the screening materials standards in [Section] 10-1.1709, shall be required adjacent to the residential property line along its full adjacent length. 
(g)  Accessory structure and equipment, if any, shall meet setbacks for accessory structure in the district or ten (10) feet, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 545-14, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Sec. 23.5-94 - Compliance standards. 
(a)  Towers shall meet the city building code and other applicable structural standards. Prior to construction, a licensed professional structural engineer's certificate certifying that the tower meets all applicable building code and other structural standards shall be provided to the building official. 
(b)  A cash bond or certified check in an amount established by resolution of city commission upon recommendation of the city manager shall be posted at the time of building permit application to cover the cost of removal and shall be maintained for the life of the tower. 
(c)  Abandoned wireless communications towers must be removed by the owner of the land, the owner of the tower and the operator of the tower. Any wireless communications tower that does not have at least one (1) antenna operating for a continuous period of one hundred eighty (180) days shall be deemed abandoned. Determination of the date of abandonment shall be made by the city manager or designee, who shall have the right to request documentation or affidavits from the owner of the land, tower owner, or operator of the tower regarding tower usage and other pertinent information. Failure or refusal for any reason by the owner of the land, tower owner, or operator of the tower to respond within thirty (30) days to such a request shall constitute prima facie evidence that the tower has been abandoned. Upon determination of abandonment and the appropriate notice thereof to the owner of the land, tower owner and/or operator of the tower, the owner of the land, tower owner and/or operator of the tower shall have one hundred twenty (120) days within which to either reactivate the use of the tower, or dismantle and remove the tower and footings to five (5) feet below grade. The owner of the land, tower owner and/or operator of the tower shall restore the property to the condition which existed prior to the construction of the tower. 
    If the owner of the land, tower owner and/or operator of the tower fails to remove the tower within the appropriate time period, the city shall have the right to remove the tower and collect on the cash bond or certified check on file with the city. The city shall bill the owner of the land, tower owner and/or operator of the tower all the costs and/or expenses associated with the removal of the tower in excess of the cash bond and/or certified check. If the owner of the land, tower owner and/or operator fails to pay the costs and/or expenses associated with the tower removal which are in excess of the cash bond and/or certified check within thirty (30) days from the date of the bill, then, in addition to any other remedy in law or in equity, the city shall have the right to place a lien on the property for all costs and expenses associated with the removal of the tower, less the amount of the cash bond or certified check which is on file with the city. 
(Ord. No. 545-14, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Sec. 23.5-95 - Violations as misdemeanor. 
    Any person who violates any section of this article or the terms or conditions of any permit issued under this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to the penalties stated in Section 1-6. 
(Ord. No. 545-14, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Chapter 24 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Vehicles hauling garbage and rubbish, § 13-24; throwing litter from vehicles prohibited, § 13-43; spilling of litter from vehicle loads, § 13-44; miscellaneous offenses and provisions, Ch. 16; noise of horn or signal devices constituting a nuisance, § 18-7(a)(1); noise of engine exhaust constituting a nuisance, § 18-7(a)(7); streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; obstructions and encroachments on streets and sidewalks, § 22-34 et seq.; vehicles for hire, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Michigan Vehicle Code, MCL § 257.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Uniform interpretation with state law. 
    It is the dominating purpose of this chapter that its provisions shall make applicable to this city the presently existing laws of the state relating to the subjects for which provision is made herein, in order that uniformity of application and interpretation may be attained. No application or interpretation of this chapter, regardless of the wording of any section of this chapter, shall deviate from uniformity of application and interpretation with comparable provisions of the laws of the state except where such deviation is required by differing jurisdictional or administrative requirements. 
(Code 1957, § 5-1.102) 
Sec. 24-2. - Penalty for conviction of violations. 
    Every person convicted of a violation or any provision of this chapter, including the "Uniform Traffic Code" and "Motor Vehicle Code," shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6 of the City Code. The penalties provided by the Michigan Vehicle Code are not adopted by reference, and the City may not enforce any provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code for which the maximum period of imprisonment is greater than ninety (90) days. 
(Code 1957, § 5-1.101; Ord. No. 468-03, § 2, 5-19-03) 
Secs. 24-3-24-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNIFORM TRAFFIC CODE AND MOTOR VEHICLE CODE[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 24-16. - Adopted. 
(a)  The Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships and Villages as promulgated by the director of the Michigan Department of State Police pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act of 1969, P.A. 306, MCL 24.201 to 24.328 and made effective October 30, 2002, and all future amendments and revisions to the Uniform Traffic Code when they are promulgated and effective in this state are incorporated and adopted by reference. 
(b)  The sections of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 P.A. 300, MCL 257.1 to 257.82, MCL 257.601 to 257.616, MCL 257.627 to 257.750, MCL 257.941 to 257.961 and all future amendments and revisions to these sections of the Michigan Vehicle Code when they are effective in this state are incorporated and adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 197, 8-6-79; Ord. No. 236-83, 5-2-83; Ord. No. 468-03, § 2, 5-19-03)

(Ord. No. 468-03, § 2, 5-19-03) 
Sec. 24-18. - Traffic-control orders. 
    All traffic-control orders, devices and signs, including parking signs, speed-limit signs, one-way signs, other directional signs, and all other traffic-control devices in existence or posted within the city prior to the effective date of this Code of Ordinances, shall and do hereby constitute the original traffic-control orders in conformance with the Uniform Traffic Code or Motor Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. 468-03, § 2, 5-19-03)
