ARTICLE III. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- P-1 vehicular parking districts, App. A, § 10-1.15. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate standing or parking of vehicles, MCL § 257.606(a)1., MCA § 9.2306(a)1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-31. - Unlawful use of parking meter; reward for information leading to conviction. 
(a)  No person shall: 
(1)  Deposit or cause to be deposited in a parking meter a coin for the purpose of increasing or extending the parking time of any vehicle beyond the legal parking time which has been established. 
(2)  Deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or metallic substitute for a United States coin. 
(3)  Remove, deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter. 
(b)  For information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person violating provision (3) of subsection (a), a reward of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be paid by the city treasurer, upon the order of the traffic engineer. 
(Code 1957, § 5-1.60) 
Sec. 24-32. - Annual meter parking permits. 
    Annual meter parking permits may be issued in the following manner: 
    Any person may pay to the city treasurer an annual fee to be determined by the city commission for the privilege of parking one (1) motor vehicle at any metered parking space in which parking permits are honored. The city manager shall designate which parking areas will not accept parking permits, and shall prominently sign said areas indicating the prohibition of parking permits. The permit shall be valid for one (1) year from the first day of July in any year, which payment shall be in lieu of the meter deposits otherwise required by the city; provided, that such person displays in the front window of such person's motor vehicle the hanger/sticker furnished by the city treasurer upon payment of such fee. The city manager shall adopt a form of hanger/sticker suitable for such purpose and a record shall be kept of the issuance thereof. Duplicate hangers/stickers to replace the original sticker will be issued at the fee presently established by or as changed from time to time by the city commission when sufficient evidence has been presented that the original sticker has been misplaced or mutilated. Stickers for city-wide parking issued pursuant to this section shall not be transferable. Hangers for restricted parking areas issued pursuant to this section shall be transferable. Permits may be issued for the unexpired portion of any year on a prorated basis, but all permits shall expire on June 30th of each year. Any person may purchase as many annual permits as desired, upon payment of the annual fee for each annual permit. 
(Ord. No. 90, § 1 (5-1.60), 6-7-71; Res. of 12-19-77; Ord. No. 204, 5-21-80; Ord. No. 427-98, § 1, 1-5-98) 
Sec. 24-33. - Exiting from parked vehicles. 
    When a vehicle is parked or stopped parallel with the curb, so far as practicable, the driver or any other occupant of the vehicle shall exit by the door or doors on the right-hand or curb side of the vehicle. 
(Code 1957, § 5-1.48) 
Sec. 24-34. - Designation of a residential parking permit area. 
(a)  Requirements and procedures for establishing. 
(1)  A citizen or citizen group in a residential district may petition the city for relief from traffic and parking problems by requesting that a specific area be designated as a residential parking permit (RPP) area. The petition shall be circulated by a citizen or citizen group to ascertain the degree of area sentiment in favor of such a parking permit designation. The petition shall be accompanied by the rules governing designation as an RPP area. 
(2)  Within thirty (30) days after receipt by the city of petitions signed by residents representing sixty (60) percent of dwelling units in the area and on each block face who favor designation, the city clerk shall verify the authenticity of petition signatures received and the city engineer and city police chief shall analyze the traffic and parking conditions in the petitioning area. No residential district or part thereof shall be recommended for designation as an RPP area unless the parking analysis reveals that the area is unreasonably impacted by vehicles of nonresidents. 
(3)  If the results of the parking analysis do not substantiate the need for an RPP area, the city shall notify the citizen or citizen's group in writing of the results of the parking analysis and the denial of the request for an RPP area. Should the citizen or citizen's group desire to appeal the decision to deny the request for an RPP area, a letter of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk. The citizen or representatives of the citizen's group will be notified of a meeting date to hear the appeal. The appeal sequence will be as follows: 
a.  The city manager; 
b.  The city commission. 
(4)  If the result of the parking analysis substantiates the need for an RPP area, the city engineer shall transmit the findings to the city manager for review. If approved by the city manager, the city clerk shall, within thirty (30) days, notify the residents of the area, by mail to each address, of the following information: The results of the parking analysis; the boundaries of the proposed RPP area under consideration; application procedures and fees to be charged; and the parking regulations recommended to be posted. The residents so notified shall have a fifteen-day period during which time comments may be filed with the city clerk's office. Not later than fifteen (15) days after passage of the comment period, the city manager shall make his recommendation to the city commission based on the findings of the parking analysis and consideration of the comments received from the residents of the affected area. 
(b)  Implementation. 
(1)  Upon city commission approval by resolution of a residential parking permit (RPP) area designation, residents of the area shall be notified by the city clerk, by mail to each address, of the city commission action and be informed of procedures for implementation of the approved RPP area. 
(2)  Signage of the designated RPP area will be installed by the city street department within thirty (30) days from the time residents representing sixty (60) percent of the dwelling units in the designated area complete an application as required by city procedures, and obtain/purchase a residential parking permit. 
(3)  Residential parking permits shall be issued for a twelve-month period, said permits to expire on May 31 of each year. The annual fee, if any, for an RPP shall be determined by the city commission. 
(4)  Not more than two (2) residential parking permits will be issued to each residence located within the designated RPP area. Should special circumstances be present, this number may be exceeded only with the approval of the city traffic engineer. 
(c)  Administration of the program. The city manager shall administer the residential parking permit (RPP) program and establish procedures for the implementation of the RPP program. 
(d)  Required levels of resident participation. The participation of residents representing sixty (60) percent of dwelling units in the designated area shall be required to achieve a posted residential parking permit area. In the event the number of residences participating in the residential parking permit program within a designated RPP area does not achieve the required sixty (60) percent level or falls below a level of sixty (60) percent of the occupied dwelling units, the designation may be revoked by the city manager. Notices of such minimal level of participation shall be mailed to each address in the RPP area. Residents will then have thirty (30) days to bring the area into compliance with the sixty-percent participation requirement. 
(e)  Improper parking within a designated area. 
(1)  No person shall: 
a.  Park or allow their vehicle to be parked in a residential parking permit area without a validly issued and unexpired residential parking permit properly displayed upon such vehicle; 
b.  Fail to surrender such permit to the city manager on its demand if such permits are used in violation of this section; 
c.  Make a false statement to obtain such permit. 
(2)  A person who violates this section shall: 
a.  Be subject to penalty under section 24-2 and section 24-56; and 
b.  Be liable for the penalty above plus towing charges incurred by the city in removing such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 297-88, § 1, 11-21-88) 
Sec. 24-35. - Winter parking from December 1 to April 1 each year. 
(a)  No person except physicians, ambulance drivers, or undertakers on emergency calls shall park a motor vehicle on any street or alley between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. from December 1 to April 1 each winter. 
(b)  No person shall park at any time on the odd-numbered-address side of any street or alley from December 1 to April 1 each winter unless the prohibited side is designated for metered parking spaces, designated for permit parking, or where one side of the street is already designated as no parking. This subsection shall not apply to Ashmun Street between Easterday Avenue and Portage Avenue nor to Portage Avenue between Gov. Osborn Boulevard and Ashmun Street nor to Bingham Avenue between E. 6th Avenue and E. Easterday Avenue nor to Peck Street between Meridian Street and Fort Street nor to Ridge Street between Magazine Street and Gov. Osborn Boulevard nor to E. Portage Avenue between Bingham Avenue and Mission Street. This subsection shall not be in effect between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. on Sundays where parking is otherwise allowed. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine as established annually by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 481-04, § 2, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 24-36. - Parking of recreational vehicle, commercial vehicle/trailer, personal trailer, and semi-truck restrictions. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Recreational vehicle means any of the following: 
Camping trailer (pop-up camper) means a folding structure mounted on wheels and designed for recreation, camping, travel, and vacation use and does not require a special highway movement permit to be towed on a street or highway. 
Motor home means a vehicle that has its own motive power that is used to provide temporary living quarters for recreation, camping, travel, vacation, or seasonal use and does not require a special highway movement permit to be driven on a street or highway. 
Sport trailer means a vehicle drawn by another motor vehicle for the purpose of transporting a watercraft, snowmobile, all-terrain vehicle, or other sport vehicle over a street or highway and does not require a special highway movement permit to be towed on a street or highway. 
Travel trailer means a vehicle used as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, or travel purposes; drawn by another motor vehicle; and does not require a special highway movement permit to be towed on a street or highway. The term includes, but is not limited to, trailer coaches and fifth wheels. 
    Commercial equipment means any machinery, parts, accessories, construction equipment or other equipment used primarily in the course of conducting a trade or business. 
    Commercial vehicle/trailer means any self-propelled vehicle or towed trailer used for the purpose of delivering goods or services, wares or merchandise, or carrying commercial equipment. 
    Personal trailer means any trailer, other than a commercial vehicle/trailer, used for the purpose of carrying personal items or possessions. 
    Semi-trailer means a freight trailer that, when attached, is supported at its forward end by the fifth-wheel device of the semi-truck. 
    Semi-truck (semi) means the motorized truck that tows a semi-trailer. 
(b)  Parking of recreational vehicles and personal trailers restricted. Recreational vehicles and personal trailers shall not be parked on a public alley or parking lot. Recreational vehicles and personal trailers may be parked on a street or highway within the city when all the following requirements are satisfied: 
(1)  A recreational vehicle or personal trailer must be parked on the street or highway in an area legal for parking of vehicles. 
(2)  A recreational vehicle or personal trailer may not be parked on a street or highway longer than forty-eight (48) hours in total per calendar year without a permit. 
Parking permits may be applied for at the city clerk's office. The application shall include such information as is requested by the city clerk. Permit fees shall be set by resolution of the city commission. No permit will be authorized for parking within an alley. 
Permits shall not be issued consecutively. A minimum of three (3) full days must fall between authorized permits. No issued permit may allow a vehicle to be parked in violation of parking restrictions in state laws, city ordinances or the rules set forth in this section. 
If approved, the permit shall allow a recreational vehicle or personal trailer to be parked on a street or highway in the city for a maximum of seventy-two (72) continuous hours. A total of four (4) 72-hour permits may be issued per recreational vehicle or personal trailer per calendar year. 
The permit shall include the date and time it was authorized by the city clerk's office. The permit shall expire seventy-two (72) hours after it has been issued. A copy of the permit shall be filed by the clerk with the police department. 
The permit shall be displayed so that it is visible from outside the vehicle on the street side. 
(3)  At no time shall any "slide-out" component of a recreational vehicle or personal trailer be extended while parked. 
(4)  At no time shall any generator, compressor, or other motors be operating while the recreational vehicle or personal trailer is parked. 
(5)  At no time shall a recreational vehicle or personal trailer be parked in a manner that would encroach upon a sidewalk or crosswalk. 
(6)  At no time shall a recreational vehicle or personal trailer be parked within ten (10) feet of the entrance of any driveway not belonging to the registered owner of the recreational vehicle or personal trailer. 
(7)  At no time shall any hose, cable or other attachment be extended to or from a recreational vehicle over or upon any public sidewalk. 
(c)  Parking of commercial equipment, commercial vehicle/trailer, semi-trailer, or semi-truck restricted: 
No person shall park any Commercial equipment, commercial vehicle/trailer, semi-trailer, or semi-truck on any public alley, parking lot, street, or highway, within the city, except that the parking of a commercial vehicle, trailer, or equipment shall be allowed during the performance of a service on the adjacent or underlying property. The exception is permitted only during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. during the time when the actual service is being performed, or if the vehicle, trailer or equipment is necessary during other hours for warning of conditions for motor vehicle safety. 
(d)  This section does not apply to parking authorized by special order of the city. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, the registered owner of a recreational vehicle, commercial vehicle or trailer, personal trailer, or a semi-truck or trailer parked in violation of this section is presumed to be the responsible party for any violation. All offenses and fines for parking shall be as presently established or as changed from time to time by resolution of the city commission as set forth in section 24-56. Each day that the violation occurs shall be considered a separate incident. The vehicle will be subject to impoundment at the owner's expense. 
(f)  This section does not replace or modify winter parking restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 569-17, § 1, 1-16-17) 
Secs. 24-37-4-39. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 24-51. - Created; supervised by city manager. 
    Pursuant to section 8395 [MCL § 600.8395] of the Revised Judicature Act, State of Michigan, as added by Public Act 154 of 1968, a parking violations bureau, for the purpose of handling alleged parking violations within the city, is hereby established. The parking violations bureau shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2-6.01, 12-3-68) 
Sec. 24-52. - Duties of city manager. 
    The city manager shall, subject to the approval of the city commission, establish a convenient location for the parking violations bureau, appoint qualified city employees to administer the bureau and adopt rules and regulations for the operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2-6.02, 12-3-68) 
Sec. 24-53. - Disposition of scheduled offenses only; rights of violator. 
    No violation not scheduled in section 24-56 shall be disposed of by the parking violations bureau. The fact that a particular violation is scheduled shall not entitle the alleged violator to disposition of the violation at the bureau and in any case the person in charge of such bureau may refuse to dispose of such violation in which case any person having knowledge of the facts may make a sworn complaint before any court having jurisdiction of the offense as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2-6.03, 12-3-68) 
Sec. 24-54. - Disposition of offense at request of violator only. 
    No violation may be settled at the parking violations bureau except at the specific request of the alleged violator. No penalty for any violation shall be accepted from any person who denies having committed the offense and in no case shall the person who is in charge of the bureau determine, or attempt to determine, the truth or falsity of any fact or matter relating to such an alleged violation. No person shall be required to dispose of a parking violation at the parking violations bureau and all persons shall be entitled to have any such violation processed before a court having jurisdiction thereof if they so desire. The unwillingness of any person to dispose of any violation at the parking violations bureau shall not prejudice such person or in any way diminish the rights, privileges and protection accorded to such person by law. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2-6.04, 12-3-68) 
Sec. 24-55. - Issuance of parking violations. 
    The issuance of a traffic ticket or notice of violation by either a: (i) police officer, (ii) any person appointed by the city manager to the parking violations bureau, (iii) city director of public works, or (iv) city street superintendent shall be deemed an allegation of a parking violation. Such traffic ticket or notice of violation shall indicate the length of time in which the person to whom the same was issued must respond before the parking violations bureau. It shall also indicate the amount of the penalty scheduled for the offense for which the ticket was issued and advise that a warrant for the arrest of the person to whom the ticket was issued will be sought if such a person fails to respond within the time limited. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2-6.05, 12-3-68; Ord. No. 477-04, § 1, 6-21-04) 
Sec. 24-56. - Schedule of offenses and fines. 
    All offenses and fines for parking shall be as presently established or as changed from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 64, § 2-6.06, 12-3-68; Ord. No. 114, 1-8-73; Ord. No. 209, § 1, 10-20-80; Ord. No. 251-85, § 1, 12-16-85; Ord. No. 299-88, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 386-94, § 1, 12-5-94; Ord. No. 422-97, §§ 1, 2, 2-17-97) 
Sec. 24-57. - Prohibition of illegal parking on private property. 
(a)  No person shall leave or park any motor vehicle on any public or private property not his own without the permission of the owner of any public or private property if there is in plain view on such property a "no parking" sign, or a sign indicating limited or restricted parking. 
(b)  Owners of private or public property or their designated agents, may prohibit parking, may restrict or limit parking, and may permit parking by certain persons and prohibit it or limit it as to other persons. 
(Ord. No. 202, 4-7-80; Ord. No. 433-98, § 1, 5-18-98) 
Secs. 24-58-24-62. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING LOTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Operation of off-road vehicles in city parking lots prohibited, § 24-159. 

Sec. 24-63. - Laying out parking spaces; correct parking. 
    The traffic engineer, subject to the approval of the city commission, shall have authority to lay out and designate the use of parking spaces on publicly owned or operated parking lots. Every person parking any vehicle therein shall park the same within designated limit lines and spaces. No person shall park any vehicle in any driveway or other portion of such lot where parking is forbidden by signs duly posted. 
(Code 1957, § 7-5.01) 
Sec. 24-64. - Duration of parking. 
    The traffic engineer, subject to the approval of the city commission, shall have authority to limit the period during which vehicles may be parked in any publicly owned or operated parking lot. No person shall park or leave any vehicle therein for a period longer than that established by the traffic engineer and posted in such parking lot by signs giving notice of such limited parking regulations. 
(Code 1957, § 7-5.02) 
Sec. 24-65. - Installation of parking meters. 
    The traffic engineer, subject to the approval of the city commission, shall have authority to install or use parking meters in any publicly owned or operated parking lot. The use of such parking meters shall be governed by the provisions of this Code relevant to parking meters. 
(Code 1957, § 7-5.03) 
Sec. 24-66. - Rules governing use. 
(a)  All parking shall be at the owner's risk. The city shall not be responsible for theft or damage to any vehicle or the loss of any articles left in any vehicle while parked in any publicly owned or operated parking lot. 
(b)  No vehicle exceeding twenty-two (22) feet in length shall be parked in any public parking lot. 
(c)  Public parking lots are hereby declared to be for the accommodation of the general public and not for the purpose of furnishing private garage space. No person shall use any parking lot for the purpose of selling or repairing vehicles, or carrying on any trade or business therein. 
(d)  Whenever a vehicle enters or leaves a public parking lot equipped with a coin-or token-operated gate or barrier, the operator of the vehicle shall, if such gate or barrier be at the entrance thereto, upon entering such lot immediately deposit or cause to be deposited a coin or coins of the United States of a denomination mentioned on the gate or barrier or an official token issued by the city for that purpose. If such gate or barrier shall be at the exit of such lot, the operator of the vehicle shall, before leaving such lot, immediately deposit or cause to be deposited a coin or coins of the United States of a denomination mentioned on the gate or barrier or an official token issued by the city for that purpose. It shall be unlawful to use such parking lot without depositing such coin or coins, or official tokens, upon entering or leaving, as the case may require, and it shall be unlawful to continuously park on such lot for a period of time longer than the time as shown by a sign or signs posted on such lot. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a motor vehicle using such lot to violate any of the conditions or regulations as posted and shown by signs on such lot regulating the use thereof, and it shall be unlawful for any operator of a motor vehicle to drive such vehicle into the exit gate of such lot or to drive said motor vehicle out of the entrance gate of such lot. 
(Code 1957, § 7-5.04; Ord. No. 18, § 7-5.05, 10-15-62) 
Secs. 24-67-24-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLER SKATES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 459, § 1, adopted Sept. 16, 2002, repealed §§ 24-84-24-90, which pertained to bicycle licenses, derived from the 1957 Code, §§ 5-1.77-5-1.82, and 5-1.84. Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 459 enacted new provisions which pertained to operation of skateboards and rollerskates designated as Art. IV, §§ 24-91, 24-93, 24-95, and 24-97 herein set out. 

Sec. 24-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words [and terms] when used in this article shall mean: 
    Operate means the use, putting into action or causing to function of a skateboard or roller skates by a person mounted thereon. 
    Parking area means and public or private parking space, lot, or parking structure for parking automobiles. 
    Pedestrian means a person on foot. 
    Plaza means that open space area between the main entrance to a building and the street. 
    Roller skates shall include and shoe-like device with wheels attached including, but not limited to, roller skates, in-line roller skates and roller blades. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street, road, or highway designed or ordinarily used for pedestrian travel. 
    Skateboard means a single platform mounted on wheels which is propelled by human power, motor or wind and which has no mechanism or other device with which to steer or control the movement or direction of the platform. 
(Ord. No. 459-02, § 2, 9-16-02) 
Sec. 24-92. - Reserved. 
Sec. 24-93. - Operation upon certain public places and restricted areas. 
(a)  No person shall operate or in any manner use a skateboard, or roller skates upon any area where such activity is prohibited by resolution adopted from time to time by the city commission. 
(b)  Skateboards and roller skates shall be prohibited on ramps, steps, retention walls, handrails, planters, curb or gutter edges, barriers and barricades, benches and picnic tables, monument or sculpture surfaces located on all public property any where in the city. 
(c)  Yield of right-of-way and careless operation. 
(1)  Notwithstanding their own status as pedestrians, roller skaters and skate boarders operating on permissible sidewalk areas shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicular traffic (including bicycles) and to all other pedestrian traffic upon the sidewalk. 
(2)  Any person roller skating or skateboarding on any sidewalk, street, or other place not prohibited by this article and which is open to the general public (including any area designated for the parking of vehicles), in a careless or negligent manner likely to endanger any person or property shall be in violation of this article. 
(d)  No person shall ride on or in any manner use a skateboard or roller skates with a wind powered sail. 
(e)  No person shall ride on or in any manner use a skateboard or roller skates which is being towed by any person, device, vehicle, or animal. 
(f)  Skateboarding and roller skating is prohibited in a parking structure. 
(g)  Operation prohibited at certain times. 
(1)  No skateboarding is permitted on any sidewalk or other public property within the city between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. The city may post a later time in certain areas it considers appropriate. 
(2)  No skateboarding or roller skating is permitted on private property if clearly posted: "NO SKATEBOARDS OR ROLLER SKATING". 
(Ord. No. 459-02, § 2, 9-16-02) 
Sec. 24-94. - Reserved. 
Sec. 24-95. - Seizure of property. 
    Any police officer upon probable cause to believe that a violation of this article has been committed may confiscate the skateboard or roller skates used in the commission of such violation and obtain the alleged violators name, address, telephone number and age. The confiscated property will be held at the police department for at least ninety-six (96) hours and in the case of a minor will be released only to a responsible parent or legal guardian. The skateboard may be held until any adjudication of penalty is completed and any penalty imposed satisfied. 
(Ord. No. 459-02, § 2, 9-16-02) 
Sec. 24-96. - Reserved. 
Sec. 24-97. - Penalties for violations. 
    A violation of this article IV shall be considered a civil infraction which is punishable by fine in an amount established by resolution of the city commission from time to time upon recommendation of the city manager together with costs and fines assessed by the court of jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 459-02, § 2, 9-16-02) 
Secs. 24-98-24-101. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - SNOWMOBILES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Snowmobiles, MCL § 257.1501 et seq., MSA § 9.3200(1) et seq.; authority to regulate snowmobiles, MCL § 257.1514, MSA § 9.3200(14). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-117. - Definitions. 
    The definitions used herein shall be the same as those defined in Section 1 of Act 74 of the Public Acts of Michigan for 1968 [MCL § 257.1501, MSA § 9.3200(1)]. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.20, 11-16-70) 
Sec. 24-118. - State registration required. 
    Snowmobiles must be properly registered with the state as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.21, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Registration of snowmobiles, MCL § 257.1503 et seq., MSA § 9.3200(3) et seq. 
Sec. 24-119. - Report of accidents. 
    The operator of a snowmobile involved in an accident resulting in injuries to or death of any person, or property damage in an estimated amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more, shall immediately, by the quickest means of communication, notify the police department. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.24, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1516, MSA § 9.3200(16). 
Sec. 24-120. - Leaving unattended. 
    A snowmobile shall not be left unattended with the engine running or the key in the ignition. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.27, 11-16-70) 
Sec. 24-121. - Responsibility of owner for operation in violation of article. 
    No person shall knowingly authorize or permit a snowmobile owned by such person or under such person's control to be driven by any person in violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.31, 11-16-70) 
Secs. 24-122-24-127. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION 

Sec. 24-128. - Lights and brakes. 
    No snowmobile shall be operated within the city limits unless it has at least one headlight, taillight and adequate brakes capable of one of the following while the snowmobile travels on packed snow and carries an operator who weighs one hundred seventy-five (175) pounds or more: 
(1)  Stopping the snowmobile in not more than forty (40) feet from an initial steady speed of twenty (20) miles per hour; or 
(2)  Locking the snowmobile's traction belt or belts. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.22, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1513, MSA § 9.3200(13). 
Sec. 24-129. - Muffler required. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile unless it is equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation from which noise emission at fifty (50) feet at right angles from vehicle path under full throttle does not exceed eighty-six (86) DBA (decibels on the "a" scale) on a sound meter having characteristics defined by American Standards Association 51, 4-1966 "general purpose sound meter." All snowmobiles manufactured after February 1, 1972, and sold or offered for sale in this city shall not exceed eighty-two (82) DBA of the 1970 Society of Automotive Engineers Code J-192. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.23, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1515(f), MSA § 9.3200(15)(f). 
Sec. 24-130. - Speed. 
(a)  No person shall operate a snowmobile at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper, having due regard to persons and property and conditions then existing. 
(b)  No person shall operate a snowmobile at a rate of speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour nor in excess of any lower posted speed that is posted as allowed upon any city streets, alleys, or rights-of-way that have been designated by resolution of the city commission as being opened for such use. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.23, 11-16-70; Ord. No. 387-94, § 1, 12-5-94; Ord. No. 504-08, § 1, 9-2-08) 
Sec. 24-131. - Operation while under influence of intoxicating drugs prohibited. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile while under the influence of intoxicants, liquor or narcotic drugs, barbital, or any derivative of barbital. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.23, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1515(b), MSA § 9.3200(15)(b). 
Sec. 24-132. - Display of lights during nighttime operation required. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile during the hours from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise without displaying a lighted headlight and lighted taillight. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.23, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1515(c), MSA § 9.3200(15)(c). 
Sec. 24-133. - Operation on frozen public waters. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile on the frozen surface of public waters within one hundred (100) feet of a person, or within one hundred (100) feet of a fishing shanty or shelter except at the minimum speed required to maintain forward movement of the snowmobile. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile on an area which has been cleared of snow for skating purposes. 
(Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, 10-16-95) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1515(e), MSA § 9.3200(15)(e). 
Sec. 24-134. - Operation at night; curfew. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile anywhere within the city between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, 10-16-95; Ord. No. 480-04, § 1, 12-6-04) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1515(g), MSA § 9.3200(15)(g). 
Sec. 24-135. - Transporting of bows or firearms. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile while transporting thereon a bow, unless unstrung, or a firearm unless securely encased or equipped with and made inoperative by a manufactured key-locked trigger housing mechanism. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.23, 11-16-70) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1515(j), MSA § 9.3200(15)(j). 
Sec. 24-136. - Yielding to pedestrians and motor vehicles while on streets and alleys required. 
    Operators of snowmobiles, when allowed to operate on city streets and alleys, shall adhere to all speed limits and traffic regulations, and shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.25, 11-16-70) 
Sec. 24-137. - Reckless operation prohibited. 
    Snowmobiles shall not be operated in a reckless, careless or negligent manner or at a speed so as to be likely to endanger persons or property. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.28, 11-16-70) 
Sec. 24-138. - Operation by certain minors. 
(a)  A parent or legal guardian shall not permit their child who is under the age of twelve (12) to operate a snowmobile without the direct supervision of an adult except on land owned or under the control of the parent or legal guardian. 
(b)  A person who is at least twelve (12) but less than sixteen (16) years of age may operate a snowmobile if: 
(1)  Such person is under the direct supervision of a person who is eighteen (18) years of age or older; or 
(2)  Such person has in such person's immediate possession a snowmobile safety certificate issued pursuant to state law; or 
(3)  Such person is on land owned or under the control of their parent or legal guardian. A person who is operating a snowmobile pursuant to subsection (2) shall present the snowmobile safety certificate to any peace officer upon demand. 
(c)  Notwithstanding other provisions of this article, an operator who is under twelve (12) years of age shall not operate upon or cross a highway or street. An operator who is at least twelve (12) years of age but less than sixteen (16) years of age may cross a highway or street only if such operator has a valid snowmobile safety certificate in such operator's immediate possession. 
(d)  All operators of snowmobiles on public rights-of-way, streets, or alleys that have been authorized by resolution of the city commission as open for snowmobile use shall be over the age of sixteen (16) years, or if they are less than sixteen (16) years of age and at least twelve (12) years of age they must be under the direct supervision of a person over the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(e)  All operators of snowmobiles on public rights-of-way, streets, or alleys that have been authorized by resolution of the city commission as open for snowmobile use who are under the age of eighteen (18) years shall carry and possess a valid State of Michigan or other state-issued safety training certificate at all times. Upon the request of any law enforcement personnel the operator shall display for examination the certificate. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.30, 11-16-70; Ord. No. 504-08, § 1, 9-2-08) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1512a., MSA § 9.3200(12a). 
Sec. 24-139. - Curfew at other times. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile upon any streets, alleys, or rights-of-way, that have been designated by resolution of the city commission as being open for such use, at a time during which such route has been posted as closed to snowmobiles, or at any time prohibited by section 24-134. 
(Ord. No. 387-94, § 2, 12-5-94; Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, 10-16-95) 
Secs. 24-140-24-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AREAS OF OPERATION RESTRICTED 

Secs. 24-145-24-147. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, adopted Oct. 16, 1995, deleted §§ 24-145-24-147, 24-150-24-152, which pertained to operation of snowmobiles on streets and alleys, street crossings, and in forest reproduction areas. Such sections were derived from Ord. No. 84, §§ 5-1.21, 5-1.23, adopted Nov. 16, 1970; and Ord. No. 360-91, § 1, adopted Nov. 4, 1991. 
Sec. 24-148. - Operation on streets and alleys in emergencies. 
    Snowmobiles may be operated on a street, highway or alley during a period of emergency, when so declared by a police agency having jurisdiction, and when travel by conventional automotive equipment is not possible. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.21, 11-16-70) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 24-149. - Operation on streets and alleys for special events. 
    Snowmobiles may be operated on a street, alley or highway for a special event of limited duration which is conducted according to a prearranged schedule under permit from the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.21, 11-16-70) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL § 257.1512(g), MSA § 9.3200(12)(g). 
Secs. 24-150-24-152. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note following §§ 24-145-24-147. 
Sec. 24-153. - Operation on private or public property. 
    No person shall operate a snowmobile on the private property of another person, or upon any publicly owned property unless the property is posted "open to snowmobiles" by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.23, 11-16-70; Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, 10-16-95) 
Sec. 24-154. - Operation on public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Unless specifically authorized by resolution of the city commission, no person shall operate a snowmobile on any street, alley, or right-of-way. 
(b)  When a street, alley, or right-of-way has been authorized for snowmobile use by resolution of the city commission snowmobile operation on such authorized public rights-of-way shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Operation is restricted to only the far-right hand portion of the authorized public right-of-way that has been plowed. 
(2)  Operation is prohibited on any unplowed portion of the authorized public right-of-way including but not limited to any snow banks, sidewalks, or bicycle paths. 
(3)  The operator shall cause the snowmobile come to a complete stop at each and every intersection with such authorized public right-of-way even if the intersection is not posted for a required stop. 
(4)  The operator shall hand signal all turns and stops. 
(5)  The operator shall not pass any vehicle which is ahead and moving in the same direction as the snowmobile upon the right-of-way. 
(6)  The operator shall not tow any passengers with the snowmobile unless the passengers are contained in a commercially manufactured trailer designed for the conveyance of passengers and such trailer is affixed to the snowmobile by a ball or pin hitch attached to a rigid tow bar. 
(Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, 10-16-95; Ord. No. 504-08, § 1, 9-2-08) 
Sec. 24-155. - Operation at airports restricted. 
    Snowmobiles shall not be operated on any airport within the city limits except upon designated snowmobile trails or other permitted areas. The crossing of runways and taxiways are prohibited at all times. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.26, 11-16-70) 
Cross reference- Airport, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 24-156. - Operation in cemeteries. 
    Snowmobiles shall not be operated in cemeteries except by cemetery officials. 
(Ord. No. 84, § 5-1.29, 11-16-70; Ord. No. 398-95, § 1, 10-16-95) 
Cross reference- Cemeteries, Ch. 10; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFF-ROAD VEHICLES 

Sec. 24-157. - Definitions. 
    The definitions herein shall be the same as those defined in Act No. 319 of the Public Acts of 1975, as amended, being Section 257.1601 et seq. of the Michigan Compiled Laws, the definitions used therein shall be deemed to apply to the words and phrases used in this chapter. These definitions are as follows: 
(a)  City: The City of Sault Ste. Marie. 
(b)  Dealer: A person engaged in the sale, lease or rental of an ORV as a regular business. 
(c)  Decal: A pressure sensitive adhesive backed label, of size and color to be determined by the department of state, to indicate the certificate of registration number awarded the ORV and is valid until the expiration date shown thereon. 
(d)  Department: Department of state. 
(e)  Forest road: A hard-surfaced road, gravel or dirt road, fire lane, abandoned railroad right-of-way, logging road, or a way capable of travel by a four-wheel vehicle except on interstate, state, county or city highway. 
(f)  Highway: The entire width between the boundary lines of a way or alley publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
(g)  Operate: To ride in or on and be in actual physical control of the operation of an ORV. 
(h)  Operator: A person who operates or is in actual physical control of the operation of an ORV. 
(i)  ORV or vehicle: A motor driven off-road recreation vehicle capable of cross-country travel without benefit of a road or trail, on or immediately over land, snow, ice, marsh, swampland or other natural terrain. It includes, but is not limited to, a multi-track or multi-wheel drive or low pressure tire vehicle, a motorcycle or related two-wheel or three-wheel vehicle, an amphibious machine, a ground effect air cushion vehicle, or other means of transportation deriving motive power from a source other than muscle or wind. ORV or vehicle does not include a registered snowmobile, a farm vehicle being used for farming, a vehicle used for military, fire, emergency or law enforcement purposes, a construction or logging vehicle used in the performance of its common function or a registered aircraft. 
(j)  Owner: Any of the following: 
(1)  A vendee or lessee of an ORV which is the subject of an agreement for the purpose of conditional sale or lease thereof; 
(2)  A person renting an ORV or having the exclusive use of an ORV for more than thirty (30) days; 
(3)  A person who holds legal ownership of the vehicle. 
(k)  Roadway: That portion of a highway unpaved, designated or ordinarily used for vehicular travel including city alleys. 
(l)  Public property: Property owned, leased or otherwise controlled by the city, including parks, parking lots and recreational areas. 
(m)  Private property open to the public: Property which is privately owned but is open to public access. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-158. - Conditions under which operation allowed-Generally. 
    Off-road vehicles may be operated within the city limits as follows: 
(a)  An ORV operated exclusively on land owned by or under the control of the vehicle owner; 
(b)  An ORV which is operated exclusively in a special event of limited duration which is conducted according to a pre-arranged schedule under a permit from the city; 
(c)  An ORV which is operated exclusively in an approved DNR safety and training program; 
(d)  An ORV operated on approved DNR trails in the city provided the ORV operator and vehicle are being operated in full compliance of state and local ORV laws; 
(e)  An ORV operated on city property so designated for ORV use by the city commission. 
(f)  An ORV operated on a street or right-of-way, or section thereof, so designated for ORV use by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78; Ord. No. 555-15, § 1, 3-2-15) 
Sec. 24-159. - Same-Additional conditions and prohibitions. 
    No off-road vehicles shall be operated within the city limits of the City of Sault Ste. Marie except as follows: 
(a)  A person shall not operate an ORV in the city limits of Sault Ste. Marie except as provided in section 24-158. 
(b)  No person shall operate an ORV during the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half before sunrise without displaying a lighted headlight and lighted taillight. 
(c)  No person shall operate an ORV on any city alley, city park, or city parking lot, except those so designated by resolution of the city commission. 
(d)  No person shall operate an ORV on any city street or sidewalk, except as so designated by resolution of the city commission. 
(e)  No person shall operate an ORV on property owned or leased by the Sault Area Public Schools. 
(f)  No person shall operate an ORV on private land open to public access. 
(g)  The owner of an ORV shall not allow the ORV to be operated in the city except as provided. 
(h)  The operation of an ORV on private land under the control of the ORV owner in the city shall not be allowed if the ORV is not equipped with a spark arrester type muffler in good working order and in constant operation. Maximum permissive noise levels are as follows: 90db(A) for ORV made before Jan. 1, 1973; 88db(A) for ORV made after Jan. 1, 1973; and 86db(A) for ORV made after Jan. 1, 1975. Noise levels are for full throttle operation at fifty (50) feet at right angles. 
(i)  ORV operators ages twelve (12) through sixteen (16) must possess valid DNR certificates and decals and produce same at the request of a law enforcement officer. 
(j)  No ORV may be operated on public property or private property open to the public at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper having due regard for existing conditions. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78; Ord. No. 555-15, § 1, 3-2-15) 
Cross reference- Parking lots, § 24-63 et seq. 
Sec. 24-160. - Reckless operation, operation in cemeteries prohibited. 
(a)  An ORV shall not be operated in a reckless, careless or negligent manner or at a speed so as to be likely to endanger persons or property. 
(b)  Off-road vehicles shall not be operated in cemeteries, except by cemetery officials, and no person under the age of twelve (12) years shall operate an off-road vehicle in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan, unless the operator is accompanied by an adult. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-161. - Responsibility of owner for violation. 
    In a proceeding for a violation of this article involving prohibited operation or conduct, the decal number displayed on the ORV constitutes prima facie evidence that the owner of the ORV was the person operating the ORV at the time of this offense. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-162. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to those penalties as set forth in section 1-6 of the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-163. - Owner not to allow unlawful operation. 
    No person shall knowingly authorize or permit an off-road vehicle owned by him or under his control to be driven by any person in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-164. - Operators to obey uniformed police officers. 
    The operator of an ORV who is given by hand, voice, emergency light or siren a visual or audible signal by a uniformed police officer, acting in the lawful performance of his duty, directing the operator to bring his/her ORV to a stop, shall do so. An operator shall not willfully fail to obey the direction by increasing his speed or otherwise attempting to flee or elude the officer. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-165. - Operation while under influence of intoxicating drugs prohibited. 
    No person shall operate an ORV in the city or any approved ORV area while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drug, barbital or other prohibited controlled substance. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-166. - Operation upon the property of another. 
    No person shall operate an ORV upon the property of another without the permission of the owner. The operator of an ORV is liable for damage to private property including but not limited to damage to trees, shrubs, injury to living creatures or erosive or other ecological damage to the private or public property. Failure to post or otherwise fence any public or private property or to personally communicate against trespass shall not imply consent for ORV use. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78) 
Sec. 24-167. - Operation near dwellings. 
    No person shall operate an ORV within one hundred (100) feet of any dwelling or house in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, except where such operation is on an ORV trail designated by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 194, 8-7-78; Ord. No. 555-15, § 1, 3-2-15) 
Chapter 25 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; preservation of trees in subdivisions, § 23-55; operation of snowmobiles in nurseries, planting areas, etc., prohibited, § 24-152; zoning requirements for planting materials, App. A, § 10-1.17(1709). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Removal of noxious weeds required; notice. 
(a)  No person shall fail to cut down, remove, destroy or otherwise obliterate all Canadian thistles, milkweed, ragweed, wild carrot, burdock, oxeye daisies, or other noxious weeds or grasses growing on property owned by such person or under their possession or control. 
(b)  The city manager shall determine a date after which any noxious weeds or grasses found growing will be destroyed by the city. Notice of this date shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks so that the second notice appears at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date so set. 
(c)  Noxious weeds are considered a public nuisance and thus subject to the provisions of chapter 18. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.09) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 18. 
Secs. 25-2-25-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREES, SHRUBS AND PLANTS 

Sec. 25-16. - Planting or removing in public places. 
    No person, except the city, shall plant, remove or destroy any ornamental shade trees or shrubs in any public place unless authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.06) 
Sec. 25-17. - Attaching articles to trees in street areas prohibited. 
    No person shall attach any guy rope, wire, cable or other contrivance whatsoever, to any tree in any public place or use the same for any banner, sign or purpose whatever. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.06) 
Sec. 25-18. - Permit required to cut, trim, etc., trees in public places. 
    No person shall cut, trim, saw or otherwise mutilate any tree in any public place to make room for telephone, telegraph or electric line wires, moving of buildings or machinery, building a sidewalk, or for any other purpose, without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.06; Ord. No. 516-10, § 2, 5-3-10) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 25-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 516-10, § 1, adopted May 3, 2010, repealed § 25-19, which pertained to location of trees and shrubs near sidewalks restricted and derived from Code 1957, § 7-1.06. 
Sec. 25-20. - Removal when roots are causing damage to public property. 
    When in the judgment of the city manager, the roots of any tree or bush are causing damage to any sewer, sidewalk, pavement or other public property the same may be declared to be a public nuisance and shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 18. 
(Code 1957, § 6-1.10) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 25-21. - Permit required to plant certain species on private property. 
    No person shall plant any poplar, box elder, basswood, willow, soft maple, common catalpa, horse chestnut tree, or "ailanthus glandulosa" on any private property without first obtaining a written permit to do so from the city manager. 
(Code 1957, §§ 6-1.10, 7-1.06) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits, Ch. 14. 
Sec. 25-22. - Trimming of trees and shrubs near streets and alleys required by property owners or occupants. 
(a)  The person having the care, either as owner or occupant, of any premises bordered by a public street or alley shall trim any limbs or branches of trees or shrubs growing on such premises in such a manner that a clear space of eight (8) feet shall be found between such branches and the ground surface of the public street or alley. 
(b)  The person having the care, either as owner or occupant, of any premises bordered by a public street or alley shall trim any hedge or bush on said premises in such a manner that no part encroaches upon the public street or alley. 
(Code 1957, § 7-1.06) 
Sec. 25-23(1). - Definitions. 
    Street trees : "Street trees" are defined as trees and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, alleys, or rights-of-way within the city. 
    Park trees : "Park trees" are herein defined as trees and all other woody vegetation in public parks which have individual names, and all other areas owned by the city upon which the public has free access as a park. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-23(2). - Creation and establishment of a city tree commission. 
    There is hereby created and established a City Tree Commission for the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan, which shall consist of seven (7) members, each of who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the commission. The city commission may appoint one (1) of its members as a nonvoting liaison to the tree commission. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-23(3). - Terms of office. 
    The term of the seven (7) persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be four (4) years, except that the first members appointed shall have staggered terms. Two (2) of the members appointed to the first commission shall be for a one-year term, two (2) of the members appointed to the first commission shall be for a two year term, two (2) of the members appointed to the first commission shall be for a three-year term, one (1) member appointed to the first commission shall be a four-year term. Two (2) members of the commission shall possess a professional background relating to landscaping, tree care, or agriculture. Members appointed to the commission must be at all times registered voters of the city, except for the two (2) members appointed to the commission possessing a background related to landscaping, tree care, or agriculture. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member the successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. Members may be re-appointed without regard to the terms limits prescribed in section 2-31 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-23(4). - Compensation. 
    Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-23(5). - Duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the commission: 
(a)  To study, investigate, develop, amend, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented to the city commission and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive City Tree Plan for the City of Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan. The tree commission, when requested by the city commission, shall consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(b)  To review plans for tree maintenance for all utility companies planning on conducting tree maintenance within the public rights-of-way. 
(c)  To recommend an annual budget to the city manager for various tree activities within the city including anticipated revenues and expenses relating to providing trimming, removal, planting and professional services needed to maintain city trees. 
(d)  To pursue fund raising activities including obtaining public or private grants or gifts, memorials, honorary tree planting, and the creation of an endowment fund for maintaining trees within the city. 
(e)  To advise the city manager, city administration, and other boards and commissions on various land use standards relating to tree and landscaping requirements for public and private developments. 
(f)  To advise the city manager on methods to purchase and produce public trees for street and park planting. 
(g)  To educate city employees, utility companies and private citizens on proper tree planting and renovation activities. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-23(6). - Operation. 
    The tree commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep minutes of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-23(7). - Street tree species to be planted. 
    The tree commission shall include in the City Tree Plan for the City of Sault Ste. Marie a comprehensive listing of acceptable street trees that can be planted in the street right-of-way in accordance with the provisions of this article. The listing of tree species should include small trees with mature height of fifteen (15) to twenty (20) feet (which could include such trees as flowering crab-apple and serviceberry) medium trees with a mature height of thirty (30) to fifty (50) feet (honey locust and linden), and large trees with a mature height of fifty (50) feet or more (bur oak and sugar maple). Species of trees included in this list shall have an appropriate branching structure to minimize interference with vehicles and pedestrians utilizing adjacent streets and sidewalks. The root structure of selected tree species shall minimize interference with underground utilities, sidewalks, and streets. Furthermore, the tree commission shall include in the city tree plan the minimum trunk size for trees to be planted in the public right-of-way. 
    This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners provided that the selection of the tree is in accordance with all sections of chapter 25 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-24(1). - Spacing. 
    No trees may be planted closer together than the following: small trees, thirty (30) feet; medium trees, forty (40) feet; and large trees, fifty (50) feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a tree commission. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-24(2). - Distance from curb and sidewalk. 
    The distance trees may be planted from curbs, curb lines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in section 25-23(7), and no trees may be planted closer to any curb, curb line, or sidewalk than the following: small trees, two (2) feet; medium trees, three (3) feet; and large trees, four (4) feet. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-24(3). - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten (10) feet of any fireplug. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-24(4). - Utilities. 
    No street trees other than those species listed as small trees in section 25-23(7) may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-25(1). - Public tree care. 
    The city shall have the right to plant, prune, and maintain trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety or preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-25(2). - Public tree removal. 
    The city tree commission shall review and determine whether street trees should be removed as requested by any city departments or utility companies operating within the right-of-way or the general public after property owners owning property adjacent to, or within fifty (50) feet of the street tree proposed for removal have been provided a minimum seven (7) days' written notice and have been given an opportunity to comment at a city tree commission meeting. If three (3) or more street trees are to be removed from a single block, then all property owners on the block should be notified of this proposal and given an opportunity to appear before the city tree commission. If a street tree in the sole opinion of the city manager poses an immediate danger, then authorization of the tree commission and related notices are note required. 
    The city tree commission may order removal of any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-25(3). - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the city tree commission. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-26(1). - Pruning, corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-26(2). - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
    The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitutes a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city tree commission will direct notification in writing to the owners of such trees in the same manner as prescribed in article III. Removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense as prescribed in article III. In the event of failure of the owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal on the owner's property tax as prescribed in article III. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-26(3). - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-28. - Interference with city tree commission. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree commission, any of its agents, city employees, or city contractors while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in Ordinance No. 516-10. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-29. - Arborist's license and insurance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring a city license from the city clerk. The license fee shall be in the amount set annually by resolution of the city commission as stated in the city fee schedule; provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-30. - Review by city commission. 
    The city commission shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the city tree commission. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree commission to the city commission who may hear the matter and make a final decision. A request for an appeal may only be made by filing a written request with the city clerk within ten (10) calendar days of the action of the tree commission. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-31. - Penalty. 
    Violations of this article shall be subject to penalties as outlined in section 1-6 of the City of Sault Ste. Marie Code. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-32. - Designate Arbor Day. 
    Arbor Day will be celebrated on the last Friday in April each year. 
(Ord. No. 516-10, § 3, 5-13-10) 
Sec. 25-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DUTCH ELM DISEASE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances, Ch. 18. 

Sec. 25-34. - Public nuisance declared. 
(a)  All species and varieties of elm trees, trees of the genus Ulmus, infected with the fungus known as the Dutch elm disease ( Certostomella ulmi ) are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  All species and varieties of elm trees that are dead or substantially dead and all dead elmwood to which the bark is still attached, which, because of their condition, may serve as a breeding place for the European Elm Bark Beetle ( Scolytus multiariatus ), or Native Elm Bark Beetle ( Hylurgopinus rufis ), are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 61, §§ 1, 2 (6-5.01), (6-5.02), 9-9-68) 
Sec. 25-35. - Removal of nuisance required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner of any lot or land in the city to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, any elm tree or dead elmwood which, as provided in section 25-34, is a public nuisance, and it shall be the duty of any such owner promptly to remove and burn any such elm tree or dead elmwood under the supervision and direction of the city manager. 
(b)  Any elm tree or dead elmwood on property owned by the city which is a public nuisance shall promptly be removed and burned under the supervision of the city manager at the expense of the city. 
(Ord. No. 61, §§ 3, 8 (6-5.03), (6-5.08), 9-9-68) 
Sec. 25-36. - Access to lands for inspection; interference prohibited. 
    In order to carry out the purposes of this article and to implement the enforcement thereof, the city manager is hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon any lot or land in the city at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting any elm trees or dead elmwood situated thereon and the city manager may remove such specimens from any such tree as are required to determine whether such tree because it is dead or substantially dead may serve as a breeding place for the Elm Bark Beetle. It shall be unlawful for any person to take any action to prevent the city manager from entering on any lot or land in the city for the purpose of such inspection, or to interfere with the city manager or such representative in the performance of any duties provided for under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 61, § 4 (6-5.04), 9-9-68) 
Sec. 25-37. - Notice to abate; service of notice; abatement. 
(a)  If, on analysis of specimens removed from any elm tree, it is determined that such tree is a public nuisance as provided by section 25-34, the city manager shall serve or cause to be served upon the person who is owner of the lot or land on which such tree or dead elmwood is located, a written notice requiring such owner to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Service of notice shall be by personal service if the owner of the lot or land on which an infected elm tree, as aforesaid, is located is a resident of the city, or, if a nonresident of the city, written notice shall be served by certified mail, addressed to such owner at the last-known address of such owner. 
(c)  If the person upon whom such notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to remove and destroy by burning such elm tree or dead elmwood within ten (10) days after service of such notice, the city manager may proceed to remove and burn such tree or dead elmwood and assess the cost thereof against the owner of such lot or land, and the amount of such cost shall be paid by such owner to the city. 
(Ord. No. 61, §§ 5, 6 (6-5.05), (6-5.06), 9-9-68) 
Sec. 25-38. - Assessment to be in addition to penalties. 
    If the city removes any infected elm tree which is a public nuisance or any dead or substantially dead elm tree or dead elmwood, the assessment of the cost of the work done by the city against the owner of the lot or land involved shall be in addition to the penalties imposed herein for any violation or noncompliance with any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 61, § 7 (6-5.07), 9-9-68) 
Cross reference- Single lot procedure for special assessments, Ch. 21, Art. V. 
Sec. 25-39. - Violation of article provisions. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article by failing, neglecting or refusing to comply with the provisions of any notice herein provided for, within ten (10) days after the service thereof, or who shall resist or obstruct the city manager in carrying out the provisions of this article, shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalty provided in section 1-6. 
(Ord. No. 61, § 9 (6-5.09), 9-9-68)

Chapter 27 - WATER SUPPLY AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal utilities, Ch. 13. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; drain laying, Ch. 8, Art. IV; garbage, rubbish, litter and junk, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; subdivision regulations, Ch. 23; sewage disposal improvements in subdivisions, § 23-53; water supply improvements in subdivisions, § 23-54; zoning ordinance, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Combined system. 
    The water supply and sewage disposal system of the city shall be operated and maintained as one system on a combined-rate basis and such system shall include all wells, pumps, pumphouses, water mains and laterals, water and sewer pumping stations, water storage and treatment facilities, sewers, force main and lift stations, sewage treatment facilities and all attendant facilities and equipment which are used or useful in the operation and maintenance of the water supply and sewage disposal system, now in existence or hereafter acquired. 
(Ord. No. 55, § 2, 2-26-68) 
Sec. 27-2. - Operation. 
    The operation, repair and management of the water supply and sewage disposal system, and the acquiring of the authorized public improvements shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager, subject to overall control by the city commission. The city commission may make such rules, orders and regulations and appoint such personnel as it may deem necessary to assure the efficient management and operation of the system. 
(Ord. No. 55, § 9, 2-26-68) 
Sec. 27-3. - Fiscal year. 
    The water supply and sewage disposal system shall be operated on the basis of an operating year commencing July first and ending on the last day of the following June. 
(Ord. No. 55, § 14, 2-26-68) 
Sec. 27-4. - Records; annual statement by city manager. 
    The city manager shall cause to be maintained and kept proper books of record and account, in which shall be made full and correct entries of all transactions relating to the water supply and sewage disposal system. Such books of record and account shall be audited annually by a certified public accountant, to be designated by the city commission, and a certified copy of such audit shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 10, § 1 (7-3.10), 10-19-59; Ord. No. 522-10, § 1, 10-4-10) 
Sec. 27-5. - Right to prohibit use of system. 
    If the character of sewage from any manufacturing or industrial plant or any other building or premises shall be such as to impose an unreasonable additional burden upon the sewers of the water supply and sewage disposal system, then an additional charge may be made over and above the regular rates, or it may be required that such sewage be treated by the person responsible therefor before being emptied into the sewer, or the right to empty such sewage may be denied if necessary for the protection of the sewer and sewage disposal facilities of the system or the public health or safety. 
(Ord. No. 55, § 12, 2-26-68) 
Sec. 27-6. - Free service prohibited. 
    No free service shall be furnished by the water supply and sewage disposal system to any person. The city shall pay for all services furnished to it or to any of its departments at the established rates, fees and charges, or any revision thereof. 
(Ord. No. 10, § 1 (7-3.08), 10-19-59; Ord. No. 55, § 11, 2-26-68) 
Sec. 27-7. - Rules, regulations, fees and charges promulgated by city manager. 
(a)  The city manager shall make such rules and regulations as such manager finds necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Any rule or regulation made by the city manager shall be in writing. A copy of each such rule or regulation shall be filed with the city clerk before the same is put into effect. The clerk shall present such rule or regulation to the city commission for its consideration not later than the next regular meeting of the commission after the filing of same. No such rule or regulation shall remain in effect if disapproved by the city commission. 
(c)  No person shall violate any such rule or regulation promulgated in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1957, § 7-2.09; Ord. No. 10, § 1 (7-3.08), 10-19-59; Ord. No. 522-10, § 1, 10-4-10) 
Sec. 27-8. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  The rates, charges and deposits to be charged for water and sewer service furnished by the water supply and sewage disposal system shall be as presently established or as changed from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(b)  The city commission may also establish, upon recommendation of the city manager, by resolution rates, fees and charges for supplying water and sewage disposal service to premises located outside the corporate limits of the city, which rates, fees and charges shall be not less than the rates, fees and charges provided for service furnished to premises within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 10, § 1 (7-3.08), 10-19-59; Ord. No. 55, § 10, 2-26-68; Ord. No. 56, § 1, 2-26-68; Ord. No. 522-10, § 1, 10-4-10) 
Sec. 27-9. - Collection of rates and charges; lien upon premises; discontinuance of service. 
(a)  In addition to other remedies possessed by the city for the collection of water and sewage disposal rates, assessments, charges or rentals for the use of the water supply and sewage disposal system by any house or building or any premises, lot, or lots, or parcel, or parcels of land, the city shall have as security for the collection thereof a lien upon such house or other building, and upon the premises or lot, or lots, or parcel, or parcels of land, upon which such house or other building shall be situated, or to which such water has been supplied. Such lien shall become effective immediately upon service to the premises or property, and the official records of the city shall constitute notice of the pendency of such lien. Such lien shall have priority over all other liens, except taxes and special assessments, whether or not such liens have accrued or were recorded, prior to the lien herein created. 
(b)  All water supply and sewage disposal charges which have been due and unpaid for thirty (30) days or more shall be reported by the city manager to the city commission at the time single lot special assessments are normally requested. All unpaid water rates or charges which are reported by the city manager to the city commission as having been due and unpaid shall be transferred to the city's tax roll and assessed against the property to which service was supplied or furnished. Such unpaid rates or charges shall be collected in the same manner as city taxes are collected. If the same shall remain delinquent and unpaid after the expiration of the time limited in the warrant for the collection of taxes levied in such roll, such charges shall be returned to the county treasurer to be collected in the same manner as city taxes on the delinquent tax roll of the city. 
(c)  The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) shall not apply in any instance where a written lease has been or is legally executed, containing a provision that the lessor shall not be liable for payment of water supply and sewage disposal bills; provided an affidavit with respect to the execution of such lease shall be filed with the officer in charge of accounting in the city, and twenty (20) days' notice shall be given to the city by the lessor of any cancellation, change in or termination of the lease. 
(d)  In addition to other remedies provided, the city shall have the right to shut off and discontinue the supply of water to any premises, pursuant to section 27-26, for the nonpayment of water supply and sewage disposal rates, fees and charges when due. 
(Code 1957, § 7-2.10; Ord. No. 10, § 1 (7-3.08), 10-19-59; Ord. No. 522-10, § 1, 10-4-10) 
Secs. 27-10-27-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SUPPLY 

Sec. 27-21. - Application for service; deposit.
